Pours with a lustrous golden orange color and a sticky, foamy head. the aroma has a bright and fruity hop bitterness, with a mild bready sweetness to provide some balance. The flavor likewise has a solid malt backbone, but the powerful bitterness dominates, albeit without being over-the-top abrasive. The mouthfeel is resinous, but the beer is still tremendously drinkable. Overall, this is one of the beers that I think exemplifies the prototypical West-coast IPA. Its like sunshine on a cloudy day. Boom.

Poured from 12 fl oz bottle. Clear golden yellow with white head. Aroma of citrus(and a little tropical) hops and slightly funk malt character. Some mellow citrus hops come through on the flavour with a bitter dry finish. A little too thin in taste and body though. It almost seemed a little flat (perhaps the bottle was sitting in the store too long - I dont see a bottling date).

650 ml bottle (enjoy by 7/1/14) poured into stem glass. Clear amber hue with a generous frothy white cap with impressive retention and lacing. Earthy aromas of pine and citrus zest dominate. Flavor is resinous and citrusy hop perfectly balanced against a carmely malt backbone. Mouthfeel is slightly astringent but wholly satisfying. This is my measuring stick for "regular" IPAs and never disappoints.
Golden pour with white head. Leaves lacing in the glass. Renowned for its hoppiness, this beer does not disappoint. Overall hoppy flavor with notes of citrus.

Bottle. pours a light golden colour. 

Aroma. Mainly a citrus aromas.

Taste. Very bitter throughout, with a nice combination of citrus and pine flavours, backed by a very slight maltiness.
thanks to my dad for bringing this back to me from the states, very expensive and hard to find here.

Overall. Everything about this beer is brilliant, dominated by a strong bitterness, complimented well with a nice citrus backing, and a maltiness that doesnt really add much flavour to the beer but acts to tame the bitterness and the overall flavour profile in general.

Bottle poured a lightly hazed orange hue w/ medium thick white lasting head and sticky lacing. Big sweet hop aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a bold bitter finish of long duration. Tastes are straw, pine, grass, and grapefruit. Medium bodied.

Faint hop aroma, mainly mango, probably a bit to old. Golden clear, white head. Really bitter, just enough maltiness to back up the bitterness without beeing noticed. Light body average carbonation. Nice taste but could have done with more aroma, probably lacks due to age

Personally, I want some of an aftertaste in my IPAs and this one has just the right amount. Hop bitterness comes through in the end but does not blow you away. I really could drink this everyday.

very very good india pale ale....tons of hops....great flavor.....one of the best...no doubt.
UPDATED: SEP 9, 2016 Bottle. What should i say a real classic. Citrus, pine and hop Aroma. Taste is fruity Aroma hops with malt sweetness. Aftertaste is bitter. Classic

As it was in the beginning, is now, and forever shall be, the quintessential SoCal IPA.Popped my craft brew cherry with the 22oz. incarnation and have wavered back and forth about the merits of the beer (primarily due to competition from the widely underappreciated but arguably most-likely-to-rival, Lagunitas IPA). But in the end, it?s the original, the meter by which all other IPAs are measured.Nose is ripe, resiny hop, cut-grass, bready malt, some sourness, and a lingering waft of orange citrus. Balanced heaviness in mouthfeel and tingly carbonation give way to sticky hop, biscuits, and bright citrus flavors that build and linger on the tongue. Alcohol is not upfront but shows up in the profile as the glass gets lower. While I could apply a myriad of exacting critiques - i.e its very sharp in flavor and not necessarly right for drinking on the reg - it?s a real classic. Oh yeah, and it looks pretty good in a glass...

Good lacing with a little retention. Smells of citrus hops, floral and sweet malts. Tastes of sweet malt, tropical hops and long bitter finish.

By far my 2nd favorite IPA (Ruination is my first). Great flavor and if I had to drink only one brand it would be Stone. This, Ruination, Arrogant Bastard and Levitation all are up high on any beer list I would make.

Aroma: strong hops, citrus, tropical fruits, flowers. Appearance: dark hazy gold, hardly any head. Taste: medium to strong bitters. My bottle is a month from the enjoy by date on the bottle neck. A nice blue smoke and a pale yellow pour into a hazy orange body. A full two-finger, white, medium-rocky, very dense and creamy head, it will last a while. The smell is amazing with great hops, yeasts and malt aromas fully developed, and rising out of my glass. The mouth gets an overload of flavor immediately. Its piney and cotton candy, bitter and sweet all at once. It goes down as smooth and creamy as it smells and leaves you with only a dry, slight lingering bitterness and the wanting of another sip. Its probably the best non-imperial IPA available. No home should be without a fresh six pack.

12oz bottle 
Pulled out the "IPA glass" for this one - certainly didnt disappoint; lovely clean pale gold body, holding a dense, creamy inch of white foam, painting thick lace in its wake.
Punchy aroma; hops, hops and more hops...as expected! Pine needle, grapefruit rind, cedar, dried grassy herbs, unripe melon, resiny, sappy - I could go on. but lets no discount some detectable biscuity toasty malt in amongst the hop maelstrom.
Medium bodied, subdued carbonation welcomed, resiny on the body lending an almost oily texture.
Intensely hoppy on the body; once again resiny, woody, sharp citrus. Malt makes an appearance as a light golden syrup, biscuit character, providing some sort of relief. Bitterness firm but balanced, lingering grassy character.
Very well made beer indeed. Despite the full on hop character, theres a good sense of balance and sessionability. Could easily drink a number of these...one is just not enough..

Clear amber pour with a decent white head. Hoppy as hell. Pine, grapefruit, hops, slight mango, catty, caramel, hops. Hops, hops, hops. Stone IPA is quite meaty and absolutely palate stripping. Love it.

Stones IPA, to me, represents everything wrong with the current beer trend. One day, people will look back at this obsession with hops and realize what a bizarre palate people in this day and age. 

Thats not to say hops are bad. No. But, excessive bittering hops, without any counter balance, are. And, Stone IPA, to me, represents that extreme. It comes off with this nasty medicinal bittering taste akin to aspirin. There is also this strong after taste that lingers on the palate for days. I couldnt get rid of that aspirin like linger on my palate even days after finishing off a Stone multipack. It was just nasty, and I vowed to swear off Stone forever. Contrast this with more floral IPAs such as Pliny the Elder or Simtra triple IPAs. With these brews, there is a more floral, sweet aroma and taste that finishes very clean and dry. Very little after taste. The predominant use of simcoe and amarillo hops gives those beers their characteristic aromatic hoppy smells and tastes that, I think, isnt emphasized enough nowadays in the single IPA.
Nice hoppy IPA aroma. Golden in color with a nice head. Crisp, lite citrus, good bitterness and mellow. Not too heavy. Overall a very good IPA.

I like...different from my citrus bomb iPas I love... More I don't know... herbal? Spicy hops... Good and I like...

Outstanding ipa, nice colour, crisp bitter finish and the hop aroma lingers. One of the elite.

Very solid, above average IPA, dry hopped as advertised, plenty of hops. If in an IPA mood, cant go wrong. Love that Costco has a great deal on a 24. Otherwise hard to find it less than $8.99 for a 6r and $9.99 normally. and there are equal or better IPAs for a dollar less.

The year is 2010, an Aussie craft beer novice travels to sunny California with his brother, he tastes Stone IPA, he is first overwhelmed by the crazy hop blast, by the end of the longneck he is converted forever to hoppy beers. Well done Stone, you made a beer wanker out of this Aussie! Perfection.

Bottle into shaker. Amber, clear, effervescent. Aroma is like holding a handful of hops. Definitely extensively dry hopped. Flavor is southern pine, and floral hops. Although the hop flavor is predominant, it is not offensive. Hardly balanced. Unable to detect any other flavors, but its not such a bad thing. Overall this beer pushes the envelope of an IPA, but in a good way. If youre a hop head youve come to the right beer.

Smells of sweet fruit toffee (grapefruit, apples). Tastes sweet at first then dry as the hops hit you with a lasting finish. A little overly hoppy for my personal taste - needs more sweetness to balance.

Rated by BrewTom

12 oz bottle into shaker. Pours clear orange-amber with a solid two-finger white head. Lots of lacing left on the glass. Aroma is a powerful hop blast: citrus, floral, and pine. A fair amount of caramel and bread malt lies below the trademarked Stone aroma. Taste is medium-high bitterness from citrus peel, pine, and flower hoppiness supported by a nice malty sweet ribbon through each sip. Medium body, slick and creamy, average carbonation, long, bitter finish. Nice to finally drink an archetypal IPA from a bedrock craft brewer.
Great solid brew. Gold dark orange hue. Great mango pine aroma with taste to follow. Agin real solid.

Golden, clear with nice light yellow foam that lasts somewhat. Fruits, flowers mild citrus in the aroma. mild malt, toffee, with HUGE flowery bitterness, strong bitter aftertaste - grapefruit. High in carbon, almost to high.

Bottle. Clear golden pour with a nice white head. Lacing is evident. Aromas of strong pine and citrus waft from the glass. Nice pungent dank hops throughout. Nice piney burn of hops lingers after the swallow. Awesome drinkable IPA!
one of the better Stope beers, nice pine and citrus aroma with a clean bitter and dry finish.

I had a comparative tasting with one of my friends who isnt used to craft beer of the Stone Pale Ale vs the Stone IPA, the bottles were from Antenna America. I would have thought the IPA would have been darker but it is a deep gold while the pale ale is an orange copperish hue. The aroma is biscuit with herbal & floral hoppy notes while the IPA has more of a citrus & tropical fruit aroma. Taste wise the pale ale has a simple clean bitter lemon profile with a solid malt backbone. The flavor of the IPA is more complex with different fruits popping through lemon, lime, grapefruit, peach & maybe pine in the aftertaste. The malts are hardly in evidence but it is a solid IPA. One thing to be said is both of these beers were best before the end of November-still damn tasty though. Once they warmed up the IPA became more cohesive with pine notes coming through, meanwhile the pale ale got mellow with more caramel nicely counterbalancing the citrusy hops & making the beer appear less acidic. Definitely a more put together flavor profile once they warm up, strangely enough the beers we liked best changed based on serving temperature. Cold from the fridge the pale ale won out but at a higher temperature the IPA was our preferred drink.
hoppy,citrusy,piney...but overrated..have had much better IPAs..especially west coast ones.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance: large white head that diminishes rather quickly, great lacing, golden straw color, slightly cloudy. Aroma: orange zest, resin, grass, caramel, floral. Palate: light body, sticky texture, average carbonation, bitter finish. Taste: slightly sweet, little bit of malts building up to the lasting bitterness that finishes through the taste with the slightest bit of metallic at the end. Overall, solid IPA, but not the best by Stones standards; just not balanced as well as maybe it should be.

Its a hazy yellow color with a poof of white foam. Even though its well before the best buy date, Im not sensing the "bountiful hop aroma" as promised. It does have a slight pleasant lemon aroma up front. Bountiful and complex bitter hop flavors and a substatial malt backbone are what make this beer worthwhile, if not quite worth the price tag.

pours a clear light golden amber color, one finger of a light off white head. bubbles last a while, with great lacing. smell is bready and caramel malts, earthy and slightly citrus hops. i get a bit of lemon. the taste is perfectly balanced, and bittered IPA. more of an east coast style with a lemon flavor. the bitterness lasts a while. overall, a great well balanced IPA.
Pours gold with thin but long lasting head. Malt, citrus and pine on the nose. Taste - bitter upfront, dry, citrus and pine, ends with long bitter slightly chewy finish. Awesome.

Bottle. Pours clear Amber with a lasting White head. Asserive pine aroma with a touch of citrus. Its clearly a top IPA. So well balanced and so flavoursome. The bitterness, the aroma, the malty caramel backdrop. Its a topper. Gets ye pished n aw.

12 oz bottle, dark golden pour with minimal white head. Aroma of pine, grapefruit and tropical fruit. Taste - bitter sweet up front medium hoppy finish with a bit of a kick a nice bit of malty sweetness. A really nice well rounded IPA.

My palate doesnt allow me to be too particular, but I try every/all IPAs wherever I go. Stone IPA is my staple. I live in San Diego, buy it by the case at Costco and feed it to all my friends. I drink it every day and have no negative comments - it tastes great and its my favorite beer. I am 71 years old and have been a beer drinker for 50 years - this is my favorite of all time.
Pours Amber, quite sweet on the nose with caramel and cooked sugars coming strong. Apricots and citrus fruits with a hint of pine also on the palate.
Nice aroma of fresh hops. Taste is hop forward over a crisp ale without being overly bitter or strong on alcohol. I would say this sets the standard for what IPA should be judged from.
Excellent aroma perfectly clear excellent carbonation great white head. It had a slight astringentcy, extremely dry, still a very good beer

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2015 Stone is no stranger to hoppy beers. They prove it with their legendary IPA. Stone IPA has everything youd expect from a West Coast style India Pale Ale. Its dank, bitter, and loaded with citrus tones. In short, this is everything you could want or expect from an IPA.
It doesn?t get much better than this IPA, strong, robust, pronounced in every category.
With such high ratings, I thought I would be more impressed by this beer. Its a great IPA, well balanced flavor and a pleasant bitterness.

This beer has a clear amber color with a large white head sitting on top of it, and the aroma is pure hops: resin, floral, citrus, and spruce. The taste is quite bitter (without it being too overwheming on the tongue) with a hint of sourness, and the palate fuses a bitter finish, average carbonation, slightly sticky texture, and a medium-full body. Overall, its a solid IPA that can easily be enjoyed.

0,33L bottle. Pours golden with big white head, the head stays. Aroma is intense hop, floral, fruits, sweet, pine, perfume like. Taste has a lot of hops of course, floral, pine, hints of honey, fruits. Finish gets bitterer, but also floral and slight sweetness are still present. It is medium-bodied, average-lively carbonation. Overall: very good IPA.

Excellent beer. The nose could be a little more agressive, but so well balanced. Like it a little more than the ruination

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark honey tinged golden brown. Huge creamy head with excellent lacing. Giant yeasty aroma (smells like a warm loaf of yeasty bread). Tastes of banana and clove, with a grapefruit aftertaste. Spectacular!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear amber with white one finger lasting head. Lovely lacing to the last. Looks fantastic. Aroma is mango, spruce, pine, citrus. Flavour is under stated sweetness with grapefruit bitterness on finish and then a final hit of caramel strawberry all the way. Not a hint water. Medium body, light carbonation. Slick mouthfeel. This is the best ipa Ive had and enjoyed it immensely.
Bottle in the Head of Steam, Durham. Golden ale with a thin white head. Massive hop aroma and taste. Very piney with cut grass and a touch of citrus. Light, refreshing, very bitter and very good.
On tap at Twisted Root - medium dark yellow. Had a nice hop aroma and a citrusy dry hop taste. Not bad at all.
Nice with a spicy meal, a littl bitter but then again it is an ipa, great standard beer.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 Grapefruit and resin in the aroma. The pine and resin come through in the taste, with the bitter grapefruit bringing up in the rear. The perfect amount of malt balance. Just a fantastic IPA.
Very good my first beer I actually enjoyed bitter taste and high alcohol percentage.

This is my first taste of Stone IPA and I must admit I was looking forward to it. It pours with a centimetre or two of white creamyish head, which quickly disappears leaving an almost soapy-like lacing. The beer itself is an inviting looking slightly hazy yellow amber. The smell is lots of floral hops with resiny pine notes coming through with pineapple and grapefruit and even a touch of tangerine. Taste wise this beer hits you hard with the Hops from the moment it touches the tongue, this is a good thing as far as I am concerned. The flavours are similar to how it smells, so if you are fond of the style then this is highly recomended! With other IPAs I have tried previously the hop bitterness times its time to enter the equation. In the mouth the beer has a medium body with a lovely thick feel with noticable to lively carbonation. The bitterness is there in the finish and it lingers for a loooong time!
All in all I loved it and am definitely buying more of this in future.

Pint at The Tavern in Farmington, CT. 
Pour is a golden copper with a beautiful head and sick lacing. Smell is hops, grapefruit and pine. Maybe some bitter orange. Taste is a hop blast, perfect balance of bittering and floral hops with a citrusy grapefruit bite. Good amount of sweetness in the malt balances everything. Nice mild bitterness between sips. Really good IPA.

355ml bottle from Drinkstore. God bless that shop and all who sail in her. Brilliant clear golden amber, big frothy white head, medium lasting. Pine, resin, spruce, tropical fruits, pineapple in the aroma. Flavour is sweet and fruity up front, resiny, pithy notes followed by whopper bitterness, grapefruit notes dominate. Medium body, slick mouthfeel. Finish is long and very bitter, with an underlying caramel sweetness in the background. I love west Coast IPA.

Caramel malt/biscuit notes as it warms up. M - Medium bodied. Lively carbonated. Slight slick mouthfeel. Citrus rind finish. O - Balanced hop profile tropical/resin. World class IPA.

Drank at Thanksmas 2014. Great go to IPA from Stone. Pours dark amber with white head.

true tasting IPA ..has bitterness that some lack great flavor . It doesnt have the alcohol taste that you sometimes get with a 6+ % content .

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2013 Double Dry hopped @ the brewery version:
Scored at brewery one week ago.

Nice honey amber ale wit ha couple fingers of soapy white foam and gauzy lace. Excellent clarity. Nose is grapefruit, peppercorn, honey, pine, a hint of mango and some resin. Flavor is nice and bitter with a solid biscuit malt profile and some nice resiny flavors. There is a bit of tangerine and pine in here as well. Medium bodied with moderate carb and a wet, yet cloying finish. Nice beer.

09-23-2012

Bottle review:

Bb: 5/18/11

A: Pours a honey ale with exceptional clarity with a two finger head of off-white blossoming head which dissipates slowly to leave a thick sheet of the same. Spotty lacing.

S: Pine, resin, mostly dominate the nose here. some medium grain and caramel tones. Lightest hints of mint and cotton candy. Decent.

T: Balanced. Super balanced. I dont believe this beer is super fresh, but the hops have died out a bit the beer is dominated by a healthy malt backbone and early hopping bitterness. Nearly good, but now, above average.

M: Medium body, and medium to light carb. Good feel. Leaves mouth with little reminder that it was just there.

O: Very drinkable. I wouldnt call this beer great, but I could likely drink all night, and thats a sign of a quality flagship beer, as this is.

Serving type: bottle

03-19-2011
22 oz. Pours light amber color. Strong Hop scent. Very hoppy flavor. The hops linger on the tongue for a while. Beautiful.

One of the standards in IPA. Light yellow color with excellent lacing. The dry hopping leaves this beer with an excellent aroma of pine and citrus that leans toward grapefruit. Taste is a variety of citrus fruits with a nice malt body and a bitterness that seems just right. Great example of an IPA.
Superbe IPA, fruitée, exotique, très amère pour 70IBU, résineuse, assez sèche. Goûtée au fût.

Fresh and clean on the back palate, tingly bitterness lingers on. Hell of an IPA, these guys know what theyre about and this beer nails it.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 Stone IPA... This is one of my faves! Poured from a bottle, light copper in color, thin head. Big citrus and astringent aroma, citrus and piney hops are there. Real bitter. Great beer.

DATE TASTED: October 2, 2013 ... GLASSWARE: Duvel tulip... OCCASION: the Browns on primetime TV--a chance at 3-2!...APPEARANCE: orange-peach hazy body supports a thick crunchy near-white head; beautiful display of bubbles with cirrus lacing... AROMA: as remembered, this IPA slams a pinecone of citrus orange peel up the nostrils, with a bit of apple too...PALATE: full-bodied, immersing the tongue in a bitter bath of effervescence; aggressively active in its aftertaste...TASTE: a crushing hops avalanche--alcohol is well hidden but warming--and enough malt to balance (?!) the mad mix-- a true feat...OVERALL: spending a summer discussing the best IPAs with a few colleagues made me want to review a few from the hallowed halls, and one of the first true west coast gems I indulged in was this label-less intimidator...Stone delivers the Cali attitude befitting its gargoyled mascot...
Beautiful beer. Frothy head good lacing. Citrus and grass. Almost balanced. Light fruity notes. Sticky mouth feel. Fair ipa, I wish it was fresher.
Aroma is citrusy, nice and hoppy. Flavor is citrusy and hop flavor does stick with you like its brother ruination but for a normal IPA it is nice.

WAY too malty - like a Fat Tire mixed with a lot of hops and a fair amount of paint thinner. I love a big hoppy IPA, but with Stone, the hop bitterness isnt floral or aromatic - its simply bitter and unpleasant. If I had purchased a six pack, Id have poured out five of them. If there is a worse IPA on the market, I dont want to know what it is. This is simply awful. On the plus side, the color was nice, and the label is cool.

Bottle brought back from Denver. Pours a clear orange colored beer with a creamy white head consisting out of very small bubbles. Aroma is light citrus, apples, grass and light fruits. Very fresh smelling. Flavour is light bitter, juicy and very fruity again. Long, medium bitter aftertaste and medium carbo. Very nice session IPA. Great stuff.

Nice floral aroma, with pine. Pours a deep golden color with light white head that lasts for days. The taste is very bitter not overly complex a little bit of sweetness on the end to balance it out. Another solid IPA from Stone. Had again recently. An all around nice IPA. A good bomber cheap quick IPA fix.

Aroma is light citrus tropical fruit aroma hopping. Appearance is crystal clear golden with small off white head. Taste is very well rounded. Grapefruit hop bitterness closely followed by a nice caramel honey malt. Mildly undesirable chalkiness. Palate medium full. Lingering grapefruit bitterness with a light sweet malt keeping it in balance. Overall a nice IPA. I expect more in the aroma for the style, but still enjoyable.

Bottle. Surprised its taken me this long to drink this. Pours clear light amber with frothy white head, good retention. Aroma is dominated by bright, clean citrus hops. Some resin and caramel follow, once the nose has recovered from the initial punch. Taste: assertive bitterness up front, carried along by moderate sweetness, giving way to a long, lingering bitter finish. The bitter finish starts off refreshing, but is at times overly harsh. Medium body, verging on full. Slick, almost sticky texture with lively carbonation. Overall: This is a remarkably solid IPA, though I expect nothing less from Stone. I appreciate that its available in 6-packs. Ive been thinking lately that its high time I think again about price point -- when one can buy 72 oz of a fine IPA like this for $10, one begins to reconsider how quick he is to spend $8-9 on a single bomber of other IPAs.

Poured a hazy light amber with a thin white head. The aroma is grassy with loads of fruit and a hint of caramel. The flavour is medium bitter with a grassy hop, nettle liqourice creamy palate. A classic IPA and one of the very best.

Hard to believe this is my very first time drinking Stone IPA. Fresh, earthy hop aroma supported by juicy/tropical hops. 

Fruity and citric hop profile initially; far less "West Coast" than I expected. Beautiful hop/malt balance. Despite disliking most Single IPAs, I can actually see myself buying this one.

Bottle pour that paired lovely with Chicken Andouille Sausage and Tater Tots (with ketchup). Strong sweet aroma of candied pine needles (yes, that pretentious) moving quickly to bitter hops in the mouth. Stone Cold Solid (or something like that).

Bottle. Pours golden clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is pine, grapefruit, citrus and fruit. Taste is the same aroma with grapefruit juice, citrus, bitter hops and pine. Medium bodied with good carbonation and balance. Prefer imperial IPAs but this is a good brew.
Bottle from AlesByMail.co.uk. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers, pine, fruits and malt. Very bitter and long bitter finish. Nice!

Pours an orangey gold amber colour, white foam head leaving alittle lacing and aroma of floral hoppy orange, grapefruit & pine. Taste is malt caramel with tropical fruits, grapefruit & resiny pine, hoppy spicey bitterness. Oily mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry lingering bitter finish. Well balanced
Bottle from walgreens, Las Vegas. Clear golden pour, white head. Aroma is fruity, citrus and some grapefruit. Flavor is bitter, loads of hops and very refreshing. Very well drinkable.

Pours a crystal clear, light golden color with what seems an eternal soapy-sudsy off-white head. Mown grass, pine, and green onion bouquet. Very wet and massively palate-wrecking mouthfeel. Extraordinarily hopped. Citrus dominates. Stone over aggressiveness.

660ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy, golden yellow with a one finger, frothy white head that thins to a thick film and leaves moderate lacing.Aroma is slightly bready with notes of pine and tropical fruit.Taste is a solid bitter with a drawn out, mild, slightly fruity, bitter after taste.Medium body with a medium to high carbonation. Bottle from Brewdog Bristol. Fat hoppy nose full of resinous pine and some rich candied orange peel. Pours a medium gold with a fluffy head. Intense flavour with early mango and papaya developing quickly into an unctuous, gritty, piney hopfest. Finish is long and dry. Excellent. Just excellent.

A medium bodied beer, it has a deep golden color and a small head. Its distinguishing characteristic is the overwhelming hoppy taste. Hops so overbalance the malt flavors, that the malt taste is nearly lost. This is a beer for people who love very strong, aromatic hops.

(bottle) pours a murky golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of mango, heavy resin and caramel, starchy pale malts, white grapes and straciatella yoghurt. flavour is mostly the same, heavy tropical fruit, resin and custard, with a slightly minerally medium-bitter finish. medium to heavy-bodied with lively carbonation.
Bottle, light orange body with a sudsy white head. Citrus hops in the aroma. Taste is citrus and grapefruit hops nicely balanced with malt and some bitterness.
Great aroma on this beer, good appearance, taste is awesome, hop aroma and bitterness are well pronounced. Bitterness lingers for a long time. Solid IPA.

1PL 6 Fl Oz. Bottle from a grocery shop in San Francisco during our visit in USA2013. Clear golden, light orange body with a large rough off-white head. Nose of exotic hops, some pine in it. Verry bitter, fruity hops. Not bad, but not my favorite ***

Ar: Pungent grapefruit rind, orange zest, and pine - a touch of rose and honey.
Ap: Light orange, clear - medium off-white head with moderate retention, a few colonies of suds and some lacing.
T: Bright orange and pine up front - a high bitterness, very pointed - a touch of sweet caramel flavor on the back end, mixes with zesty citrus - pine, lemon, and some tannic bitterness on the finish.
P: Medium body with high carbonation - finish is dry.
O: A classic west coast IPA - bitter, bright, and clean - delicious.

Hazy orange-tinted gold, white head, medium off-white head, nice lacing. Nose is peaches, malt, oranges, toffee, pine, lychee. Taste is fruity notes, biscuity malt, sweetness, oranges-peaches. Grapefruity-piney finish, dryness, sweet maltiness, bitterness. Lasting herbal-piney bitterness in the aftertaste. Medium body, smooth carbonation, oily palate. Nicely balanced, smooth. Very nice.

Nice citrus and hop aroma, decent colour and head. The flavour is bitterness, bitterness and more bitterness pretty much obscuring everything else. A classic of the seemingly trendy idea that ramming a tonne of hops in a beer makes you a good brewer. It doesnt and this is a poor beer, badly blended. The plethora of this type of beer is frankly getting really boring now.

Better than the average IPA but compared to most of Stone's other beers, I was hoping for a bit more here.

Good use of hops, a lot of citrus and sticking out. Dark golden color with a foamy white head. The taste is well balanced, and really enjoyable. Overall, a really nice single IPA.
Very cloudy orange w/ a lasting beady head. Strong hop presence but less than stone ruination. Nicely balanced yet potent hop flavors.

Piney, citrus aroma. Hazy gold appearance with a white head with excellent lacing. Avg head retention for an ipa. The flavor is full of piney hops with a bitter astringency on the end. A light sweet caramel flavor is present. It's a medium body beer with a bitter dry finish. Overall, it smells good but the taste ends with a astringent bitterness I don't care for. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Not a super tropical one, pronounced malt, hint of pub carpet, marrow, camembert. Bitterness, without pine at the end.

This IPA sets the standard. Pours a golden color with a perfect head. Strong hop presence but not overwhelming. Has a piney/earthy nose and a very smooth finish. If you havent tried this beer yet, you need to.

Bottle. Hops dominate. Floral and herbaceous. Just a hint of malt. Slightly too green. Clear golden with good white froth. Medium weight with high bitterness. Good flavour intensity but a little simple and green. Good hop flavoured American IPA.

Burnt yellow body, decent firm film of white head. Clean, plastic lemon and creamy Crystal malt and tensed hop. Big upfront zing, real white grapefruit and hopped tempo. Snapping early carbonation tunnels away, oilyish but carbonation holds firm even under a near 7%. Bitterness pushes things back for anything impressive on the finish, but is clean and simple to pin up the drinkability. Bottle, Beer Hive
Bottle. Orange gold with foamy, off-white head. Smells of pine, citrus, spice, and light malt. Flavor is citrus, malt, pine, spice with a moderate bitterness. Light bodied, medium carbonation.
pours a clear light amber color with a thin white head that persists around the edges. pine hops aroma. flavor is pine and grass, hop flavors are not overly strong but linger. medium carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2013 could be stronger Taste: citrus, grass, pine, some malt back bone, bitter Palate: average c02, light mouthfeel, some froth, bitter aftertaste Overall: a good bitter IPA, I was a bit let down by the lack of complexity, it does have a good mouth feel

Just about perfect California IPA. Great appearance, more than matched by the layered flavors and intense, varied hops. A great effort from one of my favorite breweries...

This I believe is the most balanced IPA Ive tasted. Its not a perfect combo but needs few touches here and there. Pineapples, moss-bitter, cherry-marmalade, carbonated water (briefly). This almost lets You forget about its faults, critisism and yet few are still found.
If this only wasnt so damn expensive...
Bottle pours golden color with a small white head. Nose is pine, hay, earthy. Taste is soooo smooth with a slight hop bitterness. This is what I would consider a perfect example of an IPA.

Pours a golden hue with very small head. Faint citrusy hop aroma. Grassy dank flavor with balanced hop bitterness that isn't overly bitter. Very good IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

If youre just starting out on IPAs, I would suggest Stone. Just the right amount of bitterness and hops. Almost textbook of what a great American IPA should be Nothing too over or under powering. Even more crisp on tap, enjoy!
Bottle. Copper in color with small head. Aroma of citrus fruits and hops. Flavor is fruity and hoppy with a sharp finish. Not one of my favorite IPAs, but definitely a good one.
Bottle at BBS San Diego tasting. Copper with a thin head. Aroma is grapefruit and pine. Flavour is fruity, long bitterness on a slightly sour base. Finish is sharp.

Appearance: very clear gold color, pours with a very thick and dense white head that retains very well and has average lacing

Aroma: all hops, grass, pine, citrus, could be stronger

Taste: citrus, grass, pine, some malt back bone, bitter

Palate: average c02, light mouthfeel, some froth, bitter aftertaste

Overall: a good bitter IPA, I was a bit let down by the lack of complexity, it does have a good mouth feel

A- filtered gold with 1 finger fluffy off-white head and incredible lacing. Poured into a pint glass at Roam burger, SF. 

S-grapefruit is nice up front, with your standard fresh pine, soap and hops to follow.

M- crisp and fresh with some stickiness. Medium bodied and good carb.

T- grapefruit and resin are strong in the beginning and last throughout. Pine and soap come in just after. Not complex but refreshing and enjoyable.
Bottle, rated from backlog. I will write a more extensive rating if I come across this brew again

Draft. Medium hoppy citrus and pine aroma. Cloudy orange color with substantial white head and persistent lacing. Medium bitter start and long bitter finish. Medium body and creamy texture.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours bright golden orange with a nice fluffy white head. Immediate aroma of mango, caramel and a bit of pine. Nice tropical fruit notes. Taste is very sweet, lots of sweet tropical fruits, caramel biscuit malts and a light resin on the way down. Solid bitterness, moderate body. Awesome drop, perhaps a touch too sweet for me.
Great aroma when first poured. The distinct taste of good hops comes out and begins to make your palate salivate. Taste is smooth with a nice bitter finish. Love this beer!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2016 Hopa at the forefront, in both aroma and taste. Piney aroma on top of hazy golden body with medium, creamy head. taste is astringent and bitter, and stays on the palate. Some lemony citrus notes are in the background. Excellent.

12 fl oz bottle from Trembling Madness shop, York. Pours an orangey gold amber colour, white foam head leaving alittle lacing and aroma of floral hoppy orange, grapefruit & pine. Taste is malt caramel with tropical fruits, grapefruit & resiny pine, hoppy spicey bitterness. Oily mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry lingering bitter finish. Well balanced, very drinkable IPA.
UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 Wow. I am not a IPA lover and did not expect to like this beer and I didnt . I loved it. Great hop taste but not over done. As far as IPA s go this tops the list for me!

On tap at Stone Gardens. Pours deep golden with an off white head. Aroma of pine, peach, make and some floral notes. Flavor is sweet and bitter with some peach, pine and malt. Medium body, average carbonation.

From a bottle in a chilled mug. Pours a pretty pale amber-orange. Decent head. Aroma is faint; citrus, and vaguely floral with hops. Taste is crisp, with a vaguely sweet, refreshing, citrus-flower quality at the front, followed by a brutally bitter finish. Wow, the aftertaste is absolutely brutal. Think dry-heave bile (weve all been there!) with cheap perfume and cardamon. Did I mention brutal? I wont buy it again.

Bottle into wine glass, clear, dark gold, old brass color. Small head which fades fast. Not the freshest of bottles, probably a few weeks old. Hoppy, light floral, citrus on the nose. Aroma is subdued. Tast is fairly bitter, faint citrus, hoppy, graham cracker taste, nothing stands out. Not a ton of carbonation. Need it fresher, still a solid ipa.
Tap poured at New Bohemia. Very crisp, clean IPA. Huge hop aroma followed up by a smooth citrus filled flavor. Nearly perfect balance and one of the best IPAs running.

This was my first IPA that truly had me hooked. It is a solid beer that is great in whatever method you drink it in or from. Nice golden/amber color with a big hoppy nose. Slightly sweet but it is all about the hops. Not all that boozy flavored that some IPAs can be but just hits the spot. In the end, it is a great beer for the style!

From Beerlicious iphone app: nice west coast ipa from an old schooler pale and cloudy minimal white head medium bitterness with a sticky slick feel

Golden, clear, with a thin white head, good lacing. Really nice hoppy, floral, orange and grapefruit aroma. Taste is sweet with a long, really bitter finish. Thin oily texture with light carbonation.

Via growler..solid amber orange hue..aroma of citrus..abundant grapefruit..mango..could of sworn I rated this before..oh well..medium body with the perfect abv and a good dose of the citrus..piney presence also..not too bitter..or sweet..very balanced with a wonderful finish..very tasty ipa that could pass for a dipa..excellent..
This is one of my favorites. It is hoppy, but I really like that. If someone doesnt like the taste of hops then he/she shouldnt get IPAs in my opinion.

When are RateBeers reviewers going to grow up and realize that excess hops do not make for a great beer? That unpleasant fad has come and gone.

To disabuse yourself of a hops fetish, just go to any brew-on-premises place and munch on a bit of hops (one pellet will do, if it is in the dried form). This is not moot nor rhetorical advice: Ive done it, and I guarantee it will help you get over hops. 

I bought this beer because it was rated 100 here, and I am *so* disappointed! 

This is lousy beer! Yes, it has tons of hops -- see above. 

But it has little body, little flavor (other than the excessive hops), very little yeast or malt flavors, a narrow aroma, an awful after-taste, and nothing special in appearance. 

Yuck! 😠

This beer is excellent. I am a bartender for Stone in the airport and I have a bias, but I cant help it. Stone is good for the craft beer community and I support them all the way. This beer is good and good for beer.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear golden amber color with a large foamy off white head. Aroma of grapefruit, pine, resin, and a bit of tropical fruitiness.
Taste is much the same. Nice crisp and refreshing. Definitely one of my go to IPA's.

22floz/650ml bottle into a tulip. Served cold.

Aroma: Nice, almost sweet hops. Citrus-y for sure.

Appearance: Translucent, bright orange body. Foamy white head. Very nice lacing.

Taste: Really nice hop flavor. Not really bitter like Ruination, but theres some bite.

Palate: Medium body, moderate-long bitter finish.

Overall: Nice beer! A classic for sure.

Pours gold with an off-white head which lingers. Hoppy aroma. Taste of grapefruit with a lingering bitterness.

Very hoppy and assertive. An excellent IPA. One of the premiere West Coast IPAs with a floral bitterness that lingers long after youve drained the glass.
Definitely a more than solid IPA. Stone has pulled off a good one. Great hops without being too bitter. Recommended

Cant believe Ive never rated this before... Stone being one of my favorite breweries. Also cant believe I couldnt rate it higher...

Pours a hazy amber straw with a head that dissipates to film. Aroma is fresh and simple: caramel, spruce, dough, and alcohol. Taste is bitter hops, along with the finish, rather one dimensional. A solid, base hit of an IPA. Would buy again.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy orange with white head that lingers. Mild-medium carbonation with nice hops aroma. Piney flavors up front with strong grapefruit resin and grass taste. Not super complex but a solid ipa.

In a bottle, citrus aroma, and a similar taste with some toffee notes, a top notch ipa!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2017 Draught at BBF13. Weak fruity aroma. Cloudy dark golden colour. Small stable white head. The flavour is nicely bitter, has a good tea note from the hops, like caramelly tea bonbons. Good hop bite. Well-balanced. 7 3 8 3 17

Can, 6.9%. Good grapefruit aroma. Almost clear golden colour. Small stable white head. The flavour is quite bitter but clean. Not as much aroma hoppiness in the flavour as in the aroma. 8 3 7 3 15

Wet gold straw color with a filmy head and mild carbonation. Strong citrus hops, orange and caramel notes in the nose.Flavor is sweet citrus hops, caramel, toffee, yeasts, resin, and malts. Aftertaste is a bittersweet resin taste. Body is fairly heavy in weight and the carbonation is moderate; More of a sipper. Overall a solid IPA.
Draught @ BBF13. Pours slightly hazy orange amber with small off-white head. Intense hoppy aroma and flavour wi notes of needles and citrus. Lingering bitter finish. Very nice.
Gyllen farve med lyst skum. Lukt av malt, honning og humle. Smak av malt, honning, sitrus og humle. Bittersøt avslutning. Melkebaren.
Frisk duft av citrus. Lite men sittende skum langs kant. Fin gyllen farge. God smak av citrus.

Bright golden yellow pour with receding head. Aromas of grapefruit, resin. Soft cereal malt backing. Hop story here. Bitter but not aggressive. Fragrant but not especially potent. Cleansing mouthfeel. Bitter finish. Very west coast.

Finally got around to trying this. Its rather expensive here on the East Coast, unlike Sierra Nevada or Lagunitas products, but I saw how highly rated it is and had to take a shot at it.

But honestly, Im disappointed. Seems thin-bodied, lacking malt balance and too lingeringly bitter for my tastes. Nice bottle, though.

Ive got to look into the byzantine mathematics involved in the rating process here. Ive rated this 6,4,5,4,10 in the 5 categories (A,A,T,P,O) which translates into a 2.9 rating by some process or other and then is transmogrified into part of the overall 99 (%?) rating at the top of the page. Wizardry!
This is also one of my favorite beers. Very good tasting beer. Also very high quality.

Bottle at home from brewdogenjoy by 21/7 so just out of date. Pours hazy honeyed golden blonde with fluffy offwhite head. Initially not much on the nose besides Seville orange. A full body, plenty of fruity lemon and tangerine, bitterness up front but not brash, with enough malt sweetness for balance.

Pour is a golden/light copper with white head and good lacing. Aroma is piney, citrus, light malts. Taste is very piney with good citrus presence and just enough malt. Low body and medium carbonation. Good ipa!

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange with a white head that settles slowly, thin lacing. Aroma is hoppy, resinous, bitter, and oily. Flavor is hoppy, moderately bitter, piney, with a very mild malt background. Bitter, very slightly soapy finish. Soft to moderate carbonation. Perfect well balanced IPA
Was great had this on tap at san francisco airport. Loads of pine and grapefruit aromas, nice body well balanced excellent IPA.

Best IPA Ive ever tasted. I spent a year trying to brew beer that could taste this go, but I couldnt quite nail it. I like a light ipa thats heavy on flavoring/aroma hops, thus giving it that lovely citrus flavor, and moderate to easy on bittering hops, which seems to fit the stone profile well. I also like a lighter IPA so that malts dont drown out that flavor, to which end the stone delivers yet again.

Wish this available in Alberta. A few gift bottles, second time trying stone ipa, first time from a bottle. For me, the most well balanced ipa, incredibly drinkable and pleasant. Smooth balanced citrus, pine and malt with a bit of a bite.

Bottle. Pours a dark golden/deep orange with off white small but fluffy head. Aromas of bitter grapefruit, some tropical fruits such a orange and a slight maltiness. Taste is all grapefruit straight in your face! Lovely bitterness to it as well. On the back end you get a touch more of tropical or citrus fruit. Solid malt backbone to it as well. Great ipa.

Bottle. 
Ar: pine, resin, grapefruit, caramel, hay, slightly metallic, bit earthy, toffee, alcohol. 
Ap: hazy amber colour, medium off-white head, good amount of lacing. 
T: big massive onslaught of bitterness, light/medium sweetness. Grapefruity, resinous, understated malts, hot on alcohol, bit short finish, but the bitterness lingers wonderfully. 
P: medium body, slightly oily feel, small lively bubbles. 
T: again Stone delivers.

Had the double dry hopped IPA only available in brewpubs (so I was told). Good aroma but not what I expected for the "double dry hopped" version I had. Thought itd have a stronger aroma. Same aroma as the regular Stone IPA it seemed, so double sounds like a gimmick. Taste was awesome like most of what Stone does, especially the IPAs. Didnt kill my tastebuds either. Was smooth to drink, good malt balance to the hops. Wasnt an overwhelming tastebud bitch slap. Solid beer.

A- big piney citrus nose. A- nice Carmel hue. Head doesnt hold well though for ipa. Lacing was ok. T-mild malts. Hops prevail but not the best Ive had for west coast considering the California competition. P- nice carbonation and sweetness to fight aggressive bitterness. O- was expecting a little more with the name Stone. Guess it makes you want to take the label off of a beer before you rate. Ive had better ipas from less known breweries. Still very good though. B+ in Californian standards.

Bottle. Clear amber with a good-sized off-white head. Aroma is bright citrus ,pine, with a very light cracker/bread malt background. Taste is medium-heavy bitter with a little sweetness. Finish is dry, bitter. Medium body, good carbonation. A little lacking in balance but theres nothing wrong with that. Excellent IPA, and one thats available all the time and just about everywhere.

Good beer. Your basic recipe for a good IPA Stone style. Perfect beer to have stocked in the fridge so you can have a good beer when doing yard work or some other manly project.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2014 Great aroma of hops, a lot of citrus and spruce. Nice dark golden appearance with a foamy white head. The taste is a lot of the nose with a bit of malt to balance out. Overall, really nice and one of the best single IPAs out there.

Well balanced. Hop aroma is very good. Not overly bitter. Lighter in color. Really enjoyed this.

Was at my sisters on 4th of July and grabbed it. Drank from a bottle, so I cant comment on the appearance, or even really the aroma for that part, but the taste was amazing. Flavor can best be described as bright, pleasantly bitter, citrusy with grapefruit and lemon. Well balanced.

Medium gold, hazy, white head. Aroma: very bright lemony citrus, grapefruit and tangerine, floral notes. Flavor is similar with grainy malt, a touch of caramel, a little biscuit, but dominated by bright citrusy hops. Very well done.

Amazing beer. My favorite of all time. No matter what I try I keep coming back for more. Wasn't in love at first, but it grew on me and continues to do so. Very floral and fruity with multiple layers of complexity. Perfect hop bitterness lingers just long enough. Just enough malt to balance the powerful hops. Perfect head which adheres to the glass to remind you it is disappearing by the sip. I buy it by the case whenever I can find it! I've tried many beers that are rated higher on this site, but none come close to the perfection of this beer for me. This beer has an unspeakable quality about it that is hard to describe but that I grow to appreciate more and more each year. I would buy the company if I could!

25 oz. bottle. Pours a golden amber color with a white head. Aroma of slightly citrus hops, almost like dry hopped. Medium body, great balance of malt and hops. Finish of slightly dry hops. Amazing beer. Well worth the try!

Golden amber pour with off-white fluffy head that leaves good lacing. Some pale malts with big hops aroma. Crisp carbonation, smooth mouthfeel and medium body. Caramel malt base with ample hops. Great drinking IPA.
Clear golden amber. Citrusy hop aroma. Citrus hop taste with mellow bitterness and a light malt accent. Excellent IPA.
Had it out of a bomber, poured a frothy head even lacing and a cloudy a,ber hue. Rock solid IPA, strong hop aroma and taste. Mmmm mmm good.

Not a huge fan of the style; but if I had to choose one, this would be in my top 5 (along with Lagunitas, Russian River, Victory, and Ninkasi). Pours nicely from 12 oz bottle with golden body, citrus aromas, and pillowy head. As advertised, the beer is aggressively hopped to deliver ample citrus notes and tangy a flavor profile. The genius is that Stones version is not overwhelmingly bitter as many unsophisticated IPAs tend to be.
Damn good! Outta control hops ! Big taste! Lasting lace. Just dry enough. I love IPA style and this is probably the best. Highly recommend. (Bottle to tulip)
Bottled. Pours golden with a huge white head. Smells and tastes sweet grassy hoppy, creamy and well balanced.
Pours a nice amber with a small head and lasting lace. Aroma is a heavy hop with a bit of citrus. Taste is very hoppy and finish is great. Very crisp. Wonderful.

Lovely amber pour with a big white head that fades into a ring of lacing. The aroma is robust with hops. The taste is of pure hops but leaves you with a refreshing finish. Quite nice and easy on the palate for such a potent brew. Definitely a must try for IPA lovers!
Bottle. Pours a lightly hazy gold with thick foamy head. Aroma of oranges and hops. Taste of bitter with a slight citrus that lasts.
Wonderful, really well balanced IPA. I forgot this one in the fridge for months so the hops werent as twisting as I think they could have been, still very enjoyable.

The aroma isnt quite there for me but the taste is perfect. Great balance that gives a punch but isnt over the top

Bottle. Orange amber beer with medium head and some lacing. Aroma of pine resin and grapefruit, wonderful IPA aroma. Taste is pine, grapefruit, citrus and exotic fruits. user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Smooth. Perfect hops. Amazing palate. By far a superior IPA. Color is amber with plenty of head
Has a pretty strong pleasant aroma. It has a pretty strong pine and citrusy blend of bitterness that is quite tasty. Very good, but not quite as good as ruination.
Citrus (grapefruit), herbal, spicy--with just enough light caramel sweetness to hold up the hops. Nice bitterness; stronger in aftertaste, but in a good way.

Pours clear,  amber/orange with a good size head of white foam that fell almost reasonably to a thick cap; leaving some monstrously stubborn lace. Nose is big with lemon, floral and herbal, citrus, lime and a nice soft spice under all the fruit. Not a lot of malt on the nose. Just a hint of bread and some caramel sweetness. As it warms the lemon sweetens deeply and so does the caramel. Taste is colossal. Fruit washes over the palate a bit too quickly and meets a heavy resin for a bitter that starts mid palate. Bread shows up in back with some light biscuit right before an oily pine blast. Finishes slick with a powerful bitter that lasts long into a finish that isnt really dry as much as pithy and sour. Body is thin and while the malt constantly approaches it never rounds out and so this leaves a touch imbalanced Moderate to low carbonation. 

This was a strong, beer that grows on you as you drink. I didnt find the same cocky personality in this that I have found in other Stone beers and I think I missed that. I also think that the fruit character suffered in the attempt to make it intensely bitter without provoking it sufficiently first. The malt came out more and more to show that it was indeed stronger than you might have  realized. The hop character engaged you more and more as well as the expansive bitter just kept unfolding and at the end of the bottle I was mysteriously satisfied.
22 oz. bottle. Probably the best widely available IPA out there. Complex flavors, very refreshing.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2013 There really isn?t anything else that can be said about this brew that hasn?t been said. Quite simply It is the best standard IPA out there.

Light amber pour with white head. Aroma is candied malt, ripe fruit. Flavour has malt sweetness with peaches, mango and honeydew. A nice piney bitterness cuts in mid palate. Bitter-sweet finish. Wonderful balance and flavour.
Pint at Tadg. Fantastic balance of fruit and pine, accentuated by the dry-hopping. The slight maltiness makes it incredibly drinkable.

Bottle in the Garibaldi econolodge, enjoyed out of a tiny plastic cup. Been so long since Ive had this, and still smells delicious in its hazy glory. Pine needles and caramel nose. Same in taste, but more malty with the pine coming up after. Pleasant dryness, and carbonation.

Seriously, one of the best IPAs i have ever had the pleasure of quaffing. Pours a beautiful orange/gold, honey and the fragrance of pine greets your nose by the time the bottle cap hits the counter. Velvety smooth, with medium carbonation. The taste of pine, citrus, a hint of sweet maltiness that gives way to a gentle heat on the finish. Utterly mind blowing.

Orange with no to little head; aroma of fresh grain and maltiness; Flava is of fresh barley; feels medium with little fizz; finishes dry and bitter; not much character;  I think the bartender screwed up

Stone IPA is a classic. It pours a light golden color with a white cap. Aroma of  hops and grapefruit. Flavor is in harmony with the scent. Awesome IPA!

A great IPA.  Good citrus notes and a hearty malt balance.  Smooth and tangy.
