Im Abgang findet man zudem leichte Zitrusnoten und einen erdigen Touch. Absolut harmonisches IPA 11/13/12/13/11/13
Pine and citrus on the nose..very crisp grapefruity lemon zest forward and a nice bitter finish that lingers for a second..i like this..this tasting was from a tap at the railhouse waverly ny
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2011 On tap.  A deep golden color with little head.  Strong hop flavor with a bitter aftertaste. Doesnt have the strong citrus flavors typical of other west coast IPAs

Stone IPA has a thick, off-white head and a hazy, golden appearance with some bubbles streaming up and a good amount of lacing rings left behind. The aroma is sweet, piney, sharp, and fruity. Taste is mostly hops, hops, hops, and there is some citrusy aspect and oiliness. Mouthfeel is medium, and Stone IPA finishes crisp, refreshing, mostly dry, and quite delicious. This is a very enjoyable ale, and I rate it highly.

RJT
22 oz bomber pours an orange/amber color with a nice white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, just smells great.  Medium bodies with an oily mouthfeel, delicious

This stuff is straight AMAZING! Fruity aroma, smells like 5:00 on a Friday after a long week. Smells citrus, fruit, tart. Looks like beer. Blah, Blah.

The flavor is citrus, buttery, goes down like gravy. Peppery bitter with a pleasant aftertaste. Full malty body that is truly staggering in complexity. Its like a fruity, hoppy, bitter milkshake. (does that even sound good?) Very Very good.
Beer like this one is turning me into an IPA loving gal.  No cat piss smell - tart and yummy!

This is one of the great Cali IPAs that defines the style.  It pours a slightly unclear yellow/gold with a small white head that clings all the way down.  Aroma is strong grapefruit, aroma hops, and a little booze.  The taste starts out with a slightly citrusy sweet grapefruit note and then bombs you with hops.  It bitter, strong, and dry on the finish.  A little booze sneaks in at the end as well.  When I cant find Pliny, this is what I grab.

22oz. bomber poured into pint glass.  Clear light golden color with creamy, fluffy and sticky white head that lasted forever!  An excellent presentation.  This is a hop beast with hop aroma all over and bitter taste to perfection with nice malt balance to the finish.  Big, smooth and creamy body.  This is IPA - WANT HOPS!

Nose is floral, slightly fruity, some pine notes as well.  Also bread and caramel aromas.  Pours a very slightly hazy golden color with a billowing white head, average retention and some lacing.  Flavor is bitter up front, fading into a nice malt backbone and plenty of citrus, pine, and a touch of sweetness.  Bitterness creeps back in and lingers for a while in the aftertaste.  Body is medium, carbonation is average.

Tap.  Cant believe Im now just rating this.  Anyway, lightl clearer orange with a head that retains really well and provides nice spidery lacing. Dank and grapefruit hops all around in the aroma, with some balance but no cutting sweetness. Fairly balanced, but still agressive with the hops in the flavor.  Medium body, dry, and softer carbonation.  Always great when fresh.

Nice hop aroma on the nose. Pours dark golden with a typical amount of white head from draft. Big citrus flavors on the tongue. Lingers nicely but not as long as I expected. The thing about Stones beers is the way the pinch you in the nose after hitting you over the head with a brick. Definitely not for everyone.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2011 660 ml bottle. Thanks tiong!
Pours a clear golden colour with a small lacy head. Aroma of strong grassy hops and sweet malts. Flavour of lovely bitter hops, caramel malts, grass and some floral notes. Medium bodied with a very bitter fruity finish. A top-notch IPA.
355 ml bottle.
Pours a deep golden colour with a highly lacy head. Lazy bubbles. Aroma of strong crispy hops, caramel and some grass. Flavour of caramel malts, crispy hops, some sweet fruits and again grass. Rich mouthfeel with a lovely crispy, caramel-like finish. One of the best IPAs out there. 9-4-9-4-16

22oz bottle poured into a tulip. Best by date is 5/5/11. Pours a cloudy yellow orange with two fingers of frothy foam and moderate carbonation. Nice lacing. Nose is lovely. Elegantly hoppy and bitter. Nice, playfully fresh hops with just a slight hint of malt. Mouthfeel is light and smooth. Lively carbonation. Palate is all hops dancing on the tongue. Not super resiny. Just resiny enough to give the finish a long and pleasing bitterness. The hop flavors are so light, they have a more floral quality than you find in most IPAs. This continues to be one of my favorite expressions of the style.

660ml bottle from Whole Foods Columbus Circle

Pours orange with a nice foamy head. Fruity and hoppy aroma. Excellent taste with hints of fruits and hops. Nice bitter and fruity palate. Extremely well balanced IPA.
good beer...flying saucer had their stone kick off party celebrating its arrival in missouri and i tried a few beers brewed by stone.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2011 Stone India Pale Ale: Drank out of a tumbler
Pour: The color comes out to be a pretty nice yellow/orange. The beer forms a massive head, somewhere around 4 fingers, that is pretty much white in color and lingers for awhile. It looks like there is a nice creamy top to the head with larger bubbles around the sides. 
Aroma: I absolutely love the aroma of this beer. Orange and citrus are the most prominent smells I get, along with some pine characteristics. The smell of hops really provides a backbone to the aroma but still the star is the citrus. The smell just leaves my mouth watering in anticipation. 
First Taste: You actually dont get as a much citrus taste in it as I would have expected from the aroma. You definitely still do get those nice citrus notes in the taste but what you really notice is the hops, which is indicative of an ipa. Its like the citrus has its time in the spot light for the preshow then the hops get to shine in the main event. Its definitely a great well balanced taste but really doesnt have the same punch behind it like I was expecting it to, which I sort of enjoy that fact.  If you are a real big hop head then you might think this beer needs a bit more of a wallop but I enjoy the nice balance. The finish is a little bread like with just a tiny bit of deep bitterness that doesnt last too long. I very refreshing and thirst quenching drink.
Overall I did enjoy this beer a lot and am now looking forward to its brother the ruination. A nice Ipa from the guys (and gals?) at the Stone brewing company.
12 oz. bottle. Doesnt pack the wallop of its Ruination brother, but it compensates by offering a bit more balance. The color is orange and the aroma is of course dominated by citrus. A great IPA.

Its become a standard for California IPAs. Aroma is hops, pine citrus. Appearance is gold clear with a nice white head. taste is hops. Where I feel like this falls flat is it lacks a nice smooth malt backdrop, it tastes a bit like hop tea. Palate is also a bit thin. Overall a good refreshing IPA but nowhere near the best.

Bottle.  Copper colored with an ever so small white head.  Lots of pine in the aroma with some grapefruit citrus coming through as well.  Taste is initially sweet and lightly fruity.  This gives way to a some grapefruit and a light bitterness that lingers to the finish.  The bitterness never overpowers, and is really quite a nice compliment to the sweetness.  I had this on tap earlier but was no where near as impressed with it.
Pours straw with a thin white head.  Piney and citrus hop flavor.  Nice bitterness at the end.  Bitterness end abruptly.

Bottle: medium gold pour with a thick white head.
Aroma is caramel, pine, citrus.
Flavor is medium sweetness with a nice balancing easy floral/citrusy bitterness. 
Very well balanced and super drinkable.
UPDATED: JUL 23, 2011 Bottle from Blackfriars. Amber colour with a good foamy head. Strong pine hop aroma and flavour. Dry aftertaste. Good but not the best IPA.
Nice hoppy aroma with a bit of malt to back it up, very hoppy taste, bitter hop finish, solid IPA.
This is unbelievably balanced. One of the best IPAs that have gone down my throat in recent years. Didnt think their ruination could top this one, how naive I am
In the thesaurus, you find Stone IPA as a synonym for "really solid beer." Honey sweetness, slight pine and grapefruit resin, strong bitterness.  Just a good, dry west coast IPA.

22 oz. Bottle. Pour is golden amber with a soapy white head that fades to a sticky film. Aroma is citrus lemon and pine. Taste is bitter spruce and little lemon zest and some faint malt notes. Palate is medium sticky feel that finishes fizzy and chaulky. Pretty solid IPA.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2011 The best affordable beer I have ever tried (the best being Stones Arrogant Bastard), I love this IPA so much. Its a shame I can only find it in one place by the six-pack in Cincinnati (Jungle Jims), but the search is part of the fun I suppose. The familiar dark orange color is always a welcome sight for me. The strong but balanced hop flavor satisfies me consistently, but isnt too hoppy or bitter that my non-IPA loving friends wont be able to finish it. Such a complex and wonderful flavor, the fruit tones are very appreciated once you try to notice them. Even the bottle is beautiful. I cant wait to buy another 6-pack of this beer.
UPDATED: JUL 5, 2015 Draft. Hazy gold-orange with lacing, puffy white head. Really nice balance of fruity and floral hops flavors with malt. Refreshing and smooth, an excellent beer.
this is my everyday, reliable, thirst quenching beer. great taste and beautify west coast floral nose. simply put, a beautify beer.

This beer pours a light gold semi clear with a big white and very good lacing.

Its aroma is very hoppy with light notes of honey and citrus.

The taste is overwhelmingly hoppy but I like it, still drinkable.  This is great.

This brew poured a very attractive orange color.  it was cloudy with a somewhat average sized white head.  Not a whole heap of retention and it left some lacing clinging to the sides of the glass.  A nice floral and perfumy aroma.  I smell the grapefruit and some orange.  Both citrusy and fruity.  Some piney notes along with some mild malt.  Smells very nice and balanced.  I started to get a dry bread smell as it warmed a bit.  A prominent amount of bitterness at first with the taste.  Medium to high hop flavor.  Grapefruit citrus is really nice and not over the top.  A touch piney.  Again, very well balanced and even.  A slight resinous flavor as the beer went down.  Medium mouthfeel.  Wonderful dry and snappy crisp.  Really blankets the palate and the taste hangs on for a great long while.  Nice!!!  Goes down way too easy.  Everytime I have a Stone beer Im impressed.  This brew is no different.  Very solid all the way around.  Perfect for the Spring and Summer days.  Most definitely worth a try.  Cheers.

Pretty much the gold standard for IPAs as far as I am concerned, aroma is awesome, taste is amazing, nice floral and citrus hops, perfect amount, refreshing, and light yet complex and flavorful at the same time.  Hops are awesome, great bitter flavor as well, I could drink this all the time.

Pours clowdy gokden nice off white head leaving lace. Aroma is piny, citric, hopoy, sweet. Fruity mouthfeel. Flavor is slightly yeasty and alcohol, citric, hoppy, sweet, very nice. Thin body.  Hoppy thin palate. Finishes fresh fruity and grear bitter hoppy.

12 oz bottle poured into pint glass.  Pours clear golden color with medium white head.  Aromas of pine and citrus.  Bitter hops present throughout.  Hoppy finish.  Not much malt for balance detected.  Im overall disappointed with this beer since I was expecting so much based on others Ive tried from Stone.

big aroma, not sure its pleasant.  lighter color than many IPAs, dark yellow.  lingering hop flavor is a plus.  I cant identify the hop flavor, not fruity, not spicey, not overly earthy.  hops might be a little piney to earthy, but not with a bad aftertaste.  malt is hard to identify, but it doesnt take over the beer.

Bottle. One of my all time favorite IPAs. Pours a beautiful tan color with thin head. Huge aroma of floral hops, lemon and jasmine. Taste is citrus but really well balanced and easy to drink. I could never get sick of it

The color is good.  Great lacing.  There was a keg of it for free, so I didnt really have time to decide how good it is, I just kept on drinking.  

There has to be  ample hop content and that gets done.

One outstanding IPA.

Pours bright, clear golden yellow-orange with thin white head and lacing. Nose is light, grassy and grapefruit. Light-to-medium bodied palate; medium hops, very crisp. Nice grapefruit flavor. Nice for summer.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2011 Floral nose and finish at first... aftertaste eventually mutes the balanced floral taste for me turning it almost "soapy". Medium, bitter aftertaste with long staying power.
 Draft, 12oz pint glass.

Pours a light orange with a small off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, with notes of grapefuit, hops, and caramel,  Flavor is nice, with piney hops, grapefruit, and a bit fruity in the finish.  Very well balanced and has a nice bitterness!

A very strong hop flavor to this beer, it was very bitter and stayed bitter through out the after taste and then some. But this one was a little more pleasant than the Ruination, but still would not seek it out.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 Complex hop flavors here, big bitterness at the end, that ramps up afterwards. Not balanced with malts though, decent

Bottle from Utobeer, London. Aroma hints of citrus, tropical fruits and caramel. It pours an exquisite golden, pale colour with a high white foam that leaves a lot of lacing, there is also some yeast in the bottom of the bottle. Taste is dry, crisp and bitter with some malty sweetness in there as well, perfectly balanced. The mouthfeel is intense, quite a lot of carbonation and it feels dry in your mouth like a nice champagne. This is a must try for anyone who loves a proper American IPA.

Bottle. Bright gold and orange colored in appearance with a solid inch of dense head. The aroma is a blend of resiny hops, pine and cannabis. The taste starts off strong on the sour grapefruit and citrus flavors along with a shot of floral hops, toasted malt and aggressive bitterness. The mouthfeel is slightly creamy with heavy carbonation and a bitter, citrusy finish. Like all of Stones beers, its wickedly bitter and deliciously hoppy. Definitely one of the premier West Coast style IPAs.

Surprised I hadnt rated this before. Beautiful gold beer, nice aroma. NW hops against a solid malt backbone. There was a time I thought this was heavy handed, but now seems perfectly measured. Aftertaste is mostly of hops.

12 oz bottle, enjoy by 05.03.10, I wish they had the bottled on date since it is an IPA.

Pours into my american pint glass with a nice gold color and a foamy and rocky white head that takes a bit to recede leaving gobs of lacing.

It has a decent smell though not overly intense. It is very citrusy and zesty with also some herbal grassiness. There isnt much malt to the scent of this beer.

It is smooth and hoppy with a good amount of biscuity malt backing and a nice bitter finish. Luscious but insanely drinkable. This is the quintessential quaffing IPA.

The mouthfeel is nice and medium bodied. This stuff is so easy to put back, it is like drinking water, far higher drinkability than a light beer especially when it is nice and warmed up.

Overall a great pick for American IPA if you want a superb quaffing beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-26-2010 02:27:58

On tap at Streets of London Pub in Sac. Aroma is very strongly hoped. Appearance is light, with a thin white head. Flavour is very bitter and hoppy. One of few IPAs that are. Mouth feel is medium full bodied with lively carbonation. Overall a very good IPA!
I really enjoyed this IPA, and would have to say it is now one of my favorites of the genre.  I know it is highly rated here, and I think that it is well worth the praise.
bottle; clear orange with small white head; aroma-citrus, fruits, strong hop smell; taste-wow...very light sweetness, citrus flavor, medium long-lasting bitterness. Very good IPA

Not much wrong about this one.  Pours hazy orange with stark white head, aroma has notes of big resinous pine, citrus, and a touch of caramel.  Taste is sweet citrus, bitter pine, some biscuit and caramel, and a nicely bitter finish. Solid, tasty IPA.

Like IPAs??  Then you will like this one. On tap @ The Press Room. Pours golden hue with a white, foamy, long lasting white head. Aroma is of citrusy hops and biscuit malt. Light-medium, tangy body. Citrusy hops dominate the flavor with a biscuit malt provide good balance. Finish is long lasting, dry and hoppy.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2011 12 oz bottle. Pours hazy dark orange, small head, with a bit of lacing. Aroma of citrus, fresh fruit, hops, grass. Taste is also citrusy and intensely hoppy. Aroma and flavor both very fresh. Finish is bitter (almost a bit too bitter for me), but expected for a beer with 70+ IBUs.

This is the beer that turned me on to IPAs. Love it.

Very solid IPA.  Pours a clear orange color with very wispy white head.  Hop aroma of citrus and pine is very apparent.  Taste is citrus and bitter hops with a great malt balance.  Lon, bitter finish, very classic taste.
Nice apricot flavor. Floral hop nose. Not your typical cascade dominated American IPA. Good stuff!

It pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head that fades to a thin ring. Some solid lacing present as well.

On the nose I am getting some pine notes and some citrus.

The flavor I am getting some light carmel,citrus,pine,floral. In addition to that I am getting a burning from some booze. Nothing that really stands out more than the other. But a nice drinkable beer.

It finishes with a huge lingering bitterness. You really have to like hops to like this one, but another great beer from Stone.

great great stuff, stone gets tons of press for the more outrageously named beers, but some times beauty is in simplicity.  This has a great hop nose, great palate and flavor profile...cirtus, pine, resin.  Its a great homage to hops, without being overpowering or unbalanced.  Very drinkable while being very bitter, great!

Beer has a hazy yellow color with a small head in the glass. Aroma has the strong hoppiness from the glass that you would expect. Taste continues with the hops but it also has some citrus to go along with it. Long bitter finish.

Bottle. Nice orange slightly hazy. Very foamy white head. Aromas of hops. Citrus and pine. Some sweetness and a malt presence and some hoppy spiciness. Taste is full of hop goodness. Long dry bitter finish. Near perfect balance. One of the best I have ever had.
pale, cloudy, hazy, medium bitterness, thick feel, average carbonation, bitter, full body,

You might ask yourself, does Stone make a bad beer? The answer is no. Stones IPA is top of its class as a hop forward beer only suprassed by other Stone beers. Well balanced hop profile, evocative of pines and slight ctirus with malty body to please your palate.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2015 12 oz bottle.  Pours golden hue with a white, foamy, long lasting white head.  Aroma is of citrusy, grassy, herbal hops, biscuit malt and ripe fruit. Medium, tangy body.  Citrusy, herbal hops dominate the flavor with a biscuit malt and tropical fruit provide good balance.  Finish is long lasting, dry and hoppy. Great IPA

AMAZING IPA!!! The pour is bright orange with a finger and a half of bright yellowish white head. Aroma is super hoppy with a huge grapefruit and sweet orange taste. The taste is hugely hoppy with a hop bomb throughout. Mild caramel maltiness and sweet candy toffee. Floral fruity hops make this beer unforgetable.

The aroma consist of caramel malt and orange zest. Golden copper in color with a bubbly white head. It has good lacing. Combination of sweet and bitter flavors. Starts with an orange flavor and ends in a hoppy flavor. Drinkably smooth. Once again stone brewery lives up to its expectations.

I have heard many a great thing about this beer. I will say I was not disappointed. Sampled from a six pack of 12 oz. bottles. Pours a surprisingly straw yellow color. Just a bit cloudy. Average head with decent retention and good lacing. Floral, hoppy aroma.
On tap @ The Rake, London. Pours golden with moderate head. Lots of citric hops and a balanced sweetness from the malts. Very drinkable and refreshing. Better on tap than on bottle.

Bottle- Pours a copper color with a billowing head and good lacing. Aroma is primarily pineney with citrus and a trace of sweetness. Initially has a mild malt sweetness then moves to a nice tangy bitterness with a fairly dry finish. Fairly medium body, crisp and refreshing. Well Balanced.
 Very solid IPA.

Stone IPA poured a hazy gold from the bottle with a decent white head.  The hops come through nicely in this beer and I noted scents of pine.  There is a balanced bitterness in this beer and as I got further along in my drink I started to pick up notes of butter.  This IPA finised smooth with a nice mouthfeel.

Pours an amber color with a thick white head.  Aroma is of floral notes.  Heavy bitter hop flavor like one would expect from a good IPA.  Lively and medium bodied with a slick texture and long bitter finish.  One of my favorites.

This is a classic San Diego IPA. It is crisp and refreshing and has a very good hop profile.great for everyday drinking without draining your bank account.

It pours a light golden color with a 1 finger head with decent lacing. Smells are all hops with a little malt.

Taste is bitter and hoppy with a little malt flavor just as youd expect.

It has a clean and dry mouth feel at the same time.

Overall, like I said it isnt going to make you drool for more but it is a great goto especially at bars that have bud, coors, miller, bluemoon, and stone ipa. Cant go wrong with it in that situation...

Mat yellow colour, slightly hazy with medium head. Smell of pine, grass and some malts. Taste is nicely bitter, pungent but not overdone, citrus, pine, grass with a hint of sweetness and a malty aftertaste of bread. Palate is dry. I really like this.
resin, hazy, golden, minimal head, medium bitterness, slick feel, medium body, lively, bitter, long finish,
On tap at the American Ale House. Gold with a quarter inch cream/white head. Aroma is pine. Flavor is dry--pine with some grassiness. Very nice IPA.

Light golden beer with a white, frothy, one finger head.  Excellent sticking on the lace.  

Aroma is all hops.  Mostly pine hops with fruit notes and a pungent edge.  Bitter overpowers sweet.

Taste has a bite.  Nice bitter hops.  Pine and grassy mainly.  Slight hint of pineapple.  Little bit of butter/toast malt to back up the hops.  

Leaves a bitter, dry, hoppy aftertaste.  This is a good smacky, sticky ipa.  

When I imagine a standard ipa, this is what I think of.  It isnt a tropical fruity, sweet ipa, and it isnt a high hop, high malt backbone ipa.  Nothing overpowers and its hop dominated.  Bitter and crisp.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Bottle @ Old Chicago. Mildly hazy, slightly burnt orange appearance with a frothy off white head. Fairly piney hoppy nose with a bit of citrus and light malts. Piney hops hit mildly in the start and make a much more definite and bitter impression on the finish. Some notes of citrus in the flavor that is a touch darker in malts than many other IPAs. Bitter piney hoppy flavor lingers on the back of the tongue.

Poured into a glass from a 12oz bottle. Appearance is translucent copper with a thick foamy white head. Aroma is sweet citrus, hops, and some bready notes. Taste is hops up front with sweet citrus coming through and fading to a biscuit like breadiness that fades again to hops. Overall I am surprised by the sweetness of the beer. Very enjoyable IPA.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2012 Bottle. Pours a dazzling amber colour with a thick white head, gradually recedes to a smooth layer of bubbles. Aroma of citrus, pine. Lots and lots of sharp hops, good carbonation but somehow balanced out with a big sweetness, and by the smoothness of the beer. Some grapefruit. Lingering aftertaste with very, very subtle buttery notes. Great IPA.

Pours a cloudy yellow/gold, head is white and not as plentiful as I would have expected. Whatever head was there disappeared quickly. Smells hoppy and has deep floral notes, with a bit of honey mixed in. Simple, yet pleasing aroma. Taste is similar, as it doesnt counter the bitterness of the hops with much of anything, but is not too bitter (in my opinion) as to be unpleasant. Leaves a nice sticky bitter coating in mouth and is very crisp from start to finish. Alcohol is not noticeable at all, and each gulp does down easy. Simple, well done IPA.

355mL bottle.  Pours bright hazy gold with a small white head that settles to a lingering thin covering.  Hop driven aroma, citrusy, floral and woody with a bit of cannabis and some honey and caramel in the background, although theres something else very subtle there that smells off, and possibly also some diacetyl.  Mild sweetness, medium bitterness, the malt and hop flavours are well integrated.  Light-medium bodied, very drinkable, smooth and creamy with a drying bittersweet finish.

Poured into a pint glass.

4.0 A: Vibrant orange in color. A little hazy, as if it were bottle-conditioned, but I dont think it is. Not a lot of head, even with a semi-aggressive pour. Decent amount of lacing considering the lack of head.

5.0 S: My my my, this is screaming deliciousness at me. Big citrus hop aroma followed by spice and fruity esters. Sweetness and bitterness marry as if you hybridized an orange with a grapefruit.

4.5 T: A lot of hop flavor, maybe even more than hop bitterness. Im loving it. Grassy, citrusy, woody hops make up this flavor. Theres a sweet and sour fruitiness and a biscuity character from the malts. Very good hop/malt balance.

4.5 M: Medium body, creamy as all hell. Very nicely done.

5.0 D: This is the kind of beer I want to drink when I hit up a bar. The beer is the centerpiece, not the people there. Big, bold flavor keeps me coming back for more.

Ive never enjoyed an IPA so much that didnt qualify as a double/imperial.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-09-2008 00:04:31

Pour is a golden yellow with a large white head with good retention. Nose is of hops with some floral notes and pine needles. Taste is rather hoppy while staying smooth throughout. Beer is quite refreshing and very lively carbonated.
A good IPA, very simple, might not be 100 percentile good in my opinion.  Lacked malt backbone, very good light colored hoppy brew.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours amber golden with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma strong of citrus and pine hops.  Flavor also strong of hops, with lots of fresh citrus undertones.  Smooth texture.  A great IPA.

-hoppy but not too hoppy or sweet

-smells of pine, citrus, and grass

-dry and exquisitely balanced

-One of my favorite beers ever

-

Dark honey color. Not too much head but there was some lacing. Some piney, and floral hops in the nose. Tastes have some tart citrus and piney flavor. Also some sweet bready malt. Light to medium body and fairly dry. Nice IPA.

Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow with a long-lasting white head.  Smell is sharp...orange zest, lemon, maybe some lime.  Taste is similar, but the bite fades away the longer you let it sit.  Good hoppiness though, almost a flowery feel as it warms.  Ive had this one before, but apparently never rated it.

Durhambeer sent me this bomber, thanks Bob! Seems like every time I have the opportunity to drink this its in some sort of social setting, then I can never find it in bottles when Im beer shopping out of state. Im happy to have a bomber to myself finally! 
The beer pours a nice hazy yellow with a large to medium sized head and quite a good deal of lace.  The aroma is fruity with some orange zest, light cooking spice, the aroma is quite nice but doesnt pack the pungency of many IPAs of this flavor caliber
The flavor is grapefruit and melon... this sits pretty nicely with me as these are decidedly my two favorite flavors in the repertoire of new world hops. The beer is bitter in that way that keeps you wanting to drink more of it. It might just be that I really like this kind of bitterness, but it almost seems like more of a sensation after a while than a flavor. This delivers the balance between dryness and fruity hops as well as two hearted, in a way the two almost seem akin in their character.  There is little doubt I would drink a lot of this if it were more available to me.

A big solid beer, hoppy and straight forward. The aroma is obviously impressively bitter, with grapefruit hoppiness, and some sweet malt aroma giving a semblance of balance. Caramel malt and grapefruit bitter flavour, leaning heavily on the bitter side, some raisin is evident. Nice full body. Overall... big, beautiful and bitter.

Pours amber/orange with a large lasting head.
Nose shows lots of grapefruit, resin, pine and grassy hops. Pretty delightful. Underneath is sweet clean malt, and lots of it.
Flavours are quite different, instead focussing of some interesting toasty malt that mixes in with the grapefuit and resinous hops. Finishes with a powerful, spicy, hoppy bitterness.
Great moderate carbonation, nice slightly slick mouthfeel.
Tap at RnH for Stone tap takeover: Double Dry hopped version - sweet caramel, really hoppy fresh grassy, really tasty.

Pour: light orange with a white head. body looks a bit thin

Smell: loads of hops, some citrus (maybe lemon?) grassy and floral

Taste: slightly agressive hop flavor up front with some citrus notes. floral grassy notes with a slightly spicy and skunky finish. 

One of the better IPA iv had. i still like the ruination version better but overall not bad.

355ml bottle in a tasting between Dogfish Head and Stone IPAs. Big head on a rusted honey pour. Tangerine and chalk on the nose. With big forward tangerine on the palate. Overall disappointing and over-hyped.

This is everything an IPA should be.  The hops burst out when you first take a whiff.  You can taste the hops very distinctly, providing a great floral character and a great deal of bitterness.  Goes down crisp, medium to heavy mouthfeel, fairly bitter for a single IPA.  One of the best single IPAs Ive had.

1" pure white thick head that lasts for ever with very thick lacing, that lasted at the top of the glass when the glass was empty. Crystal clear golden-ornage color.  Citrus, particularily orange, and pine aroma. Lots of hop flavor with a good malt backbone. Medium-light mouthfeel with good carbonation, nice bitter bite on the back and outside of my tongue.  I like this beer a lot though its not my favorite IPA.

Bottle from Discount Milwaukee (in the discount area - final couple of bottles as Stone leaves WI).  Pours a hazy yellow-orange with a 1/2 inch head.  Aroma is grapefruit and pine.  Flavor is more grapefruit, very smooth bitter grapefruit, with a long bitter finish.  It is no longer "perhaps the best beer Ive ever had" however it is a wonderfully tasty, hoppy and smooth ipa - certainly a top 10 ipa.
Excellent, excellent IPA.  medium bitterness, medium sweetness, lively, bitter, full body, resin, spruce, golden, hazy, sparkling, white foam, frothy,

Wow. If you like hops and thats all you like, than this is the beer for you. Its a very nice golden color with heavy white head that lasts. The aroma and taste is nothing but hops and pine. Very true to the cascade hops, however, it lacks on the complexity of the taste. While I love hops, there still needs to be some undertones of citrus which Im not getting at all. Not overwhelmingly bitter, but what you could expect at 70 BIUs. Overall, a very good cascade hops IPA and definitely worth trying.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver, Co. Pours clear golden with a big white head. Aroma of Citruss, light grapefruit, floral hops. Taste is huge hops, pine, grapefruit, grassy and floral tones, very refreshing. Medium body, soft carbonation, nice slick mouthfeel, bitter finish. Overall very good IPA, high drinkability.031210

drank in comparisson to the 60 minute IPA and Squall 90 minute IPA and Stone Ruination and Stone IPA. its cloudy, super frothy and more orange than the others. wow, can you say pine cones, booze and fruity hops? I say there is little malts in this one, big leafy pine cones on the mouth, I find it has a sort of wet rock or chalky note on the palate as well. it is super hoppy but I find it is lacking in complexity, there are no malts big fruity hops with good carbonation. A wonderful brew but can i say it is actually kinda almost just too much hops and not much else?
Great beer citrus flavors in the hops, not overpowering with the hops, but most definately prevalent, just a good all around IPA

Pours a dark gold with a nice, fluffy white head. Nose is of citrus and floral hops. Taste is quite bitter along with citrus and floral notes blending together quite well, with the floral notes taking the lead--very nice in the sense that its different from many of the better IPAs, which are typically loaded solely with citrus. Great carbonation and excellent drinkability.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 01-20-2010

sam bottle as pictures. aroma of hops and citrus. poured cloudy yellow with decent head.  when you take a sip the hops hit you. so so good. my only complaint is the finish could be little more bitter. if you can find this beer buy it, its well worth it.

Wow what a gem. A great example of an American brewery using cascade hops (which are frowned upon by some Europeans) to produce a magnificent IPA. This is cascade hop juice. Poured from a 24 oz. bottle, dark golden and slightly hazy. Big citrus and pine aromas. Medium head, dissipates quickly, but reeks and tastes of hops. Nice full chewy mouth feel, very bitter and dry on the finish, also some spicy and floral notes, but thats why we buy a 70 IBU beer.

Stone IPA is one of, well, it is my favorite beer. I can drink a Stone IPA and completely change my mood. Stone is probably the best example of an American IPA available. Ive made IPAs a focus of my beer drinking and sampling and I can say without hyperbole, this is a great beer. Of course it is better on draught than in the bottle, but I had a 12 oz bottle of it served in my Stone IPA glass. Medium head, strong aroma of cascade hops, dark yellow, clear (although sometimes the bottles are cloudy). Excellent mouthfeel, a great amount of hops but the bitterness is not overpowering.

Serving type: bottle

12 fl. oz bottle at a beer taste, Nuremberg, Brau-Beviale.
Amber colored with a coppery-reddish tones, small lacing off white head. Nuts and toasted caramel in the nose withcitrusses, grapefruit, riped cheese, spicies. Medium but oily body with a floral-herbal, citrussy and resiny bitterness. Sweetish honey and some vanilla in the background. Correct IPA.
An amazing IPA. Huge aroma. Can smell in a foot away. Creamy and sticky mouthful. Crisp and bitter. Citrus and sweet. Awesome!! so happy I have one more in the cellar.
Stone makes plenty of beers that will let you know what hops tastes like and this is certainly one of them.

How many thousand reviews? you know what it looks like. For me i knew straight away upon opening with those powerful drifting hop and malt aromas this was good, my style, and it is. Love it. Try it youll know. Hop heaven.

Very good IPA. Light poor with small frothy head. Very crisp taste of toasted hops. Best if slowly consumed so thegreat taste of hops can satisfy your palate.Highly ranked IPA for all beer lovers, but espically the IPA enthausist.

Bomber pours orange/copper with a large khaki head. Aroma is citrus, pine, floral, malt, and caramel. Taste is similar to aroma and is excellently well balanced with a nice earthy bitter finish. There is a generous but not overpowering hop presence that mixes well with sweet flavors. Very refreshing and drinkable, a great IPA.
Aroma is caramel, grapefruit and general citrus. Well balanced sweet and bitter flavors. Wish I had paid more attention, but knew it was a fantastic IPA at the first sip.

IPAs are not my favorites - normally, but I got this by mistake and really enjoyed it.  Certainly it has the requisite amount of hops and then some but I fine it to be particularly well balanced. The bitterness is down from what one might expect and the overall taste is really very good

Pours golden-orange with a frothy, ivory head that lasts. Sticky lace. Nose of tangerine and pine. Taste of sweet citrus up front with grass, resin, caramel and bread on the finish. This is a solid gateway brew to the hoppy side. Medium bitter finish that lasts, and lasts.

Hazy golden color pour with nice head. Fruit hop aroma consisting of hop, malt, oranges, and grapefruit. Quite dry texture, thin body, the malt improves later in the drink as it gets bolder.  Initially sweet finishing very bitter.  Great for those not looking for a simple drink.

(Courtoisie de Viper666)  Le liquide dévoile une robe jaune orangée.  La mousse blanche est dense et épaisse avec une très bonne rétention.  De gros morceaux restent collés au verre.  Au nez, les arômes de houblons américains sont intenses et complexes : les agrumes sont juteux et saccompagnent de fruits tropicaux.  Les effluves de résine sont collants, permettant aux parfums floraux de chatouiller subtilement les narines.  On entend aussi le chuchotement du malt, tout juste ce quil faut pour se faire entendre.  Au goût, les saveurs des houblons sont tranchantes : les fruits et la résine explosent pour donner une amertume puissante.  Le support des grains maltés est minimal : son côté sucré atténue quand même le choc des notes amères.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une bonne effervescence et une texture légèrement huileuse.  En finale, la langue est saturée de saveurs de houblons et de notes amères intenses et très étirées.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2014 Hazy and surprisingly large amont of foam for an IPA like this. Easy to smell the floral hops. Aroma is completed with toast, lime, yeast and more hops. It?s clear why this beer was brewed: hoppy bitterness. It isn?t even too overwhelming though in the mouth, but room for sugars. Aftertaste again is dry and sharp. I enjoyed this IPA but it is no easy drink. A bit too much, really. (On my FL trip.)

Had another pint of this yesterday in Rattle n Hum New Year and boy did my palate change over the two years since I first rated this. My score is a bit higher, but its my perception of bitterness thats so different now. I find this quite rounded in fact, however good hop mix this might have. Very solid brew, Rightfully a classic!

First off this is an excellent brew to start someone on the path down real beer.

The aroma is the first thing you notice, very full and gets you excited about your first drink.

Looks good in the glass, I prefer a glass mug out of the freezer, has a good head without too much foam.

For having a strong (and I mean that in the best way possible) aroma, the taste is not to bitter which makes it accessible to most people who appreciate good beer.

It finishes very well leaving you wanting more.  You still taste it afterwards, but in a good way.

Overall, this is one of the best brews out there hands down.  It is a good starter beer for anyone wanting to explore what real beer can be.
UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 Several month old bottle. Would like to try something fresher. I can tell it was good though.

Well time to review this monster, I do mean monster. Because like with all the stone products they tend to be a tad heavy handed with there hops. With a IPA that can be a good thing.

The bottle poured into a Stone IMP pint glass produced the most perfect looking IPA you can imagine.
It looks like the advertisement photos you see. A nice golden orange with a beautiful pillow of a white head on top. As you consume the brew the lace just follows the beer down the glass.

The aromas are hop forward. Again there is no surprise, its the typical pine almost floral bouquet. I would expect from an IPA. Only hoped to the max.. (LOL) This is a typical west cost IPA. If you want to experience one out here in the east this is the one I would point you too. The flavor is bitter grapefruit with almost no malt profile in it at all. Balance would not be a word I use in describing this one. The feel is a soiled medium to me with a good amount of carbonation in it helping to cleanse the pallet.

This is a great IPA drinkability is perfect. This beer is one everyone needs to try at least once. I myself tend to return to this one quite often.

Tasted on draft at Old Oak Tap. Pours clear golden with a thick but smooth white head that leaves a smooth lace blanket. The nose is resin and citrus hops with a solid baked bread malt aroma. The flavor starts with cereal malt up front, and then the pine and resin hops dominate the rest of the palate with bitterness. The body is medium with average carbonation and a super long bitter finish.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2012 Very hoppy aroma. A very hop directed, yet balanced flavor -- this is one IPA that takes all aspects of the style into consideration. There is the bitterness, the floral notes, the crisp finish, and the malt underpinnings that come together in an extremely choreographed manner. If you have been unnerved by IPAs in the past that leaned to heavily towards the bitterness, the floral aspects, the alcohol content, or were too dry or sweet give this a try and experience an IPA in harmony.

Bottle. Clear golden/orange with a thick foamy off-white head with very good retention and nice lacing. Aroma is citrus, piney hops, caramel, sweet malt, alcohol and pineapple. Flavor is bitter with citrus, pine, sweet malt, caramel, alcohol and an intense bitter finish. Medium to full body with an oily mouthfeel. Very good IPA.

Pours a golden-orange with a nice frothy head that lingers and laces the glass well. Huge hops aroma. citrus and pine. The taste has a pretty strong hop bitterness. Some grapefruity-citrus flavors that give it a balance of sweetness. Full mouthfeel and long finish where some of the alcohol comes through but this is a very smooth brew.

[355ml bottle, Beers of Europe, Kings Lynn] Quite pale for a strong American IPA  more the colour of a British golden ale. Long-lasting half-inch head, quite highly carbonated. Wonderful piney citrus hop aroma  really something on the nose. Perfectly balanced flavour  not much alcohol at first, the hops start off  then the alcohol recovers and comes at you. But it stops before it gets to Ruination standards; its more refreshing than punishing. A really, really great beer  balanced and moreish. It does get quite a lot towards the end of the bottle, but by then it doesnt seem to matter. Never overpowering, always flavourful, brilliantly crafted. If the 100/100 score doesnt do it for you  let me sum it up. This is one of the best beers in the world [06082009]

22oz bomber poured into a pint glass.  The aromas are very citrus and pine, but very, very nice.  Appearance is golden yellow, with a white head.  The taste is phenomenal with straightforward hop bitterness in your face.  Very crisp and clean.  Very nice tasty brew.  Overall, one of my faves.

Hazy amber body, with a nice creamy beige head. Good head retention and some lacing. No visible carbonation to speak of.

The aroma is full of the West Coast-style citrus hoppiness. Juicy grapefruit, oranges, and some floral notes. Also hints of caramel, apple, and sour dough. Pretty hop-forward but not one-dimensional.

As far as taste goes, first you get a good hop bite, with very apparent grapefruit notes and a hint of orange. Then sweetness, breadiness, and bitterness come in all at once. The finish is bitter and bready, with a little tartness. Very tasty!

Light-to-medium body to it. Not very carbonated. Quite dry in the mouth, though. A little spiciness from the hops can be felt on the tongue. A little hint of alcohol.

Pretty good drinkability, however, I wouldnt make this my session IPA, because of its dryness and its ABV. Goes down smooth at first, but then it may become more challenging to drink, especially if youre not a hophead.

Overall, I agree that this is one of the finer examples of the style. A true classic American IPA!

Pale golden and full of hops. Aroma is overpowering and smells like youve got a whole leaf. Striking bitterness from beginning to end. Citrus slightly, mostly pine. Dry hopping very apparent.  A beast.

Hazy golden pour with a thin white head. Overwhelming hop aroma, mainly pine and citrus hops. Lots of lemon and some grass. Flavor is exceedingly bitter. Pine and resin hops are dominant. Not much malt flavor to back up the hoppy slap in the face. Make no mistake, this is not a particularly balanced beer, and I dont think the fine folks at Stone ever intended it to be.  Palate is very nice though, well carbonated with a nice body that manages to be light without getting watery. If youre into the bitter hop stuff this is a great choice, I just happen to prefer a stronger malt presence in my IPAs.
Always a favorite. Beautiful, floral aromas, light body, average carbonation, astringent, golden color.

Clear, yellow, really nice head.  Tons of "green" hop aroma - mostly pine.  A good, strong, hop taste - very bitter and very pleasing.  Some good malt behind it, but difficult to tell much more behind all the bitterness.

Draught on Miami Beach. Orange yellow, big white head sticking to the sides of the glass. Strong flowery aroma, nicely balanced. Taste a bit weak, not as balanced. Finish is just bitterness, no flowery notes left.
Bottle. Pours a clear orange colour  with a good white head. The aroma is full of  hops with more than a hint of citrus. The taste is all citrus and pine.
Pour is a bright orange with a huge white head.  Aroma is of course fresh hops.  Flavor is again lots of fresh tasty hops.  After 2000+ ratings not much else to say.  A superb IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2010 Pours orange with a white head. The aroma is very prominent but not overwhelming. The taste is not sour nor is it really sweet and definitely has a bitter taste. Stone IPA has a medium body with a nice texture and a fair amount of carbonation and certainly finishes nice but bitter. Overall, its quite a great drink.
Draft, had the DDH version at Alewife. Pours golden with a white head. Big pine/citrus hops but smooth. Definitely a top 10, if not top 5 IPA.
Pours golden in color with dense white head. Aroma is pineapple, hoppy, pine. Taste is crisp, bitter, hoppy and clean. remarkably smooth and very tasty and drinkable. Good beer.

Bouteille 12 Oz. De couleur dorée-orange et claire. Nez de houblon citrique (pamplemousse), légèrement résineux et aux notes herbeuses, de malt légèrement caramélisé, moyen de fruits (agrumes, traces dabricots) et léger de biscuits. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture légèrement crémeuse et aux notes résineuses. Goût moyen-amer de houblon citrique (pamplemousse, une amertume présente toute la gorgée) accompagné dun goût fruité (agrumes, petites notes d"abricots) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de caramel doux, moyen de biscuits avec des traces de pain puis en finale lamertume asséchante de houblon revient en force en étant légèrement herbeuse (herbes fraîches et herbes mouillées) et aux notes résineuses. Post-goût moyen-long et aux notes sèches, amer de houblon citrique, légèrement herbeux et aux notes résineuses avec des notes fruitées (zest dagrumes).

12oz bottle. Mmmm hops ... yep, this is a tasty one. West Coast IPAs are my favorite and this is one of the best in this style so we are talking some good stuff here. Hazy golden pour with a decent white head that sticks around to the finish. Hops, pine, more hops, delicious.

This is the beer that is my standard for all IPAs I try. Its just oh so good. Hoppy aroma, hoppy bitter flavor, and hoppy bitter aftertaste. What could be better? Crisp and refreshing anytime of year. I wish I was closer to San Diego to get some on tap

Bottle. Ah yes yet another fantastic west coast IPA. Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a big frothy white head, that sticks around. Aroma is of grapefruit, orange, citrus and a good amount of both caramel, sweet and biscuity malts. Flavor is quite bitter, but yet very well balanced between malts and hops. I get grapefruit, orange peel, floral notes, some citrus, tangerine, caramel and biscuity malts, along with a pretty nice amount of sweet malts. The body is medium and has a quite dry mouthfeel. Overall a really good IPA, i really hope Stone decides to open a brewery in the UK, then i might be able to get this beer more often!

Golden honey in color with a very thick, soapy looking inviting head.  Clean pine/mint hoppy aroma.  Good bitter hops flavor up front with toffee malt notes following in the aftertaste.  Overall, its good
An all around great IPA. A good casual brew. could drink it everyday for the rest of my life.
Delightfully strong hoppy scent, has the trademark hop and fruit taste of a well done IPA with a massive kick of bitterness, Stone produces another winner.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2010 Bottle: Pours golden/light amber with medium size, long lasting white head with decent lacing. Aroma of piney grapefruity hoppy goodness. Medium body, well balanced bitterness. Very drinkable.
Gold in body with good size, lasting white head. Hops are bold and standout in both aroma and the taste, medium body, exceptionally drinkable.

All around great beer. I will definitely drink this again. I am surpised to hear they have a better IPA, I cannot wait to try that. Basically perfect balance. Very highly recommend. Please try if you havent

The beer pours a hazy light amber color with a white head. The aroma is a mix of various hops, but is a little bit faint. I get some orange citrus, pine and flowery notes. The flavor is more assertive, with notes of pithy oranges and some caramel malt. The bitterness is about medium and just about right for a regular American IPA. Medium carbonation and medium mouthfeel. A very good IPA.

Beer poors from a bottle hazy copper with little to no head.  Aroma is huge on the initial poor and fades quickly.  Piney/citrusy notes are prevalent.  Bitterness is strong with a medium sweetness that balances everything out.  Palate is bubbly and bitterness lingers in the back of the throat after swallow.  Overall beer is a nice IPA and something I would go to for an overall IPA at the house

12oz bottle from Glens..
Appearance : Clear pale yellow with big foamy and creamy head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Very fruity (passion fruits), white sugar, lots of malt. Leafy hops. Piny.

Taste : Lots of malt with citrusy hops. Finish quite resinous and bitter. Fresh hops. 

Overall : Great IPA. Nice malt, nice hops. Soft carbonation. Quite drinkable. A little bit too resinous for my taste.

Pours cloudy and golden, white head. 
Pine nose, tons of hoppy bitterness throughout

On tap @ Old Chicago.  Pours a clear goldish yellow with slightly off-white head.  Almost no head retention, though it left a hazy white film on top of the beer, pretty great lacing.  Perfect IPA aromas: citrus hops with a hint of pine resin and some caramel notes from the malts. Taste is very well balanced, something I was not expecting from my 2nd ever Stone.  Sweet caramel maltiness intertwine with the orangy-pine hops.  Not a very assertive aftertaste, but great flavors nonetheless.  Medium bodied, also surprising from my 2nd ever Stone.  Subtle yet somehow lively carbonation kept this brew fun to keep sippin.

Nice grassy/resiny hop aroma with hint of the malt in the background.  Nice white head  on a hazy golden yellow brew.  Wonderful texture with a creaminess as you taste.  Very hop forward, but pleasantly so.  Some initial sweetness, but nice long, dry finish with warming alcohols.  Delicious.
I know IPA fanboys will hate me for this, but I really didnt care for this one.
great resin in the aroma - citrus and pine notes as well. strong hop bittering in in the taste. classic ipa hues and good head - slight lacing.

Cloudy golden pour from bottle.  Nose is burnt rubber bands and pine.  Taste is an excellent balance of hoppy bitterness, tropical fruits and spice.  Finish is grapefruitish (is that even a word??).  Solid!!

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Cloudy orange pour with a fluffy white head. Tangerine, baked apple and apricot aromas. Pineapple, orange peel, lemon rind flavours. Sharp citrus tang. Classic American IPA, does the job.

West USA trip 2010. On tap @ Stone Brewery. The aroma has mainly citric and piney hops. Clear, yellow-golden coloured beer with a white head. The taste has decent bitterness, pine and citrus. Clean. Crisp. Nice.

A: nice bright apricot colored orange with a good slightly off-white head. moderate retention level. great lacing.

S: perfect IPA aromas. citrus hops with some serious grapefruit aromas, some pine resin and some caramel notes from the malts.

T: very well balanced palate. sweet caramel flavors intertwine with the potent grapefruit flavors from the hops. strong aftertaste of pine resin and citrus. great flavors.

M: medium bodied for the style. perfect carbonation level. sharp, yet subtle. very clean and crisp.

Pours an orange color that is slightly hazy.  Has a large white foamy head.  Smells of citrus and earthy hops.  Taste of oranges and other citrus fruits are prevalent in the beginning.  Has quite the hoppy finish.  Floral notes hit my mouth during this beer.  Has blossoming oak tree tastes all over this drink.  A fairly good ipa.  I am a big fan of the hop - a - riffic beers and this is right up there.

12 oz. -> shaker.  At first blush, this is just your ordinary IPA: pours a translucent light amber, with a nice, frothy head and decent lacing.  Then you smell it, and something seems off: hoppy, citrus, with subtle apricot and evergreen notes, and bubble gum?  But when you taste it, you know this is no ordinary IPA..  Mixed in with the flora-citrus hoppiness and the subtle toasted maltiness are Bubblicious and the subdued bite of fresh black pepper.  And balance?  Perfect.

A-pours a transparent slightly hazed golden orange with a good bit of dense creamy off white head that leaves a solid lacing.

S-a light bready malt lies up front with toasted grain in the middle.  the hops take over with pine and citrus, notes of grapefruit, pear and appricot.

T-a lot of the same, extremely well balanced as the flavors seem to meld together in harmony, the malt base flashes quickly in the front with bready and caramel and compliments the piney hops towards the back.  the toasted grain is behind the malt and adds an earthy quality that adds complexity and balance to the herbal hop presence.  The citrus hops are juicy adding grapefruit, appricot, and mango.  there is a moderate lingering bitterness that rolls down the back of the tongue.  very well done!

M-light body, clean and crisp with a well done carbonation, juicy on the tongue and crisp in the finish.

D-this is a well balanced IPA that has malt flavors really complimenting the big hop presence.  everything compliments each other so well, it has the complexity you want but the hop bomb and bitterness you need.

Murky gold with a small head.  Not much visual carbonation.  Hoppy aroma and taste that lingers around after each swallow.  Finishes slightly dry.  If you love IPAs then this is your beer.  I find that American IPAs are mostly over hopped.
i love bitter beer but this one just doesnt do it for me. even though it is very bitter it just doesnt work well with the overall beer.
12 ounce bottle.  Golden color, thick white head.  Aroma of lemongrass and light spice.  Taste is progressively bitter with plenty of citrus, white pepper.  Decent.

12 oz bottle obtained during travels to S. Lake Tahoe.

Poured into a goblet. One finger wide head settles to a thin film over a hazy light golden beer. 

Smell: Light solvent alcohol, pine, and citrus. My nose is not good enough yet to distinguish which ones. Not as potent as the ruination I had a few days ago.

Taste: Just as an IPA should be, this one is hoppy but also balanced with the malts. The balance is very good. The finish is longish with the carbonation perfect, not too fizzy

Mouthfeel: This one is probably a great example of how an IPA should feel. The body is not too heavy, and combined with the flavors, makes for a very tasty beverage.

Drinkability: If I could get these on a regular basis, I would. This is a very good IPA.

Review #2

Bottle: Pours a Light Golden, with a modest white head. Decent Lacing. Smells of light floral hops and malt. Flavor of light floral hops, malt, molasses (when it warmed), and citrus. Taste is slightly bitter at the end, A fantastic IPA!

355 ml bottle. From Seattle, WA, USA.
Clear pale golden colour with tiny white head.
Fresh fruity bitter hops and some fruity sweetness in aroma.
Flavour is fruity fruit tea like bitterness with malty body. Grapefruit and harsh darkish (Stone) bitterness.

Stone India Pale Ale is one amazing brew. it pours out a moderately clear golden tint with a small white head with slight lacing. The aroma smells strongly of hops which is definitely expected considering the type of beer. A slight malt aroma is also present but plays a secondary role to the hops. The flavor is tiered. It begins with a malt flavor, moderately sweet that quickly gets passed up by the bite of the  hops. Its a pretty floral beer and it works well with the light body. It all works together it create and strongly flavored IPA with a great bitter bite throughout. Great brew.
For an India Pale Ale, I can actually tolerate this. Heavy, but not too strong.

(22oz bottle).  Pours apricot in color with white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, lemon and pine.  Taste is bitter with some sweetness.  Medium bodied with long bitter finish.  Overall, and excellent example of an IPA.
Poured from bottle, light hazey carmel color with nice lacing, has aroma of hops and has a very nice hop bite overall in the taste.  Very good IPA!
Fantastic beer, excellent aroma and a fantastic overall taste. A very consistent choice to get.
from a bottle.  This is a great IPA.  I just wrote a long review and ratebeer logged me out and I lost it so Im too lazy to write it again.  Highly recommended.

Appearance: Poured a golden amber with a 1 inch white head. Excellent lacing throughout.

Smell: Very strong hops with a bit of citrus. Very pleasant aroma with a hint of pine.

Taste: Very strong hops up front. Very nice bitter citrus flavor throughout.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied and very smooth.

Drinkability: Excellent drinakbility. Too bad the handle on my 6 pack broke while I was checking my mail, breaking all but one of these bad boys. Ill definitely be buying more.

Overall: Id rate this very high. One of the best IPAs Ive ever had.

Been a while since I had one of these. Grabbed 1 for a 12 pack sampler of my choice, was going to save it for my b-day Party in August, but it fell out of the Fridge, and it started hissing at me.....well, better drink it now :-)~
Poured into my Great Lakes Pilsner glass, Translucent yellow/orange. 2 inch White foamy head. What a freekin smooth IPA. Less hops than other IPAs, but balanced in every way. smells like Grapefruit. Wonderful malt sweetness on the back, with a dry hop finish. I wont be wasting my time with 1 freekin beer next time.  Better than I remember it.
Enjoyable floral hops aroma and spicy citrus flavor. Watery compared to the Ruination. I enjoyed it, its really a good IPA, but I was not impressed quite like the other Stone brews Ive had.

Decided to finally give this a try, the fact that I hadnt already was just odd.  Bought a bomber from Bullocks in Marietta.  Poured into a pint glass a clear golden hue with a creamy and sticky white head, awesome retention.  Left tons of lace on the glass.  Aroma was some fruity citrus hops, some earthy hop notes, bready malt and a bit of resin.  I am sure the aroma on a fresh bottle is much more hop forward, this was a bit subdued, yet very nice.  Good American IPA flavors throughout, maybe a bit too bready for my tastes but not bad.  Biting bitterness in the finish.  Leaves a very tasty hop presence long after each sip.  Good IPA, will seek some out on draft.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2015 On tap poured in dry, room temp glass. The color is a copper that looks great as the carbonation climbs the glass to a nice foamy, white head. Great lacing all the way down to the last sip. Flavor is citrus with a little spice that balances well against the bitterness. Hoppy aroma from the moment it hit the table. Very fragrant. Scents pine wood as well as the citrus. Easy flow, thin consistency that doesnt linger in the mouth which makes each sip taste fresh. This is my go-to ipa bottle drinker thats even better on tap, like most brews. Middle of the road abv makes this a great sixpack to keep in the fridge at all times or a great weekend night drinker. Highly recommend.
great after taste almost floral, good hop flavor. very enjoyable with a very nice body
It pours a nice cloudy golden color. Has a nice bitter hop taste with hints of hay and cereal. Nice strong hop aftertaste.

Orange with thin white head.
Aroma of fresh hops, citrus, spices and perfume. Complex!
Citrus flavour with notes of spices. Somewhat acidic with some sweetness and a loooooong bitterness.

On tap at Ginos East. Presents as a nice medium amber with a brilliant white head. Aroma is spicy, maybe a bit of cloves. Flavor is very smooth.  Im very impressed, especially after the arrogant bastard.
12 oz Bottle -- Pours burnt orange-amber with a thick creamy off-white head.  Aromas of tea, lemon, bergamot, peach, apricot, and pine, floral, and resin hops.  Big on both ends.

12oz bottle. Man, this is so controversial, but this has to be the first Stone beer I really wasnt that blown away by... Its one of the classics, and I still hadnt had a chance to try it, so I had to give it a go. I have a feeling this could have been a slightly old bottle, or maybe just an off bottling, so I have given it the benefit of the doubt and will definitely give it another go if I get another chance. Pours out deep golden with a dense off-white head which rests well for a time then dissipates. Aroma is very citrusy with lots of grapefruit and resinous earthy notes - reminds me of Jaipur or maybe Punk. So far so good, but the flavour was a bit weird, a lot of soapy notes, even a mild detergenty character, then some more citrus and lots of earthy hops, finish is bitter, but not necessarily pleasant... More odd soap notes. All in all a little upset as I love stone, and Im sure this is normally a great beer, but in this case this was not that pleasant.

Pours a deep golden honey hue with a small white head (1 finger) and near perfect carbonation. The nose is a delicious and enticing mix of caramel malt, floral, piney hops, citrus fruits (predominately pineapple and lemon zest), as well as an almost nectarine like fruitiness. The taste is bitter and balanced hops (not overly bitter) and an intruiging caramel malt backend followed by pineapple and a slightly bitter finale. The mouthfeel is light and perfect for a hot day. One of my favorite ipas.

The most drinkable IPA Ive tried.  Very well balanced with a hoppy flavor thats not overpowering.  Its easy to see why this beer is so popular in IPA markets.  Bitter aftertaste, but not the kind that make your tongue curl up.  Very well rounded beer that could easily be drank year round.

I am new to craft beer and this is my initial attempt at rating. I tried 4 beers, Stone IPA, Stone Ruination IPA, La Chouffe, Great Divide Oak Aged Chocolate Yeti. This Stone IPA was my favorite of the 4. I drank each bottle on a different night. I drank them early evening at the Jersey Shore sitting by the ocean. I drank each one in stages so I could test the change is taste and aroma as the beers became less chilled. Right out of the bottle, the beer had a strong positive aroma that created anticipation that this was going to be one great beer. I drank it in a tall pilsner glass and it looked beautiful against the backdrop of the sun going down over the ocean. The beer appeared darker at the bottom and then gradually lighter as the beer filled the glass. As I drank it, I realized this was one great beer. As noted, my favorite of these four. As I drank the beer throughout the evening, the aroma and taste seemed to get even better as the beer became less chilled. The taste that stayed on the palate was awesome. I rated this beer perfect as it struck me as my perfect beer. So overall, I see this as a beer I would store in my beer frig on a regular basis.

#700, 33cl bottle. Poured a hazy golden orange with a small, creamy and lasting white head leaving an uneven lacing. Lovely grapefruit, lychee hops, a peach sweetness and some caramel in the back. A crisp grapefruit and tangerine sweetness and a chewy sweet malt body. A hint of alcohol perhaps on the swallow but otherwise dominated by a lingering bitterness thats top notch. Maintains a bright mouthfeel on a medium body with medium carbonation and that lingering mid-dry hop finish.

This beer poured a golden, coppery straw color with a huge white rocky head. The smell was great! Nice typical hoppiness smells such as citrus nd pine. The taste was wonderful as well with a nice maltiness in the front followed by a proper bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel was thick. Nice heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall incredible. Stone Brewing is one of the best breweries out there. Enough said.
Draught at Pour 24, LV. Dry and bitter with a dominant grapefruit taste. Tangy, sharp, with a finish that makes you breathe in sharply and lingers well.
Stone ipa is a delicious blend of hops with lovely floral undertones. Yum yum gimmee some
Bottle. Pours deep rich orange. Head is lasting, rich white. Aroma and taste is citrus and piney. Malt and hops are well balanced. Hop bite is not overly bitter. This is a great beer.

Pours golden / cloudy orange. Nice long lasting white head. Nose is piney hops, some citrus. Taste is piney hops, citrus with some malt sweetness. Palate is medium body, good carboantion. crisp. Finish is hops with some citrus notes. A very nice well balanced IPA.
Hoppy aroma, light golden cloudy appearance. Great hoppy bitter taste that isnt overpowering. Feels smooth on the palate. Overall great beer.

Growler fill from the brewery.  I go back a long way with this beer and remember it being the hoppiest beer Id ever had about 12 years ago.  Glad to say that it can still hold its own against the plethora of IPAs out on the market.  Pours a bright orange with a nicely lacing white collar of froth. Nose is hoppy, but not as pungent as I remember from my early days.  I get mostly pine from the aroma, but there is some grapefruit lurking there as well.  The flavor is all about the hops with a subdued malt bill.  Needless to say this one is bitter and definitely a little lopsided.  My guess is that this has a ton of Chinook serving as the backbone.  Has just enough of a malt backbone to keep it from being like alcoholic grapefruit juice.  Mouthfeel is relatively light to showcase the hops and the texture is oily and resinous with a persistent carbonation.  Ends with a dry bitter bite that lingers on the tongue.  Not my favorite anymore, but still a classic.

Bottle. Pours clear gold. Head is typically retained and lacing is quite prominent around the glass. Aroma is a touch underwhelming (perhaps i expected more..) at close range, however upon opening of the bottle, the resinous piney-citrusy hop aromas could be experienced. Light medium mouthfeel with lingering bitterness, alcohol is not overly noticeable, body light-medium and makes the beer somewhat sessionable. Nice beer!

355ml bottle. Brilliant and bright golden orange in colour with an even layer of white foam. Aromas waft from the glass, big, bold and floral with a citrus backdrop. Packed full of mouth numbing flavours and a big kick of alcohol. Leaves a long and lasting impression on the palate.

Pours a burnt orange with a medium white head. Aroma is sweet citrus, grapefruit. Taste real sweet, very hoppy, with grapefruit notes. bitter near the end. good medium mouthfeel with a bit of warming ability. This is a pretty great offering from stone.

(bottle)  Poured with diminishing head and decent lacing.  I feel this is a little overrated.  I would call this an above average IPA.  Very hoppy and  slightly bitter with a long finish.  This is good, but theres some better IPAs out there.  Smooth with no alcohol flavor.

@ Capones into a standard pint glass.
Poured a a cloudy lemon yellow with a smallish one-finger white head which lasted throughout.  The lacing on this beer was exceptional, leaving a thick set of rings that marked each sip.  The nose presents citrus and some pine, but warns of heavy hops - hop-timid stay away!  Tastes starts with some bitterness, follows with a tinge of orange, grapefruit, lemon and pine.  Mouthfeel is medium with some edge/graininess from the very healthy carbonation.  I wouldnt call this a balanced IPA, but I enjoyed it very much and I would seek it out again.   Does Stone make ANYTHING that isnt good?
Pours a hazy gold with a thick white head. Aromas of pine and citrus, flavor is the same with just the right amount of malt sweetness. Nice dry finish; very drinkable. Another great beer from Stone.

Orange gold pour good strong carbonation a misty looking  IPA aroma citric hops caramel pine flavour good citric hop taste grapefruit decent bitter malt sweetness caramel is smooth pine taste floral very good body finish strong bitter aftertaste and fruity hops
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2012 Lovely fresh hops, could be just a tad more malty for my tastes.  Very good.  But I am not sure if this is the best IPA out there.   Serving: Bottle

22oz bottle from Lees Liquor 
Appearance: Slightly hazy golden amber with a nice white head and a nice amount of lacing 
Aroma: Caramel, citrus and pine resin 
Taste: Piney, grassy, malty and yeasty 
Always a good IPA.

Bottle - Golden amber pour with a big foamy white head. Smells big and citrusy. Real bright and fresh, with slightly sweet malt in the backbone. Taste is grassy, pine hops with a smooth heat in the mouth and through the finish. Nice malt balance. Slick and hefty in the mouth--I could drink this all day.
i cant just write ahhh hopppsss apparently. nice, standard ipa. pretty to look at, nice to smell, and hoppiness abounds.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a pale slightly hazy golden color with a huge white long lasting head. It has a floral, citrus and resin aroma. This is a phenomenal beer. The bitterness is close to perfect. It is complex and satisfying.
caramel, earthy, golden, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, average carbonation, bitter,
If there is a more perfect american IPA, I am not aware of it.  This beer is exactly what an IPA should be, and is exactly the blue print for every other wannabe brewery to aim for.  Excellent beer

Had this one from a special cask that used centennial hops.  Stone was doing some sort of promotion at Iron Abbey.  Poured a golden amber with a thick white head.  Aroma was very floral and hoppy.  Taste was a heap of hops right up front, but then some faint fruity notes and a bitter aftertaste.  Very drinkable, very balanced, especially for something this hoppy.  Like I said, this was a special cask, so its a little different from the standard brew.
Poured on tap.  Nice two-finger head, excellent lacing.  Very hoppy and bitter.  This should be a standard beer on anyones list.

SD Trip, sampler: Hmmm, maybe Im getting the pales mixed up, that can happen. This is a hoppy, but not overly so, IPA. The best IPA out there, as the community score would suggest, Id say no, but its drinkable and not offensive so it has mass appeal over some (better) IPAs and DIPAs (Hercules). Again, may have been muted by the Sublimely I was also drinking.

Great beer. A hallmark of the style in America. A true measuring stick.  Lots of big hop, great bitterness in the finish and ultimately refreshing. A super beer, we are all lucky to have as a main stay of craft brewing.

Bottle. Slightly hazy orangeish gold pour with a foamy white head that doesnt last too long. Nose is pretty hoppy, with notes of passionfruit, grapefruit, lemon, pine, lychee, wood and caramel. The flavour has a bit more spice than the aroma, the malty caramel is more pronounced and the citrus is more concentrated, being a little sharper and less sweet. Mouthfeel is smooth and oily with moderate to low carbonation and a long bitter finish that conceals a hint of sweetness. Overall this is a real artisan IPA; refined, excellently balanced and highly drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2010 earthy wheat and citrus/piney/resiny aroma not too powerful..appearance is just what an ipa should look like amber orange pure white foamy head which dissipates halfway thru..nice balance of flavors again citrus and bitter flavors with subtle honey-like malts..drinkability is very easy ..overall a good-very good ipa dont think it warrants straight 100 marks but may be just the thing on a hot summer day
An unclear amber beer with a frothy white head. Aroma is very hoppy, citrus and caramel. Flavor is malty and bitter, notes of caramel. Very solid bitterness. A really good IPA.
Simply put....this beer is the reason I switched to IPAs as my everyday beer of choice. Forever will be my favorite beer.
Bottle. Hazy amber with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel and lots of hops.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2015 [6/10] Bottle, 12C. Almost clear orange with a small off-white head. Low bead. Smells extremely sweet under a fresh hop aroma that is more pine than grapefruit. Taste has a good balance between sweet and bitter. The sweetness has nectarines and sugary caramel. The bitterness is big and lingering but not overpowering and - as in the aroma - is more pine than citrus. Let down by the slightly crude sweetness - maybe youre supposed to drink it colder (but then it would surely be quite unbalanced).[3.5] [11/11]Much colder this time (about 8C) and it does work rather better - the malt platform now registers as an adequate platform for the hop show (but contributes little). These West coast takes on IPA still seem very 8-bit high-contrast to me. Still, the hops are lovely. [3.7][4/15] Non-deprecated import. The same. Good but very sweet.

12 oz. Drank yesterday. Pours a slightly hazed orange copper collar with big head that leaves lots of lacing.  Aroma is very hoppy hints of citrus pine hop resin and floral.  Taste is similar with very strong but not overpowering hop bite subtly balanced by smooth crisp malts.  Finish is incredibly well crafted, light, crisp, and clean with a perfect balance.   A standard to which all IPAs should be compared.

Poured from 22 oz. Bottle into shaker.  As soon as I cracked open the bottle the great scent of hops rushed into my nose and I just smiled.  It has a great aroma of hops...oh yeah...did I mention hops.  The pour released this aroma even more and had a nice two-finger head that leaves a lot of lacing, pours a nice golden amber.  The taste is great...well balanced, but hoppy...hard to describe; just taste it.  The mouthfeel is great; silky smooth and just damn refreshing.  Overall a great IPA, one of the best I have had.  4.3
Picked up a 22 oz. bottle. Pours a beautiful color with minimal head. Tastes of citrus.
Bottle. Was EXTREMELY fresh. Almost an ammonia-cat piss smell and taste to the hops. Can say that it could stand to calm down for a couple weeks. Still not bad at all
this is an amazing IPA. The hops really come out in this beer. It also has the right amount of color and clearness too it. The head stays with you almost to the bottom of the glass.

Pours from the bottle an orange color with hefty, creamy, white head that really stays around for the whole drink. Aroma has a floral, heavy citrus, light pine hoppiness to it with a mild caramel and pale mate sweetness with a touch of toastedness. Flavor has a nice strong grapefruit citrus with a slight less strong pine note with the combination creating a perfect IPA flavor. The hops is there but not off balance with the slightly sweet, caramel and low toastedness of the malt. Body is modest with fine carbonation lending a very smooth creamy feeling. Alcohol isnt detectable. Overall a very well crafted brew with a great balance of hops and sweetness. One of the best, every day drinking IPAs on the market.

Picked up a 15.5g keg down at stone after a tour for the kegerator.  Head is thick white  and lasts.  Color is a golden with hint of orange.

Smells of hops, floral, a bit of citrus.  Taste is super hoppy, less balanced with malt than some other IPAs, but very delcious.  Medium mouthful, just the right carbonation, perfect balance of biterness and malt.  Super drinkable when in the mood for a simple IPA.

Pours rich gold with a rocky foam head of white froth.  Sweet oranges and flowers in the nose.  It has a tart and tangy feel in the mouth that is pleasantly sweet into bitter.  This is an excellent IPA.

Pours gold-orange with a medium off-white head. Nose is very bitter hops, as you might expect from a Stone IPA. The hoppiness takes no prisoners, but is almost too concerned with being knock-down bitter without boiling in mid-grade hops early for a more floral bitterness. I made the mistake of trying Stones Ruination IPA before this one and I have to say Ruination is the superior beer....its even more bitter but is much more balanced than this one is. My complaints aside, this is still one of the best IPAs Ive had.
Pours orange-yellow with close to no head. Smell is citrus; grapefruit, and some orange and grapefruit. Taste is similar, with a bigger grapefruit kick. Bitter, with a clean finish.

Pours a cloudy orange with half a Ginger of off white head.  Nice strong hop bitterness in the nose with a bit of lemon zest.  Less bitterness in the initial taste, a light lemon that builds into a strong great bitter aftertaste.  Very solid IPA

Bottle, 355ml. Pours a clear golden/amber colour with a small yet appetizing, fluffy, offwhite head. Aroma is of course all about the hoppiness, with some nice hints of honey. Taste is heavy and comlex, all the bitterness is nicely balanced by a malty backbone. Extraordinary.

Tried this one on a friends recommendation.  I tend to look for a more balanced style like Pale Ale so Im a bit skeptical of West Coast massive IPAs.  But wow.  Stone IPA is a must drink beer.  Amazing hop balance between flavor, aroma and bitterness.  The bitterness is nicely balanced against the malt.  Somehow they have managed to get a strong hop profile that doesnt hang on too long.    The high rating on this beer is well deserved.  I cant believe Ive waited so long to try it.

Bottle.  Pours hazy and orange/amber with a one-finger frothy white head, and leaves sheets of lacing.  Aroma is crisp, fresh citrus, floral hops, and some sweet fruit.
