This is a very nicely balanced beer.  Bitter citrus is evident first, with a sweet malt backbone, slight fruit notes, and a bit of an earthy undertone.  Very smooth, tingly, and warming.  Very good.

From 12 oz bottle at Fuel and Fuddle. Nice white head that subsided to a nice barely-there foam that left no lacing (Im thinking this is due to Fuel & Fuddles glasses, not the beer itself). Strong floral hop aroma predominates on the nose. Strong hop character in the mouth. Good malt backbone that balances the bitterness - I think this is one of the things that makes this beer great. Medium bodied, with a hoppy oiliness on the palate thats balanced by the lively carbonation. Clean bitter finish. Outstanding IPA that, for me, is one of the definers of the style.

A clear, yellow-amber color. Appears light-bodied and thin. 

Has a very mild aroma. A slight hop aroma, but malts also coming through. Balanced scent, nothing overpowering. Has an underlying fruit scent; maybe apricot? Pleasant, but doesnt make me salivate for it. 

Strong hoppy flavor. Malts are present, but overwhelmed by the hops for sure. Nicely balanced; hops are not as overwhelming as I expected. Malt is a nice, smooth counterpoint. Has a slight fruit flavor which I cant quite identify, but it works. 

Thick and heavily hopped. Has a fizzy consistency that bounces off the tongue. Not a light beer, by any stretch. But highly drinkable. Has a very hoppy aftertaste, which means I probably couldnt drink two consecutively, but I could drink several in a night. Good beer.

Poured from the bottle into an Adams glass.  Pour produced a slightly hazy, golden-yellow body topped by a thick luxurious head of foam, with a good amount of cling.  Excellent hops aroma, full-bodied and rich.  The taste, like one would expect, is dry and bitter, full of hops flavor.  What I like about this IPA is that the hop aftertaste does not overstay its welcome, tasting good and clean.  While I dont have enough IPAs under my belt to call this a definitive IPA, I would have to say it ranks up there somewhere.
Pours a hazy yellow with thick white head. Aroma is spruce and grapefruit. Flavor is grapefruit and hay. Body is creamy with high carbonation.

Dark transparent golden body, fluffy slightly toasty colored head.  Rich floral aroma with notes of mostly pine with some grass and light toast.  Slightly carbonated body, tasty bitter flavors, mostly earthy hops.  Overall a good IPA.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2011 poured from 220z bomb - Finally getting around to consuming the original Stone IPA after being sidetracked by numbers like Ruination IPA and Double Bastard Ale.  Stone has so many flashy bottles that the rather plain looking "IPA" is unassuming.  Well...it is good.  Rather one dimensional and straight forward hoppiness, but if Im getting serious, Ill spend my money on Ruination.  All said, straight forward and solid IPA.  Re-rated 5.13.11 - This is even better than I remembered.  Im not sure this is better than Ruination after all.  What a great IPA.

On tap into a pilsner glass at the flying saucer in San Antonio.  

Poured a light bronze with one finger of white head.  Cant smell much, mostly grapefruit.  The taste is floral and grapefruit with a sharp bitter bite on the finish.  Crisp and clean.  I dont taste much malt.  very dry.

Drank gallons of this stuff for years.  Recently had a bottle again (at Chipotle of all places) and was a bit underwhelmed.  The best by date was fine and it seemed like the hops were a bit course and there were no citrus notes.  It was a decent but not excellent IPA.  Ive had it before though both in bottle and on tap where it is really a solid IPA with a crisp finish and some pine and citrus among the chewy hops.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2010 12 oz. bottle. Golden pour with an initially thick head. Smells strongly of cascade and floral hops and sweet citrus grapefruit. Taste is initially of bitter hops with some lighter flower tones. It then morphs into a citrus grapefruit flavor. The final stage is a cascading plunge of bitterness culminating in a wave of intense hops in the aftertaste. Palate is somewhat thick and syrupy. A very excellent IPA. As Ludwig Wittgenstein once said, "I turn to stone" -- now who could deny the taste continues?
Has everything you need in a good IPA, good aroma, appearance and dry hoppy taste. This could be a great session beer, and the ABV could allow this to work. Ill try and make that happen.

One of the most interesting things Ive discovered since venturing into the world of beer-reviewing is the fact many beers can have a flavor that is reminiscent of a certain ingredient even though the brewer has not added it to the recipe. For example, many German wheat beers have a banana and spice taste, but neither are added. In the case of American India pale ales like Stone IPA, many taste like grapefruit, but the beer contains no juice whatsoever.Stone IPA is packed full of flavor with a seemingly distinct taste of grapefruit. Whats odd is the beers taste is more accurately described as sweet than tart. Still, its a delicious beer even if it isnt your usual IPA.POUR, COLOR AND AROMAPoured from a 22oz bomber, this beer flows a little rough but eventually evens out. It produces a bright orange/dark amber body which is rather hazy (although I didnt see any sediment). The carbonation is low, and the head is well-proportioned, white, foamy and creamy. The aroma is to die for with a strong, sweet and yet light fragrance of flowers and citrus. The hops are just calling out to be drunk!TASTEWhat puts some people off about IPAs is their intense hop bite, and even though Stone IPA is quite the hoppy its actually not as intense as you might think. Like any quality beer of this style the presence of hops is definitely noticeable immediately, but the beer finishes with a sweet, refreshing and slightly watery taste of citrus. There isnt much of a hop bite here; in fact, the flavor in the end is rather dry. The brewerys website states it is dry-hopped for two weeks to get the extra bitterness. While I would agree that this beer is certainly bitter, I found it to be more sweet than tart. It has a candy-like taste which is very pleasing, and thankfully no sugary aftertaste. Still, I was a little surprised this beer was more citrusy than it was hoppy, since it was crisp, clean and refreshing, rather than an all-out assault on the palate (hey, when a beer has a picture of a demon on the label, its rather ominous dont you think?). FINISHStone IPA is much smoother than youd expect. There is a faint dryness to the finish, but no aftertaste or scouring effect on your tongue. The sweet taste and slightly watery body make it very drinker-friendly.BODYThe Stone Brewing Company has a reputation for making [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ beers that are for true connoisseurs only. Although their IPA is rather heavy at 6.9% ABV and 77 IBUs, its amazing as just how light and easy this beer is on your system. This is a case where the numbers lie, since this beer drinks like something much more pedestrian and would work well as a session beer rather than a one-and-done drink.FINAL THOUGHTSId say this is definitely an outstanding beer and one of the best American examples of the India Pale Ale style. However, I think Stone (much like Rogue) goes to show the distinct difference between beers brewed on the East Coast versus the West Coast. If you want intense hop bitterness opt for Dogfish Head. If you want something lighter and sweet, opt for Stone  you wont be sorry.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOv35yP6J-8
bottled, clear gold pour with white head, aroma of grassy hop and light malt, big grass/pine hops up front with clean crisp malt finish, medium-low carbonation with lasting hops on palate, tasty

Bottle @ Caedinal, Stavanger. Pours nice amber/gold, with a huge creamy white head. Aroma of rich floral hops, citrus, & some malt; taste of malt, pine hops, citrus (notably grapefruit), and some caramel; Finish is bitter and does linger awhile. Overall, a really good IPA.
12oz bottle. Full bodied but smooth. Some beers are better, but this is highly drinkable.

12oz bottled April 13, 2010.  2 weeks old is as fresh as I ever see Stone round here.  Pours pale golden/amber with a good white head that maintains a foamy cap and leaves some nice spots and rings of lacing.  Aroma is a blast of pine up front, some citrus, grapefruit, touch of floral & grass, and a hint of bready malt.  Flavor is bitter & hoppy, pine, earthy, citrus rind, a little bit of malt sweetness and a nice long bitter finish.  Not incredibly complex, but very tasty.  Mouthfeel is on the thin side, sharp carbonation.  This drinks really easy, and is an exceptional IPA.
Bottle. Medium head with a clear golden appearance. Some bitterness with not as hoppy as some of their beers. Lingering bitterness. A straightforward, uncomplicated example of this style.
Reeks of pine, light in body, laces your glass, and boasts a bitterly refreshing aftertaste. Pretty much everything an IPA should be.
Just about as sessionable an ipa as there is. Very piney with a lot of grapefruit.  Goes great with anything spicy

Pours orange amber off-white head Light carbonation with a nice floral and pine hops with a little malt to the nose; Floral, grassy, very light citrus hops provide the bitterness while a touch of malt provides some sweetness on the initial taste.  Full medium body, a  good bitter aftertaste that you would expect.

Had this IPA a million times but just had it at a Stone beer dinner at BJs Brew house so....I have always loved this beer, it was the beer that introduced me to craft beer. Great hop aroma, citrus, pine. Tastes like it smells. This sets the standard for IPAs in my opinion...it also helps that its freakin cheap for a beer this good.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 Stone week sampler at Finnegans, Plainfield. This is the Double Dry Hopped IPA, for those keeping score. Deceptively pale Bud color, but for a bit of haze. Some clingy lace. Smell is another boxing glove stuffed with hops straight from the homebrew store. Just hoppus in extremis, that gets in the way of a malty beer.
Regular IPA from 12 oz. bottle, $1.79 @ Binnys. Im breaking my beer fast after a week on antibiotics. Again, a light golden pour, but notably hazy. Kicks up a big slightly orange head of foam. In my beer-starved state, I find the citrusy, resiny hop smell to be strangely warming, the malts inviting. Taste has some dried hop to it, a little rough as befits dry-hopping and quite welcome after two weeks without. So I can bump it up a few notches from the Double Dry Hopped draft (was 6-3-7-4-13 for 3.3). Not as smooth and chewy as Alpha King or Two Hearted, and clearly they dont care.

A- Transparent medium amber body. An aggressive pour only produced a head of 1 finger. The tiny bubbles constantly rising to the top (which is great because Im drinking this from a standard pint glass) give this one a decent head retention. Eventually a thin collar remains and no lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Wonderful bouquet of citrus, floral, and earthy hops with a sweet caramel malt backbone.

T- A balance of herbal and citrus hop taste upfront with a weak caramel malt backbone. The finish is mostly herbal hops with a caramel malt sweetness. Lingering bitterness is aggressive and somewhat unpleasant. Also lingering is an herbal hop taste, caramel malt sweetness, and alcohol warmth.

P- Aggressive carbonation and oily body of medium thickness.

O- This is a decent IPA but not one of my favorites. I was surprised that the alcohol was detected in this medium ABV brew. This one is full of hop flavor and bitterness. I may revisit this one again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-06-2007 15:47:34
very solid IPA- one of my favs now.  Great hoppy taste and smooth. Citrusy goodness

Slightly hazy gold body with a sudsy white head.  Nice aroma of pine and citrus rind.  Slick, oily mouthfeel...very easy to drink.  Fantastic flavor that starts with some nice malty sweetness that builds before being pushed aside in favor of a perfect citrus and pine bitter fade.  A top notch IPA.
pours a cloudy yellow with bits of stuff floating around. Taste is hoppy and a standard expectation from stone.

I think I found my new favorite beer, at least my new favorite IPA by far.  Aroma is a mixture of floral and citrus hops, appearance is a very bright copper with a creamy head.  This is the perfect balance of hops and a slight maltiness with a sort of creaminess typically not found in hoppy beers.  Its $11.99 for a six pack in Chicago and its worth every penny.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 Clear golden-amber liquid with a big white head and lots of lacing.  Wonderful hops produce a smell that makes me picture groves of oranges and lemons. Its fresh and clean without overwhelming.  The flavor is hoppy with almost perfect bitterness. The malt backbone is there and provides just enough sweetness to express the hops at their finest, keeping the bitterness pleasant. Creamy, sudsy, oily with hops.  Edit (7/22/10): Had it a few times since the rating and Im not quite as impressed with the aroma anymore.
One of the best IPAs that I have tried! The balance between the hops and malts shows in this great tasting IPA.

Thanks Stone for turning me on to Ipas.  Very first ipa I drank nearly 7 yrs ago.  Now this is my go to Ipa.  Appearance is golden. Taste is grapefruit, citrus, with a little pine aroma with a touch of resin.  Touch of bitterness but just perfect.  Very easy to drink and very enjoyable!

Pours a golden-orange color with a solid white foamy head which clings to glass. Citrus hops, grapefruit, and light bread in the nose. The palate is light and smooth with a lasting finish. Light sweetness upfront with a puckering hop bitterness in the end. For an IPA this beer is well-balanced between the hops and malt. The hops certainly come out on top, but theyre not harsh or overpowering. Nice refreshing citrus flavor.

Having tried 3 bottles in the last couple days Im just not getting what all the rave is about. It looks good. Beautiful sunshine color with a lasting 1 finger head. Nice lacing. Aroma is mild crisp hops and not much else. Taste is bitter hops that finishes too dry almost to the point of giving me cotton mouth. Not a session beer here and certainly FAR from being the best.

Tap. Pours a clear golden orange with a fluffy white head. Aroma is very piney, hop resin, citric, some melon and grapefruit. Flavor is even more intensely hoppy. Again, very melon, grapefruit, nectarine, juicy hops, all melded together into a soft but present malt backbone. The dry hops really give it a fresh flavor, and the bitterness is very sharp but not off-putting. Medium body and a moderate fizzy carbonation. Very tasty IPA

Pours a clear golden hue with a nice white head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is grapefruit, grass, florals and pine.  Taste is bitter with the grapefruit shining through, the alcohol is there but hidden extremely well. Finish is dry, clean and crisp.  The flavors stick around.  A great IPA.
from a taster at bj and stone tasting,golden, crip ,white head,great hoppy ipa

Pours hazy bright yellow.  Minimal soapy head which disappates quickly while lace continues throughout drinking.  Nice hoppy floral nose with slight piney taste.  Well balanced, great hop flavor.  Well deserved any time of year!
6 pack from Greens. Aroma is resin, citrus.Appearance is nothing special: pale, clear, minimal head.very bitter, light sweetness, lightly sour,

pours slightly cloudy golden colour with small white head.  Carbonation dissipates relatively quickly.  Citrus floral and pine on the nose.  Decent bit of  hoppiness in the taste (floral with citrus) ,   but not too bitter, which lingers slightly but not too long. .  Overall is (in my mind a textbook ipa) with nice nose, and good crisp and easy drinking.

Pours a beautiful golden apricot color with a medium sized, frothy white head. Lots of sticky lacing. The aroma is very juicy citrus, with floral and pine notes as well. The flavor has more pine and floral character, without as much citrus as the aroma. Its pretty sweet upfront, but very bitter on the backend. There is also a bit of cereal grains on the finish. Medium bodied with very soft carbonation, and a long, bitter finish. Yum.

12-oz bottle.
A - Aroma is citric, but not as with loads of heavy as some. Some floral undertones. Some other fruits also present, maybe peach.
A - Cloudy golden color with a one-finger white fizzy head. Good lacing on the glass.
T - Hops are featured up front and they are salty and wet. Sweet malts taste like honey and caramel. Long and bitter finish but not tonsil-twisting. Crisp.
end.
P - Medium body with a slightly sticky texture.
O - For all the trash talking on the bottle, this is a balanced American IPA. Very drinkable, But its not something you want to hurry through. Savor it.

Aroma:  fruity hops are strong 
Appearance: golden and cloudy golden color with a frothy head.
Taste: bitter tasting of hops through and through.  Perfect and a bit crisp.
Palate: medium bodied with a bitter finish.  Lingers for a moment in the back of the mouth.
Overall:  This is an IPA.

From a pint glass - a nice golden yellow color with a fairly thin white head.  Hops and citrus with some pine in the aroma. A medium-to-full body gives way to a balance of bitter/sweet,  A nice crisp finish.  This is a very solid IPA, but you probably wont still be thinking about it the next day.

It was listed as Double dry hopped. The hoppy aroma was hitting me as I raised the glass. Piney goodness. The taste was hoppy as the aroma.  The glass laced after the first sip showing its sticky goodness. Another supurb beer from Stone. Welcome to Illinois!!!

[A] Very candy-like, sugary, smell. Malt must do it. Piney, orange, fruity hop perfume. This is quite a quaffer. [A] Clear gold. White head. Alive in glass. [F] Piney hops. Hops. Hops. Citrus. Some pale malt sweetness. [P] Between light and medium bodied. Easy to drink. Bitter is great for 70 IBUs. Lingers on. [O] This is a pretty damn flavorful brew. I enjoyed every sip of it. Highly drinkable. 99/100 is impressive. I imagine its deserving, as this is a great definition and rendition of style, let alone, a great beer. Nice.
Very good.  Biting, sharp, hoppy taste.  Not overpowering.  A true IPA.  Hazy, full appearance.  A very, very good beer.  Worthy of every rating.
12 oz. bottle, pours a vibrant orange with a white head. Aroma of grassy hops, citrus, pine and floral notes. Great hoppy flavour, with a nice bitter finish. Smooth, creamy palate. Wonderful IPA.
Light golden color medium bitterness with a nice citrusy hop flavor.Nice floral citrus aroma.
Pours hazy blonde with no head and great lacing.  Warm aroma of pine and cheddar.  Strong hop character pine and grapfruit flavor.  Finishes citric and bitter.  A paragon of IPAs
Pint at The Traveler. Pretty sweet IPA from Stone. Big hops, which is exactly what I looking for. Only slightly hoppier than Dales Pale Ale (my current pale goto) which is how it should be.
this rating shouldnt even count. im not an ipa fan. this beer wasnt bad. dont read this.

355ml Bottle, via trade with Lithy. Hazy golden orange colour, frothy white head. Aroma of lovely fruity and piny hops, mango, some grapefruit, a bit of caramel. Flavour is malty, fruity, mango, peach, a touch of earthy liquorice root, good earthy pine bitter finish that lingers. Light to medium bodied, smooth and creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. I could drink this all the time. Thanks Justin!

Flaske 0,355l på Bar & Cigar,Oslo 16 Feb 10. Aprikosfarget. Litt uklar. Kraftig aroma dominert av sitrusfrukter.  Lavt luftig skum. Variert fruktig smak med sitron & appelsin i forgrunnen. Avslutningen er litt syrlig med en fruktig bitterhet. Bra.

12 oz bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in an English pint glass. Pours a slightly hazy golden colour with a small white head that fades quickly leaving slight lace. Aroma is pungent high-alpha hops: big citrus dripping with pine resin. Notes of biscuit malts are also present, but subservient to hops. Flavour begins with moderate malt sweetness, but hops quickly take over, building towards a big grapefruit finish that is intensely bitter. Light in body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Finish is mildly astringent. Overall, an intensely hoppy, intensely bitter IPA. While I enjoy big IPAs, this one is one-dimensional: malts are sparse and have virtually no depth. Inadequate for such enormous hops. Even the hops are quite simple: a more complex blend would have made for a much better beer. 2010-03-08

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.
It pours a nice light amber color with a sizeable, pillowy, off-white head.  The head is very lasting and it leaves nice sheets of lacing all the way down the glass.  The nose is full of herbal, floral, and citrus hop notes.  The flavor is solidly bitter as you would expect.  The herbal and citric qualities take center stage in the flavor profile.  The malt side of things is almost nowhere to be found.  Medium to medium-light in body with medium carbonation and a lengthy, bitter finish.  Overall this is one solid IPA and definitely one everybody should try.
Bottle. Hazy yellow body with a large bubbly white head. Aroma is light hops, grapefruit, pine and fruit. Flavor is tons of hops, firfruit and grapefruit. It has a long lasting bitter aftertaste.

Bottle from Kris Wines, London. A hazy amber affair with a terrific pillowy white head. Earthy, piney hop packed aroma and flavour with bags of tropical fruit notes. Great balance and a poised bitter finish. Top notch.
12 ounce bottle a dark gold pour white head. A big floral hop aroma taste of citrus, floral A pleasent bitter hop finish

Bottle, shared with hobbersr and Cole. Ours clear amber, medium head, spotty lacing. Nose is super grassy, and frankly really smells like pot! Plenty of spicy, piney hops, notes of anise, and there is malt lurking in the background as well. Flavors of pot, very mild malt, pine resin, simple bitter finish.

Beer #4 of IPA night in good old Lethbridge AB. I brought this one back from Marcus Foods in Whitefish MT. Pours a pale yellow with a small white head. The aroma is like sticking your face into a big old bag o weed. These hops really have an identity crisis. They see what their cousin is doing and they really want to join in. Wow this tastes like weed too. Herbaceous, citric, woodsy... just like good reefer. It really tastes like bong water... Again, in a good way. Very, very nice.

Very hoppy smell, distinct hops from pacific north west. Nice head, pretty good lacing too. Fairly clear, slightly reddish brownish yellowish. Too clear. Cant really taste anything other than hops in there, no malt flavour to be had. Not much else in the palate either, just a hops blast. I like it fine, but its more like a drink to float hops in to drink thier favorite hops strains. Its just too thin and not alcoholic enough for such a good hops prescence.

Clear amber colour with a tall white head. Gread hoppy aroma smells like the pacific north west. Flavour is very sharp and hoppy a really nice IPA with a very nice mild bitter aftertaste. I did have the ruination a few day ago and this is letting me down. but still a great IPA.
Pours a light orange color with white head.Has an enticing aroma of floral hops and citrus fruit.The flavor is a grapefruit citrus.Great full body and bitter aftertaste.Another great Stone brew.

Not my favorite Stone brew, but not bad. Bottles from a local store, a dark orange colored beer. The aroma is biter fruit/floral. Tastes like very bitter fruit, the taste lingers after every sip. Very bitter, but not offensive, sour taste. Tastes better with food, preferably a juicy steak.
A little bit of a light color to it with a nice head. Great bite on the hop flavor, really nice IPA!!

I adore Stone,  got this in a great BIF package.  Aroma is hop and some citrus.  Pours a golden yellow with a white head.  Taste is intense hop with dry hop bitterness.  Its a hop lovers dream.  What a nice beer but you need the palate for it.

22 oz bottle - pours Orangish-Brown, nose is bitter and hoppy.  Taste is strong and bitter.  finishes bitter and lasts.  Ok to try, not one of my favorites at all.  Im having a hard time liking anything from Stone.

Bottle shared by hallinghansen. Thanks a bunch! Pours hazy yellow with a thick longlasting white head. Piney hoppy aroma with lots of fruity notes. Peach, pineapple and a good caramel background. Heavy piney flavour with lots of fruity hoppy notes like peach and pineapple. Only disturbing thing is a light plastic note. Long bitter hoppy aftertaste. Nice IPA indeed.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2010 Poured from a bottle into a Sam Adams perfect pint glass.  The best by date gives is about a month and a half away.
Pours a nice translucent deep orange, with a small quickly receding white head.  Smells great being dominated by citrus hops.  Taste is hops, hops, hops.  Also a bit spicy and citrus are coming through, without much of a malt backbone to back it up.  Ends crisp with lingering hops.

This is a classic CALI IPA that I have had many times in the past but yet to rate.. Its that time. Called the "baseline" for all IPAs by JW32HOOPS, I needed to give this IPA a proper rating..pours a very translucent golden almost a pearly golden if thats possible, the trademark snow white two finger head lingers for just a bit.. aroma is a dry pine scented floral montage of hops.. first hit to the palate is smooth and powerful at the same time.. the bitterness is very apparent and mugs my mouth for the duration.. yes, its good but its also like a hug from a coworker...a little awkward, meaning that the bitterness bullys the smooth transition from hops to aftertaste and Im not sure it allows my palate to fully adjust. I was hoping this time would be different and it is a very good IPA but just not on the level of a Lagunitas, Green Flash or even the Sierra Nevada Torpedo which I really enjoy. Rich? yes.. robust? yes, refreshing?..  not exactly..  Sorry JW32Hoops, this stone has stopped rolling..

Poured from bottle, enjoyed with vegetarian feijoada (which I know is a contradiction in terms). Aroma is bright with citrus hops notes. A perfect appearance; gorgeous gold, great head, delicate lace that nevertheless lasts. Palate is rich and spritzy, perfect for cutting through the serrano pepper. My sole complaint is the taste; Im not a huge hophead (though Im learning) and I wanted a bit more malt to counterbalance the hops. Still, damned fine beer.

Favorite IPA.  Clear amber appearance with substantial white head.  Spicey and piney hops with a touch of citrus.  Extremely bitter, but very tolerable with balanced malt, full body and crisp finish.  Keep trying other IPAs, but keep buying the Stone.

22oz poured into a pint glass.   Color is a beautiful translucent light copper with an unassuming off white head.  Hits the palate as if it were my tastebud g-spot, just hard enough.  Piney with some subtle herbal and even more subtle citrius hops. Aftertaste is hops with just the right amount of bitterness.  Aroma is slightly floral piney hops with a dash of hops. Hops.

What can you say that hasnt already been said about Stone IPA, the king, the quintessential IPA, the baseline standard by which all other IPAs are to be judged.  I am a complete and total IPA addict and it was Stone that irst got me into IPAs when I moved to California.  Since then, Ive broadened my IPA horizons and my palate is a bit more mature.  Still, you can never go wrong with Stone IPA.  So simple, but maybe that is what makes it great.  When I think of hops, I think of Stone.  When I think IPA, I think of Stone.

330mL bottle from Volo. Great beer, right up there with their lovely ruination double IPA. Pours yellow with small amount of white head. Citrus, grassy nose. Lots of piney bitterness upfront, not much malt, and finish tapers off quite quickly. Nice full flavour, and something I could drink several of.

A: Golden straw color with a small, very small, amount of white foam that dissipates quickly. Not much carbonation to speak of.

S: Lots of citrus, most notable is lemon. There is also a mild pine scent. Not much malt to speak of.

T: A wonderful and powerful bitterness. Very piney, but also slight lemony notes. Again, not much malt shining through.

M: Very crisp beer with a lingering bitterness.

D: Highly drinkable, but watch out for this one, it will bite when youre not looking at 6.9%.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2010 This is a great beer and it is readily available everywhere (Southern CA obviously). Nicely bitter, some fruit with spicy/earthy flavors. Nice mouth-feel. Its a great IPA, but not the absolute best.

22oz bomber.  Pours a hazy body topped with a 1-inch off-white head that recedes leaving sticky lacing from top to bottom.  Aroma of light malt sweetness and orange/floral hops.  Taste is piney, resin, floral, bitter, light sweet, grapefruit and then bitter again.  Malt fights to get a foothold vs hops.  Bitter, lasting aftertaste.  What one of my relatives says "...tastes like carpet..."  Hoptacular!!

Pours orange-golden with thin white head that dissipates.  Clear.  Nice floral hop aroma invites you in.  Straight bitterness, but very clean and crisp and not overly harsh.  Malt is present for only a blink.  Dry finish.  Very good, but I think I prefer the Ruination.  This is a very easy drink, though.  Makes me wish it was 80 F and sunny and not 22 F like it is now!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2013 Pours a orange amber color with a good sized white head with good lacing.  aroma is nice and hoppy with alot of pine resin and citrus.  flavor hoppy with alot of pine resin, grapefurit, and lemon.  has a mediium body with a nice dry bitter finnis that makes it very drinable for such a great beer.  overall, one of the best IPAs in the world with out a doubt.
one of the classic american i.p.a.s. there is nothing negative about this beer, other than i wish it was *slightly* hoppier. other than that, its basically perfect.

12 z bottle, pours a copper hue with a generous off white head. Hops aroma do not overpower, but provide an inviting bouquet. Medium to heavy taste of grapefruit and grass. A solid hoppy bitter finish. Another fine offering from Stone!

12 oz bottle pours murky orange-amber with a good bit of retaining off white head into a tulip.  Crisp lemon/grapefruit hops pervade in the aroma, honey and a bready malt sweetness are there as well.  More bitter than I thought it would be: loads of bitter hops upfront which blend into a floral bouquet; finishes dry, bready, and slightly sweet with lemon.  Nice, soft, frothy mouthfeel with medium body and carbonation level.  Highly drinkable and sessionable.  Solid IPA.
Bottle. Clear golden amber color with a slight light cream frothy head. An easy to drink IPA that is not complex and has a great flavor. Strong hops which give you a tasty dry bitterness.
on tap - orange amber beer with almost no foam. Strong lemony hops aroma. Flavour is very bitter, long lasting. Could be a little bit more balanced.
Bottle.  Light amber and slight orange with a nice white head that last a long time.  Citrus and pine.  Nice balance of bitterness with a clean finish.  A great IPA.

Bottle into glass.  Too cold; will have to try again.  Poured a hazy amber with small white head and little lacing.  Wonderful hop aroma of pine and citrus.  Balance is definitely toward hops.  Enjoyed the light, dry body, so a little less bitterness would be appreciated.  Overall a very refreshing IPA.  One of better IPAs Ive tried.  If they only sold Stone in AR...

Its on tap at the Ale House in Geneva IL.  I love hops so this is a great beer for me.  It has a great hop aroma.  Nice orange color and a thick white head.  A little grapefruit and some floral on the pallet.  Overall its one of my favorite beers.

Slighty hazy amber in the glass with a moderate amount of lacing down the sides.  Strong hoppy aromas dominate the nose with piney, spruce notes.  Flavors on the palate pretty much follow the aromas on the nose with a predominance of hops.  Very enjoyable IPA.

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold, slight orange highlights, a bit lighter in color than I expected. Inch-thick head that doesnt go ANYWHERE. Nose is heavy with pine and boozy citrus. The hops are up front and almost brutal, very bitter, but not in an overpowering way. Just enough of a cloying sweetness from the citrus overtones to cut the assault. Finishes clean, with a slight lingering grapefruit aftertaste. My new favorite standard IPA.
Clear copper of color with a nice white head. An aroma of grass, grapefruit and pines. A flavor of grapefruit, pines, grass and fresh and dry. A very nice IPA

Typical IPA nose of citrusy hops.  Not overpowering but prominent enough that you know youve got an IPA in your hand.   Some malt nose as well.  I wish I could score the aroma higher but there just doesnt seem to be a lot going on in the ol nose.  Amber to dark yellow with off-white head.  Thick lacing. Visually appealing.  Kinda makes you anxious to have that first sip.  Medium mouthfeel and a bit sharp.  Perfect for a IPA!  Ultimately delicious!  Finishes with a quick, bracing bitterness that doesnt last.  Very drinkable and my favorite, everday IPA!

pours out clear gold with a 2 finger thick off white head that was frothy and some what lumpy.  the body is a very clear gold with very few bubbles rising from the center of the glass.  the aromas are nice with a lot of hops and pine in the nose, very balanced smell with some sweet fruit undertones.  it is medium bodied and pretty bitter but also has a balanced sweet undertone on the tongue with bitterness in the back of the palate.  i taste pine, lemon, fresh aromatic hops, and plenty of fresh bittering hops.  finishes crisp and clean with a potent aftertaste that lingers on the palate for some time to come.
POurs orange. Nose is all the usual suspects of a west coast IPA. Pine, citrus, caramel. Flavor is a bitey sharp bitterness, finishes dry.
AMAZING!!! Been eyeing up the Stone IPA at my local beer store and finally bought it. 11.99 a six pack was kinda gross but the taste is well worth it.
bottle.  poured a good foamy white head.  light, golden color.  i got an aroma of honey and floral hops.  get the biterness of the hops in the beginning then sweetness, good clean, refreshing finish

A: Poured with an average-sized, white head, that scored pretty well in the lasting-department. Body is hazy and a light orange color.

S: Excellent aroma. Lots of hops, and lots of citrus... especially orange and lemon. Beautiful.

T: Huge citrus blast at first, then the equally-huge bitterness hits you at the finish. This results in an expected very-long-lasting flavor.

M: Creamy, medium-bodied, average carbonation.

D: Being on the east coast of Canada, Ive probably been lucky to have the few Stone beers that Ive managed to find on trips to the U.S. Beers like this one continue to make me want to try more... three for three so far, Stone! Keep up the excellent work.
Pours out golden with a white head. Strong hops and pine smell. Pretty light mouthfeel with a smooth taste that finishes with a good amount of hops bitterness. Great IPA.
Beautiful pine and citrus hop aroma. Light in color. Great hop flavor, with a little residual sweetness at the end. Hops linger in the mouth. Delicious

Super hop-bomb....watch out!  A lot of bittering hops used in this, but they do seem to mellow a bit as you drink more.  Great PNW hop aroma and flavors, complex...good malt backbone.  Not the cleanest hop flavor in the world, but a really enjoyable beer from a great brewery.

Picked up a bomber of this while I was home in Texas back in August... Nose and mouth exploded with huge citrus, piney hop profile... It was hard to find the malt, but it was there in the background, burried somwhere under all that fresh hops... At the time I found it almost unbearably bitter, but would love to revisit it now that I have a better appreciation for the style.
had 2 pints in Atlantic city. Fresh hoppy floral aroma and taste. High carbonation and vert nice appearance. Overall very good one of my favorite IPAs

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Had many, many times in both bottle and on tap.This is the beer that opened up my world and led me down the path of great beers.  Pours a hazy burnt orange with lots of white head.  Huge citrus and pine aromas - not overly bitter.  Crisp and refreshing.  A go to beer for me and one of the best widely available IPAs around.

A grey market import bottle from beerstore.co.nz, so its not up to its best. But here it is anyway: Pours golden, thin white head. Aroma is sweet, with a hint of piny citrus hop, candyish malt. Bitterness dominates initially, a nice unique hop character, with a balancing caramelly malt.

Light, but floral hop aroma and taste.  Golden/copper color.  A standard IPA.

 Notes: 09 GABF

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 (br-btl gr/wh-paint-lbl, 6 pack & 22oz($3.99))

lct-cpr, thin-lasting-wh-head, med-body, fine(tiny-bubbles)-med-co2, wavy-lace.

aroma:  fresh-citrus-piney-leafy-hops §sweet-malt.

flavor:  §sweet-malt piney-earthy-juicy-hops T1, leafy-citrus-juicy-herbal-^hops sweet-§biscuity-malt T2, short leafy-pine-hop-oil T3, longer-hop-§bitterness Tf(for the 22oz).

dry and aroma hoping is obvious, but main hop profile seems to come from early/bittering additions.
super-hoppy but not-really-bitter.
^drinkable, great-clean-fresh-hops.
its the very noticeable sweet biscuity malt backbone along with the fresh juicy (not bitter) hop character that makes this so good.

Bottle, Pours a hazy amber with soft effervescent head. Lots of bubbles causes nice lacing. Aroma, Soft hops citrus and spruce. Taste, is mild with pine and spruce and grapefruit aftertaste - some bitterness with dry finish. The hop flavor lingers but never produces the tongue tingle. Its a solid beer but not great
Clear golden  pour with a frothy white head and thick lacing. Appealing floral scent. Rather bitter. Solid IPA.

Pours a clear, light orange color.  Very effervescent and transparent.  Pleasant, yet mild aroma.  Floral on the nose.  Hoppy taste that takes a little time bubbling on the palate to develop, and leaves a nice lingering bitterness.  Nicely balanced, all in all pretty darned good.

Pours a crystal clear straw yellow scarily like macro swill. Smallish snow white head clings and leaves massive lacing. Honestly, looks like Miller Lite. Even my wife said "I thought you dont drink that cheap stuff." Nose dominate by citrus and malt. Classic one dimensional IPA aroma. Crisp flavor of grapefruit. Strong bitterness at the finish. Lively mouth feel. High carbonation level is just right for the style. A pretty decent IPA. Ugly as hell, but still very tasty.

One of the Best!  Great aroma, solid dark brown Color, great initial taste, along with fantastic aftertaste of bitter hops.  One of my top 5, i just with Ruination wasnt so expensive of I would buy THAT all the time.
A bit bitter. My wife thought it was sweet. It was kind of bland. Sour aftertaste. Meh.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2011 Excellent IPA.  I have to place it close behind 90 Minute (Dogfish Head).  Love the bitters, love the aroma.  For me it loses to 90 Minute on palate and finish.  I think the higher alcohol content gives 90 Minute the fullness on the palate that the thinner Stone IPA just cant do.  But the higher carbonation of the Stone IPA gives adds a touch to keep it close.

Surprised I hadnt rated this before. This rating is from two draft pints at some L.A. restaurant. Nice fresh hop aroma, a little grassy in a nice way. Fruity. Something about the character of the hops, reminiscent of SNPA, that I dont like, well, I like it, but its not my favorite hop profile, flavor wise. Slightly too high carbonation.

I really liked this beer and it had a very complex blend of bitterness and hops that it was an excellent choice for anyone that is wanting to taste a very good IPA and get into beer tasting and rating

Pours from bottle clear pale yellow-orange, with a nice bubbly head.  Very nice earthy hop aroma, not to overpowering.   Smooth, hoppy, and a nice bitter bite.  Finishes leaves a watering mouth.  Very balance beer, malt and hop, hop and malt, this is a very nice IPA.

Growler. Super-solid IPA. Pours a nice, light orange-gold with a fine white head. Heavy aroma of bitter hops, noting pine and citrus. Flavor is a hop roller coaster: exciting and exhilarating. (None of the experience made me want to hurl, mind you.) Very mild hints of malt. Alcohol is almost undetectable. Bitter, crisp, lip-smacking finish with lingering hops on the tongue. Really, really good.
Drank from bottle at a Christmas party.  Nice IPA with a little citrusy sweetness, hints of spices, and a nice hoppy bitterness.  Well balanced and enjoyable.

A: Pours a nice golden yellow color with a head that looks like whipped egg whites. There are a few bubbles racing too the top, and some beautiful lacing left behind. 

S: This one has a nice big aroma. I poured it into my De Verboden Vrucht chalice which let the aroma waft into the air. There is a wonderful citrus aroma here. I smell grapefruit, limes, and lemon, with an underlying touch of pine. 

T: I love every Stone beer I have ever tried and this one is no exception. It starts out with a splash of citrus and the bite of some of the earths most wonderful hops. It finishes with a nice sweetness as it runs down my throat. 

M: Medium bodied with a nice bite from the hops.
Tap. Golden orange with slightly off white head. Aromas of pine and grapefruit. Flavors of caramel, pine, and grapefruit. Soft mouthfeel. The benchmark IPA.
floral hops along with a great malt foundation. a prime example of a west coast ipa. an old stand-by.
One of the best IPAs I know of.  Wonderful from start to finish. Its not overly hoppy like some IPAs tend to be but it doesnt fall flat either.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a mostly clear gold with a medium off-white head that leaves a lot of lacing behind.  Hoppy aroma, with notes of caramel, grapefruit citrus, malt, pine, floral notes.  Bitter, hoppy flavor, with notes of pine, soap, grapefruit, caramel malts.  Light bodied, and bitter hops characterize it.  Moderate carbonation.  Dry, bitter finish.  I had higher expectations for this one, which is still very good, but a little one-note.

Wow... I have heard that this was a good one and its true. Poured great leaving a nice head that didnt disappear two sips in. Had a wonderfully hoppie aroma and taste that was very satisfying but not overpowering. Good to the last drop, thank goodness that I has 5 more. This is a road that will be traveled again... soon!

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 ྫྷ ounce bottle - pint glass)  Golden dark yellow color,  light head that leads to a light lacing.  Awsome grapefruit hoppy aroma which any hophead will love.  Taste is hoppy with a light malt that is only there to give it balance.  The hops are grassy, floral and citrusy.  Has a somewhat lively carbonation.  Hoppy aftertaste so you know you just drank a beer.  If  you are a hop head you should try this beer.
Crisp with a definite cereal taste.  Hops have only a medium bite .  color is dark yellow. The flavors do not linger much on the tongue.  A starter Stone beer for sure.

Bottle. After drinking this beer I came to the conclusion, I love hops. This is quite a statement for one who loves malty, dark beers. This has to be a favorite of anyone who loves hops. It has a floral aroma. Taste wonderful with a great flowery taste with a bitter "bite" of an after taste. Good stuff.

Well I had my first Stone beer last night, and it was the India Pale Ale. All I can say is: WOW, this thing is hoppy! Ridiculously hoppy is an understatement. Now Im not saying this in a bad way. It is definitely something different, but very enjoyable.

Poured into a standard pint glass.  Thick frothy head that released the aromas of fruity, citrus notes with a definite alcohol character.  Bitter, dry finish with the citrus notes still on the tongue.  Good beer

Pours light orange with an enormous white, frothy head. Looks incredible. You can smell the alcohol through the aromas of citrus. The flavor is heavier on citrus than hops to me. Very dry, alcoholic, and bitter on the finish.

12oz bottle.  Nice clear bright golden with a good head. Hot hop pine aroma. Palate is all hot, pepper hops. Lacks some malt sweetness and weight to give it balance. Drinkable enough but Im not seeing what all the fanfare and hype is all about...

Remarks
12 oz. Bottle.
Mild lacy head.Clear bright rich gold color.Rich hop front.Dry sweet citrus caramel crisp Pils malt body.Clean rich tangy hop spice end.Hoppy clean balanced mild sweet IPA.
Bottle from Tiffanys, Kalamazoo. Copper colour, off-white head. Aroma of pine hops, grapefruit. Flavour of pine hops, grapefruit and citrus, with some malts. Fairly bitter and very dry. Good stuff.

Bottle. Poured amber with a white head that laced nicely. Aroma was a nice combination of grapefruit and earthy notes. The flavor had the same notes with the earthy notes taking more of a dominate position.

Bottle. Pour is lighter than most of its ilk, nice carbonation bubbles and small white head. Nose is grapefruit and a little straw and earthiness. Flavor is all grapefruit  bitterness. Certainly a beer for hopheads (in which I would include myself), and well-made, but I find it really one-dimensional and not very interesting.
12 oz bottle from Johns - Beautiful copper color with a nice 1/2" creamy head.  Tastes as good at it looks.  This is what an IPA should be.

Brown bottle, 1 pint, 6 ounces, gift from Viviana Martinez, savoured on November 21 2009; eye: amber, clear, minimal effervescence, tiny ring of white head, no lacing; nose: resinous hops, hops, hops, grapefruit, dryness, pine; mouth: resinous hops, astringency, pine, grapefruit, dry finale in resinous hops with presence of grapefruit, medium-full body, good carbonation, rather bitter, nice astringency, lightly harsh texture; overall: quite likable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte, 6 onces, cadeau de Viviana Martinez, savourée le 21 novembre 2009; il : ambrée, claire, effervescence minime, petit anneau de mousse blanche, pas de dentelle; nez : houblon résineux, houblon, houblon, pamplemousse, sèche, pin; bouche : houblon résineux, astringence, pin, pamplemousse, finale sèche en houblon résineux avec présence de pamplemousse, corps moyen-corsé, bonne carbonatation, plutôt amère, bonne astringence, texture légèrement rugueuse; en résumé : bien aimé

Incredibly smooth, I could easily drink two six packs and not blink an eye. One of my favorite beers, great on tap and by bottle. Bitter flavor and slight citrus finish. Great floral aroma. As it says on the bottle, this beer is liquid poetry. Try this beer!

Discount Liquor Milwaukee, WI. $9.49 6-pk. 11/09. As soon as you open the bottle you can smell the hops! Lemon aroma, very fresh, dry hopped. Perfectly balanced, a great malt backbone. This may be the best IPA I have ever tasted.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2010 Pours orange with a white head.  Aroma is lots of american hops, evergreen and citrus with some grass and earth notes.  Flavor is similar with more citrus and resin and a bit less grass and earth than I got on the aroma.  Has a rather sweet and brown sugary malt body, stops just short of being too sweet for my IPA tastes.  This is a reliable IPA with a lovely hop profile that Im glad I can get almost anywhere.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2013 4th June 2008. Easy drinking IPA. Nice fruity hops with a medium level of bitterness. Lighter palate than a lot of IPAs. 3.413th April 2013A much fresher bottle. Hazy amber beer. tidy white head. Palate is light and crisp and dry. Thin creamy malt with mild caramel. Good piney hops, rich and bitter. Lesser citrus and whisper of skunk. Dry minerally finish with some fresh hop sting. Tasty IPA but a bit dry.

Pours a murky light tinged yellow producing a thick white cloud of heaven above. Aromas enlighten the nose tantalizing with citrusy fruit, caramel, pines, and some floral.  Once it hits the tongue it leaves its mark with ample citrus, with a splash of pine. Almost like biting into some unknown fruit. Caramel peeks it self through down the line. Whilst the sip end, the bitter end doesnt, just waiting for the next one.

Pours pale golden with monster head.  Nice retention and great lacing.  Nose is predictable... Citrus, pine, resin and dry hay.  Flavor is pleasant.  Orange peel,  vegetable greens and roasty wood finish.   Thin on the palate.  Solid ipa,  but not the revelation I was expecting
650 ml Bottle: Big head, strong hoppy aroma, bitter taste. I love amercian style IPA and Stone Brewing has to be one of the best.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2009 From bottle to pint glass.  pungent hoppy aroma. Nice golden appearance. Hints of grapefruit. A solid IPA

Bottle from Cavie.  "Why hello, dry hop.  You seem to have overrun my aroma."  A little lemon aroma as well.  Taste is hoppy, but not as much as the aroma.  Very citrusy.  Lots of side tingle on the tongue.

This is a very solid, hoppy IPA. Generous hops on the aroma and in the flavor. Notes of pine and citrus in the aroma. The flavor and finish are also quite bitter and floral and not too sweet, with at most medium carbonation. I like the Ruination IPA more, but this is a good IPA.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2011 Light orange color. Both Fratto and I in tandum: "Why hello hops!" explains the aroma. Tastes of hops as well that dont disappoint. Finish isnt bad. 3.7
RE-RATE 6/6/11 Bottle from Central Market.   This beer pours a clear copper orange color with a fizzy off-white head.  Little carbonation beyond what forms the head.

Now to the aroma; MAN is this thing intense.  I smell tons and tons of drippy, wet hops in this.  Lots of pine needles, fresh tree sap, grapefruit and tart citrus, man this smells great.  I almost dont want to drink it; I just want to keep on smelling it!

Well eventually I did take a sip and it was just as tasty as the smell made it out to be.  Lots of sweet hops with a big bitterness imparted over the palate.  This is very warming, and the Christmas tree flavor never leaves!  Andwatermelon?  I kid you not, try it and see.  This is an intense IPA for sure.

Bouteille de 12 oz. Arômes intenses et invitants de houblon américain (fruits tropicaux et résine). Robe dorée et claire, effervescence moyenne et légère mousse. Il sagit dune IPA qui met le houblon à lavant-plan, avec une très belle présence aromatique (fruits tropicaux, résine). Le malt, très net, est juste assez présent pour soutenir le houblon. Finale bien amère. Une très bonne IPA de la côte ouest.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Slightly hazy burnt yellow with foamy head and pretty strong lacing.

Aroma of pine and citrus, slightly sweet toasted malts.

Fantastic hop taste - mostly pine, citrus and some grapefruit. Some mostly dry malts to counterbalance the hop explosion, but not too much. Persistent bitterness at end.

Very smooth and very dry. Medium body and moderate carbonation.

For being so hop-centric and bitter, this is unbelievably easy to drink.

This has now become one of my top IPAs, along with Celebration and Two-Hearted.

12 oz. bottle- Pours clear golden with a pillow on top, aroma is of citrus  and hops. The flavor is mellow, drinkable, and damn right enjoyable, you dirty bastard. Sorry, i apologize, the arrogant bastard in me got out, you stupid jackasses.

12-oz bottle Marcellos, Lafayette, LA - aroma: floral, burnt, pine, grapefruit (hops); flavor: slight sweet, salty (malt), bitter , citrus, grapefruit (hop); appearance: hazy yellow off white head, some lacings; mouthfeel: medium to heavy bodied, moderate carbonation; overall: nice
UPDATED: APR 27, 2010 Poured a golden yellow with a nice effervescent head.  Taste of Grapefruit hops dominated throughout. Finished surprisingly smooth. Delicious IPA.

Yellow colored with cloudy appearance. Medium sized white head. Rich aroma with nice pine and grass, some flowers and grape also come up. Medium bodied. Flavor is also strongly piny with lemon also dominating, nice fruits with some pineapple also here. Aftertaste lasts with bitter hops.

Foamy white head over a cloudy orange beer. Brilliant hop bouquet. Cascade citrus, spicyness, grapefruit some floral notes as well as earthiness. Intense bitter bite, just enough malt to balance. Grapefruit starts to come through. Medium to light body. This is the IPA pushed as far as it can go without having to up the malt/body. Very, very good.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 Medium golden/ochre murky pour with a long lasting creamy white head. Excellent lacing. Aroma is very hoppy, grapefruit, perfume and flowers, but also caramel malt, prune, dates and alcohol. Flavor matches the aroma. It starts off lightly sweet and moderately bitter, but quickly becomes bitter in a heavy way - lasting and lasting with a an alcoholic sting in there as well. Well balanced. Medium to full bodied, syrupy with soft carbonation. Smooth to drink. A delight even though it was served too cold. Nice perfumed after taste.

(Bottled) Poured orange and hazy. Head was medium sized and white. The aroma was strongly hoppy and also fruity. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. The dominant component in the taste was hop flavour. In addtion to that there were malts, fruitiness, pine and bitternes. Hoppiness continued in the long lasting aftertaste. Really good IPA. I had this later from tap but I didnt rerate it.

On tap at The Barley Oak, Mandeville La.  Light amber color with a medium sized but persistent head.  Floral aroma.  A great one for the hop heads (like me).  Very hoppy, bitter, yet clean and crisp.  Hoppy finish.
strong aroma of fresh whole-leaf hop, medium body, flavor is grapefruity maybe with a little melon, very hoppy, bitter finish. very nice

Bottle. Pale and diaphanous like a spiced blond with an uneven, tufting whip of suds; some serious thick Belgian condition pushing a perfect 5 for looks and feel...Aroma immediately greener and leafier than the Mikkeller JB Ive just seen off; tomato leaf on the pop, becoming piney, lemon sherbet and tangerine-accented. Buttery sweet malt and a good wring of green like BrewDogs paler efforts, especially The Punk; resins, pine, pollen, mellow lemon sherbet and soapy hop with a hint of orange zest; vanilla and cheesecake base malt, a little alcohol harshness (fair game at 6.9%); tweak of lime in the afters and some fantastic green hop on the burp. Raspy bitterness, balanced. If this was a quid a bottle in Tesco, Id be downing it like The Dog. Give it 12 months. Quality.

Bitterness that mashes your tastebuds into a sort of shock, this IPA ropes up big bold flavors and top tier hoppiness. Rich and effortlessly bombastic as the Stone company itself, this ale is hearty, rich and refuses to pull any punches.

22oz bottle.  Poured a clear golden ambe with a two finger, foamy eggshell white head.  A huge piney and citrus HOP aroma.  The taste has a brief sweet malt presence that is quickly smashed by the big floral hop flavor.  It finishes with a nice bitterness and a citrus kick.  A great IPA.

Bottle. Poured a hazy orange color with an off white head that went quick. Aroma was citrus hops and floral hops. Flavor was a lot of hops. Very well balanced though. A sweeter ipa. Very good. Love this IPA.

1 pint 6 oz. Bottle. Pours Golden/Amber; head is thick and foamy. Citrus hops dominate the aroma with flavors of lemon and orange. A sensation...more citrus flavors with the swallow; lemons dominate...somewhat sweet, lightly bitter...an everyday beer with a top notch taste. A classic...
One of the best IPAs ive had! Very flavorful, great aroma! Appearance was a little lacking, but overall one of my favorites!
Lovely flavor.  Major hops with grapefruit and some pine.  Medium yellow amber color with medium white head.  Right up there with two hearted and furious.  I love a great IPA.

Bottle. An ordinary hazy golden color with a medium sized, lasting, off white head. Strong grapefruit and hops in the aroma. Notice first... sweet... like brown sugar then a nice easy transition to hops and a restrained grapefruit bitterness. For a special occasion I would prefer this over a Sierra Nevada.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2011 Aroma is sweet, bread, caramel, floral hops.  The appearance was true to the style.  The flavor is floral hops, caramel, bread,  very good.  The finish was again floral hops,perfume,  lingering sweetness.  Medium in body, strong carbonation.  Excellent IPA, straddles the border of an IIPA.

Bottle.  Creamy light orange color with 1.5 finger white head that stays.  Lacing.  Aroma of sweet, flowery hops.  Flavor had citrus and caramel notes along with a ton of hops.  Palate was creamy and light with a dry finish.  I was looking forward to this and it did not disappoint.  Killer logo too!
12 oz bottle.  Smells of apricot, citrus, pine.  Amber-gold color.  Not much head or lacing.  Nice bitterness.  Tastes of fruit, pine.  Low on the carbonation end.  Very nice IPA.
BOTTLE: gold pour, nice white head with good lacing. Grapefruit and pine hop aroma, taste is sweet, medium creamy mouthfeel, and lots of hops. Pretty good.

Bottle. Always a good time to be had with Stone. These guys are all about hops and IBUs and they arent afraid to tell you all about it. The smell, taste, after-taste: Hops, hops, hops. Anyone who likes their beer especially bitter should upgrade to the Arrogant Bastard or, if you need even MORE hops, the double Bastard. These guys make a mean thirst quencher

This is my goto sessions IPA beer. Stone has truely got a great IPA. Almost the epitomy of a west coast IPA. Nothing that well jump out and scream HOPS! but enuff there not to over power you and let you enjoy the other flavors that are going on with this beer

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 Bottle. Gold pour with ivory white head. Aroma is heavy pine, a whole coniferous forests worth. Some sweetness too slightly citrusy or some pineapple. Taste is definately piney and grapefruit with an extra bitter finish. Good sparkling mouthfeel with a bitter dry taste.
A great IPA. One of my favorites. Great hoppy flavor, but sweet . Has a nice thick feel, but is light and very drinkable. Just a good beer
I love this beer.  Starting with the rush of grapefruit hop smell to the bitter taste that finishes into a sweet malt.  Ive never had a Stone I didnt like.

Its hop-tastic.  If Blatz made an IPA this would be it.  Full of wondrous hop aromas, and more bitter than your wife (or ex-wife).  After you quaff a Bakers dozen of Vals Finest (Blatz or Blatz Light) you may slam one of these hop-bombs down, screaming, "Blatz is a genius" while trying to light your genitalia on fire (or not).  Good stuff.  and if you place some of these in front of your cache of Blatz, the in-laws will be fooled into thinking you are all out of the good stuff.  Have a Stone IPA, then get tore up on Blatz....thats how I roll.

Bottle. Ive had a long journey in a relatively short time since I first had a Stone IPA, probably not as long ago as I would guess. When I wasnt seeking out hoppy beers on a regular basis, I used to say it smelled to me like new carpet. At this point I dont even really detect that any more. Just a fruity orange refreshing aroma, piney and musty sure, but no rugs. For me the Stone is still a little underbalanced, slightly thin and unrepentantly bitter. I like more malt, but I still like this beer.

Appearance: Yellow orange.
Aroma: Intense fresh, West Coast floral and citrus hop and malt.
Flavor: Orange malt and citrus & floral hops launch a simultaneous assault.  Some earthy flavors appear on the mid-palate and carry on into the finish.
Comment: Yep, this delivers.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 (small bottle) When I reside in Cali im sure ill have this as a go to beer.  A rabbit on crack hopping all over your tounge....grassy ..waxy ,with light sticky sweetness.  Quality all day & night.
Draught at Q-Brick. Big dry citrus hop aroma. Fruity, citrus, ok malt sweetness. Big bitter finish. Great balance, very drinkable. Good quaffing IPA with no faults.

almost clear orange straw, fizzy white head.
bursting sweet and fresh grassy aroma, with pineapple and maple syrup, and some soap.
similar super-bright fruity flavor with stinging bitterness and not-quite-balancing sweetness in the front. finish is long and quite bitter.
i dont know, this seems somewhat too bitter, and not really balanced.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a slightly hazy orange, with a tall, frothy, rich snowy white head. Aroma of fresh dry hops, lemon zest, grapefruit, oranges, and herbal/grassy notes. Intensely full body, especially for an IPA, with a tangy, moderately funky palate. Crisp, bitter, ever-so-slightly dry finish. Excellent IPA from Stone. Definitely one of the best Ive ever tasted, and an easy sessioner. Try this brew if you are having trouble appreciating IPAs.

Aroma, pure hops. loving it! Bitter hop, alcohol, some fennel and slightly nutty in the aftertaste but fantastic warmth comes through at the end.
Sticks on the palate for a great while afterward.
Awesome beer.

Copper orange in color. Aroma of pine and all-purpose cleaner. Vinegar, peach, banana, and pineapple with a flowery, over-hopped finish. I like this one, but Ive always found it lacking a certain caramel balance.

bottle, pours light gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is very fresh smelling, almost like when I homebrew.  Flavor is nice and balanced, good malt richness and sweet flavors with bitter and citrus flavors from the hops.  Highly drinkable.

bottle: tulip: this pours a cloudy amber, leaving a dry head about 1 finger. Smells gloriously hoppy and crisp. The taste is super crisp, clean bitters, some esters maybe some young sugars.  I sip, I rest, I think... this is the famous Stone IPA?!  Dont get me wrong, the hops are delicious, there is some great depth... but I expected more complexity.  Then I read the bottle: "Ingredients: Nothing but Barley, Hops, Water & Yeast."  Then it hits my like lightning... the mulititude of flavors came from so few ingredients?!  Thats why these guys are so damn good, and why this is such a kick ass beer.
Poured golden with a little while head, amazing fruity smell went up my nose before my lips hit the glass, citrus hops definitely present, tasty brew.
very mild citrus aroma. Nice golden honey colour with lot cream coloured head and lacing. Nice citrus hop flavour with an almost mild nutty after taste. A really nicely brewed beer! Its a good one!

Beautiful golden colour with a fluffy white head. Aroma of freshly cut grapefruit with sugar sprinkled on it. Perfectly balanced - crisp malt sweetness up front, cut through nicely with a cleansing bitterness. Great beer.
Bottle poured brown IPA with a average off white head.  A taste of hay but integrated into ale with the hops adding the correct level of bitterness.

Pours a pretty golden/copper color with a white head. The aroma is great and overwhelmingly full of hops. The aroma dominates on the first few sips adding depth of flavor. Great finish thats full of hops as well.

I remember this beer getting a lot of fuss at one time, so Ive finally had the chance to have one and now I may understand why.  All hops. This beer is loaded with tongue burning hops.  Probably led the way for todays IPAs and made it cool to love hops.  I guess a good thing for hop heads and hop recognition.  Not my favorite but good for the hop industry from a historical sense.  Not quite sure how to rate it, but I can apprecatie it for what it is.

Bottle (in NZ). Pours a hazy light gold. Beautiful fruity hop nose with just the right amount of toffee malt for balance. I could just sniff this beer! But it tastes pretty good too. Plenty of those fruity hops again with the perfect amount of bitterness on the palate. Citrus and stoned fruits jostle on the taste buds, along with a touch of vanilla. The finish is moreishly dry. This is an IPA good enough to punch in the IIPA division.
Cloudy dark apple cider color with generous carbonation.  Subdued hoppy aroma.  Great, somewhat  bubbly mouthfeel.  Nice consistency.
Top notch all around. Body was  a little lighter than some IPAs  and a bit more grassy than most.

Bottle - Amber/golden in colour. Fresh and hoppy aroma with strong notes of grapefruit, peach and pine. Hoppy and bitter taste with tangy grapefruit, peach and a faint hint of aniseed.  The finish is nice and hoppy, but not overwhelmingly so.

Double dry hopped version on firkin at Brouwers hopfest.  Pours a deep cloudy golden color with a very loose looking white head.  Slightly sweet and piney nose with some citrus notes.  Very well rounded and nice smelling.  Body is a bit thin and watery, but I suppose that is to be expected given it was a firkin.  The flavor just really lets the nose down...just not as much going on.  Nice bittering from the dry hopping though.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2009 Looks tanned gold and slightly cloudy. Aroma of pine and bread and grapefruit. Flavour has strawberries (!?), lemon, grapefruit, and a tasty dose of hop bitterness. There is some dryness in the aftertaste. Medium to heavy body. The bitterness fills my palate (as it should), but is restrained enough to retain guzzlability. Where did my pint go?
Bottle. A very good IPA I thought. Darkish gold with a thin white head. Obviously hoppy. Grapefruit, nice bitterness. Refreshing and one I would definitely drink again. Im liking Stones work.
12oz bottles. Pours a slight cloudy yellow colour. A nice hop punch to it, quite tasty and smooth. Doesnt live up to the hype though. Have had better IPAs, but its still damn good.
Poured light amber, nose is all floral hops, very pleasant aroma. Flavor was more floral hops, the malts I thought were nicely blended.  Very nice IPA.  Will definitely have this again.
awesome ipa!! could put this stuff on i.v..very hoppy bite but not to the point of turpentine.one of the cleanest tasteing ipa iv ever had.

as expected, a winner in every way.....floral citrus and pine on the nose with an oily hop coating and faint malt.  just the right amount of carbonation to be very refreshing. very nice long hoppy finish. Stone never lets me down!
8/22/09 Double Dry Hopped draft version. Nose is fresh hops, period. Piney. Taste is spot on perfect I.P.A. Oily & sticky. I mean the hop oils really coat your tongue. Its special.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2011 Had this bad boy while visiting Hollywood... picked it up from a random pharmacy.  A great and solid IPA, as we have come to expect from Stone. Re-rate 6/5/11. On tap. Slightly cloudy orange pour with a small, creamy tan head. Mild piney, almost sour, aroma that is nice but not super complex. Almost sweet flavor with some pineapple hints, pine, straight up hop bitterness, and some more. Not bad!

Hazy orange color with white head.  Sweet smelling grapefruit and pine aroma.  Has a bitter flavor and dry texture with a long hop finish.  Im surprised how smooth it is, considering the ABV and IBUs.

22oz bomber from The Lighthouse in Manchester, Maine. Pours a hazy yellow-amber with a thin film of off-white head that leaves some lace. Smells amazing - orange, grapefruit etc hops dominate for sure with just the slightest hint of malt. Bright citrussy hops dominate the flavor - orange, grapfruit, and slight pith. Slight caramel and biscuit malt help to make the hops not overpowering. Nonetheless, hops dominate and create perhaps one of the finest hop flavors in any beer Ive ever had. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. An easier drinker than expected, considering the ABV and big flavor. Perhaps one of the finest IPAs I have ever had. Phenomenal in almost every way.

Bomber.  Hazy gold with a nice thick small white head. Nose of citrusy hops with some lingerng sweetness. Taste is a nice hop profile, quite bitter but with little malt balance. The true hop bomb. Drinkable but one dimensional.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: This one has seen better days. Not bad, but much better on the other side of the Pacific. Id imagine.
Lemon and grapefruit aroma of medium strength. Cloudy amber, medium yellow head, nice lace. Grapefruit rind and lemon flavor. Medium body, well bittered.
Bottle.  A good, clean crisp IPA.  Very well balanced and easy to drink.  One of my favorites...

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 11/08/2009. 12oz. Beerstore.co.nz. Stewed jelly-like barley malt, good hop bitterness but the hop flavour and aroma is muddied behind the oxidised malt.  I can see this is a great beer on the way out.  Certainly still drinkable, enjoyable even, but the tide is hop tide is way out.

I really enjoyed this stone brew, but I enjoy every stone brew... so that isnt big news. Over all it is a very smooth easy to drink IPA with a lot of good hoppy flavor. Definitely bitter but in a good way. 

I enjoyed a 22oz bottle all to myself and after the pour the beer looked delicious with a great head and color.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2009 (22oz bomber) Pours a medium yellow with glimpses of orange and a nice 2 finger head. The lacing coats the glass well. Nose has a great honey aroma, juicy pineapple and other citrus fruits.  Smells sweeter than most IPAs which for me is good. Taste is a little too bitter on the front and finish, but the body and carbonation are just right. Those grapefruit and honey esters hit you up front, but the honey fades faster than the bitter hops unfortunately.

Cask at the White Horses American Beer Festival 2009. What a perfect beer for the summer weather. As I sat in the sun I found the floral, pine and hops aroma thoroughly refreshing. Absolutely full of those classic IPA flavours: citrus, pine and a lasting bitter finish. Wonderful.

Pours a light amber, a tinge hazy, thick foamy head, great retention, great lace. Nose is hops and citrus. Taste slapped my tongue with hops and citrus, extremely balanced, finishes a tad dry and deliciously bitter. Long lasting hop taste in my mouth after sipping. A benchmark in IPAs, always good, refreshing.

Bottle from Realale.com. Golden in colour with a big white head and slight carbonation. Sharp, grapefruit and pine aroma with some balancing malt. Flavour had some sweet, butterscotch malt, some citrus and resin hops and a decent dry finish. Very good.

On Tap at BJs GPM. Pours murky, pale orange. Nose is fresh hops, citrus, very inviting. Taste didnt follow the nose as I had wished, very dry and tasted slightly overcarbed. May have been an old barrel, not sure. Even at that, I enjoyed my glass. Finish is dry bitter, rough. Need to try a fresh batch.

Bottle pours hazy light amber color with thick foamy off white head.  Aroma smells like I just crushed fresh hops into my glass.  Literally.  Like I took a hop from one of my hop vines, crushed it, and put it into the glass.  Opulent mouthfeel.  Taste is resinous hops, is sticky in my mouth hops, has a nice malt backbone, then finishes semi-dry.  Wonderful.  Just wonderful.

Pours a slightly hazy orange.  Gorgeous moderate pillowy white head with very good retention and lacing.  Great hoppy aroma of pine and hint of citrus.  Flavor is dominated by grassy bittering hops, with some floral, peach and pine notes as it fills your mouth.  Medium mouthfeel with just the right amount of bitter bite in the finish.  Excellent.

Pours hazy light gold, with a medium, pillowy head. Crisp citrus hops right off the bat, and enough of them to make the aroma resemble most DIPAs, some pepper, and some butterscotch-like malt to counter. This is a great all-around IPA - very crisp flavor, nice balance (while remaining hop-forward like an IPA should), and while the hops are a little stale / uninteresting, this remains a refreshing brew, and a great example of the style.
beautiful golden pour with a nice size, white head...nose and flavor full of hops...lingering aftertaste...very nice
Bottled and draft. A very light amber. Bitter beer with a slight floral arrangement. #2 IPA in my book - right behind Two Hearted.

Poured from the 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is yellowish gold color, with a foamy white head.

The smell is quite hoppy. A bit piny and floral.

The taste is sweet with a blend of citric hops, floral hops, and some peppery feel to it as well.

I have heard many good things about Stone brewery and the IPA that they brew. I have yet to be misled by BA reviews in the past so I picked this up and gave it a try.

One of the best IPAs that I have ever tried, hell, one of the best beers Ive ever tried. A great spicey hop taste that is just what you would expect from a good IPA but is also quite drinkable.

Gotta love a piney smelling ipa .... Pours an orange hazy gold with white head awesome citrus piney aroma and a great hoppy taste through and through finishes dry with a lasting aftertaste very clean beer excellent ipa

EASILY my favorite IPA.  Cant get enough of the citrus and grapefruit hops.  Lip puckering, yet refreshing.

Give mre more.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2010 White head, golden/orange in color.  Prominent smell besides the wonderful hops was pine.  Very refreshing major hops taste with a beautifully smooth finish.

Aroma is noticeably full of those Pacific North Western hop varieties, no grapefruit citrus present.  The flavor is a great balance of strong hops and malts, no citrus to speak of.  Appearance is a bit boring and bland.  the head is nil, with barely a thin white collar and a coppery color.  The palate is a superb balance, with a lingering bitter aftertaste nice hop-malt.
I like this beer alot....a fine representation of the WC IPA...Ive had better, but Ive had many, many worse...I still prefer Ruination.........................................

UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 On draught at RnH (NYC): Amazing IPA.  Hops, yeast, grapefruit, dry malts... the works. Really crisp and refreshing for an IPA- which is outstanding. One good beer. #084 on 25072009, DG.

Bottle pours gold with bronze highlights and a soapy white head, leaving decent lacing.  The nose is primarily grapefruit, pine, and other misc. citrus. Flavor is basically the same with some bitter peach and apricot notes. Overall mouthfeel is moderate/light with a sticky, lasting finish.  This beer is pretty much one of my default bar beers, due to availability and consistency.  Bravo stone, as usual.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Gillys, 7/23/09


Aroma: Huge citrus hop nose, grapefruit, orange, apricot

Appearance: Cloudy gold, thin white head, light lacing

Flavor: Nice hop flavor with some dry malts

Palate: Really easy to drink for a beer of this size, I can go through a lot of these, refreshing and enjoyable, still has a decent amount of body and a nice mouthfeel

Overall Impression: 
I went to move my rating of this beer onto RateBeer a few weeks back, but since I hadnt had it in sometime, I decided it best to pick up a fresh one.  This is really good.  Along with the Arrogant Bastard, this was one of my first beer loves, thanks to Stone for showing me the craft beer movement.
Tap. Stone made a great IPA here,  its quite run of the mill compared to some of the great stuff that stone makes, but definitely a solid beer here.

Wow, I get the 2000th rating of this beer, and just above my friend Joe.  I have had this countless times on draft, cask, and in bottles.  This rating based on a growler fill from the brewery.  Pours a somewhat light golden amber color with a decent white head.  Mild hop aroma (mostly floral, but also a bit of citrus and pine) is a bit weaker than most California IPAs.  Also aroma of brewed black tea and a distinct grainy-ness that it not altogether good.  Flavor is decidedly better as the hops kick in more (bitter citrus and pine) with a decent malt backbone.  I think the bottled version may be better.  Have I just gotten overly used to this?  Its good, but when it comes to local IPAs here in San Diego, I much prefer the Alesmith.

Growler fill of double dry hopped IPA at Stone Brewing the day of the Sour Fest. Pours a clear golden color with tiny head. Aroma of fresh floral hops. Taste is light and refreshing with very good balance of hop heaven. Palate is medium carbonation with nice aftertaste. Very very good and fresh.

Aroma- Slight floral and lemon-like citrus aroma.  Low biscuit aroma.
Appearance- Yellow, good clarity, white head with great retention.
Taste- Floral/citric taste, same as aroma, and it is strong.  High bitterness.  Low malt flavor.
Palate- easy drinking, light in body, smooth.
Overall- Nice, easy drinking IPA with not a lot of malt balance.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2009 Does not have the balls of Ruination but in some ways is better....more drinkable being one. The hop lover will be pleased, the non hop fan will enjoy as well unlike the Ruination

A clear amber pour with a nice white head and good lacing. Grapefruit aroma with malt sweetness. Flavor is citrus hops, pine hops, and a fair amount of malt balance. Not as in your face as Ruination but quite good.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Beautiful golden brew with tons of lacing.  Hoppy with a dry bitter ending.   Not overly carbonated making it easy to have a few of these in an evening.  Not my favorite IPA but one of the better ones.

Clear amber, nice head and lace.  Citrussy, grapefruit hoppy aroma with obvious malt.  Starts with mellow but noticeable citrus bite, develops quickly into piney, grapefruit hop taste, then finishes with grassy and citrussy hop bite.  Wonderful hoppy experience.

Excellent IPA. Golden hued pour with off-white foam head. Great citrus/pine hop and floral hop aroma. First taste and you know what youre in for. Dominated by bittersweet hoppiness and a long, surprisingly smooth, hoppy finish. Notes of spices and fruits detail the body. Better than Dogfish 60. Its only problem is the price tag for a 6-pack.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2015 12 oz. bottle from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons); bottle date says "enjoy by 09/23/15." Aroma: A near balance of moderately sweet cereal and grapefruit hop character; a little pine and nectarine in the background. Appearance: Pours a light copper with a foamy white head that settles into a sticky white cap; the carbonation is slow and mesmerizing in the glass. Flavor: Sweet cereal and citrus balanced up front; more pine/stone fruit shows up towards the finish, which is bittersweet. Palate: Full body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish. Overall: One that is showing its age for me. Granted, I have to wonder how much different a fresher keg/bottle would be.

This is a superb IPA with as much complexity and strength as many doubles; yet it still amazingly achieves a subdued balance (unlike Ruination).
