Out of bottle this golden-amber ale has light opacity and a frothy off-white head. Smell is hop-dominated with a sweet blossom and light citrus character. After several sips one can identify oranges, tangerines, light caramel malt, subtle orange zest, guava, sweet floral undertones and a hoppy finish. Body is shockingly light ad crisp. What this beer achieves in hop-flavor without excessive bitterness is inspiring.

Well, since its been a while and Ive sampled many offerings since I wanted to re-review my favorite beer, Stone IPA. Text and stats on the original review follows. Long story short...its still right up there...

12 oz. into Duvel tulip...

2+ finger butter/eggshell head tops a clean and still honey/copper body. Head is slightly meringuish with great staying power and a lot of lacing. What an IPA should look like.

Greapefruit is subtle yet strong with slight floral notes and mild caramel malt. Thats what Im talkin about...overall citrus is dominant but not one-sided - aroma has Beautiful Chemistry in spades.

Caramel malt comes forward in an even keel. Hoppiness manifests itself in more of a bitter citrus tone than on the nose...with a little warmth theres solid balance but the citrus and malt do quiet down rather quickly.

This achieves almost perfect balance on the palate. Malt is clean but hearty and hops provide ample bitterness and citrus. Finish is strong and even-keeled. Husky but bright. Never gets old.

One of the most drinkable beers around in my opinion and my favorite beer to drink all-around. Excellent for all seasons - hearty enough for cold, light enough for warm. Quenches thirst and provides a strong but clean flavor profile.
Good stuff! I really like this one more than the Ruination. Good hop flavor but not at all overpowering.
Cant believe how widely distributed this one has become. A very good example of the style--probably more on the English than the American side (which is, after all, a good thing).

Cask conditioned at The White Horse, Parsons Green, London. Hazed gold with white head. Quite a fruity beer with good hop character, the best beer in this Festival for me, a little flat but still very drinkable. Lemony citrus body, quite powerful and drying. A pretty decent beer.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2011 1. On Tap at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 10/10/2007
Hoppy and fruity aroma. Some carbonation. Amber golden coloured strong in alcohol and hoppy with a grapefruit flavour. Bitter and dry lasting finish.
2. From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center Denver 18/09/2010 (As Double Dry Hopped IPA)
Big hop aroma. Clear golden coloured very hoppy and fruity with a pineapple flavour. A hint of dryness in a bitter malt finish.
Strong piney hop aroma; taste of dough and pepper beyond the standard hoppy bitterness.  Clear dark gold with bubbly carbonation; dry finish; thin white head is short-lived but laces nicely.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a nice white head which stays.  Aroma almost knocks you over with tons of citrus hops - lemons, limes, grapefruit.  Flavor is sweet nectar up front followed by huge citrus and floral hops.  Heavily carbonated but still very smooth.  Very nice IPA.
A golden orange beer with a small head. Aroma is floral, piney, & peppery. Taste is very hoppy, bitter, & smooth for the bitterness. A very good standard IPA but there are better ones.
Just a great IPA, gotta love it.  A classic West-coast hopped-up example of the style.  Very reliably good.
Wonderful brew. Very bitter and very flavourful. One of my favourite beers, extremely smooth.

Light golden in color.. Floral hops aroma, more subtle than a lot of west coast ipas Ive had.... Flavor is floral hops, nice bitterness throughout with a nice spicy bitter finish... Very enjoyable IPA

Bottle at Henrik Øl og Vinstove in Bergen, shared with Elisabeth. Unclear golden. A few patches on the surface. Sweet and bitter aroma of citric hops. Well blended flavour of grapefruit, lemon and orange shells. Malty sweetness beneath. Decent dry bitter ending. A real pleaser to the palate (18.06.2009).

Pours an apricot-gold with a medium-sized foamy head that condenses without collapsing. Aroma is nicely hoppy and quite floral/sweet nectar. Flavor is quite robust for an IPA, releasing the flora and huge citrus hops, with a creamy body and finish. Mouthfeel is nice and full but not at all gooey. Dont know what else to say about it other than its just damn good all around. Flawless for the style. Overall, very good minus.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a medium yellow, with a short-lived white head.  Aromas indicating aggressive hopping with west coast varieties are evident in the nose.  The palate is dominated by the aforementioned, although there is a nice touch of malt at the finish, which is quite dry.  A lingering hop flavor remains on the palate and in the mouth for perhaps a full thirty seconds.  A wonderfully crafted American IPA.

Pours amber with a thick, pillowy head that lasts throughout with excellent lacing.  Perfect level of bitterness, distinctive but not overwhelming.  A wonderful experience to be repeated again and again.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2009 FIRST TIME IM TRYING ANY STONE BREW, POARS GOLDEN HONEY COLOR, VERY LITTLE HEAD, SMELLS GREAT, TASTE VERY GOOD TOO, NICE BALANCE BETWEEN SWEETNESS AND BITTERNESS, GOOD IPA, NOT THE BEST BUT VERY GOOD CANT WAIT TO TRY OTHER STONE BREWS

On Tap at Gingerman, Dallas.  Pours golden amber, lovely head & lacing.  Fresh citrus on the nose, with white grapes; like walking through an evergreen forest after a rain.  Hops-forward, pleasant resiny flavor fills your mouoth with pine-bright goodness.  Clean, fantastic aftertaste, perfection that lingers in the best way.  Very drinkable/sessionable, we order this beer anytime/anywhere.

Bomber served in a tulip. Hazy light orange color. Medium off-white head. Nose of sweet citrus (tangerine) and fresh pine. Refreshing and crisp. The bitterness dominates overall. Medium body. Not overly creamy, oily, thick, thin, or sticky. A good balance in mouthfeel. Smooth. This is good brew. Hold it!... As the beer warms the nose develops a heavy artificial floral soap fragrance. The anti-bacterial foaming kind with Aloe Vera and Vitamin B5. Eeehhhck!! Just lost some points. I will drink it faster next time.

Pours hazy orange with an off-white head that lingers leaving great lace. Beautiful citrus aroma is a perfect balance between sweet and bitter. Taste matches well with aroma being perfectly balanced. Thick malt supports the entire beer allowing it to be superb.
A great IPA. Not the best Ive ever had, but top tier. Bitter, but not quite bitter enough. Fruity notes and a good backbone of flavor. Will try again when I get the chance.

Man, this is one fine brew...Ive had it before a couple of times before, but that was prior to my reviewing existance. Although this beer is somewhere near hazy apricot but closer to a gold, it has some interesting clarity and my glass is giving off a weird shadowed pattern. Its not the hype, its just that right off the bat from first smell to first sip you know this beer separates itself from the competiton. The aroma has the standard smells but they are straight up better - mild pine and grapefruit, slight spice, floral, background caramel malts: the beauty of this is that the aroma is not over the top - its just excellent. Taste is very nice: awsome well blended flavours of grapefruit, oranges, pine, nice sweetness. Mouthfeel is the ultimate..sure Im fairy tanked but this beer feels so good I wish I lived in Utah so I could marry again...and again...and again....lots of whores! Fake name and ID too....yea...seeds and siblings! hahahahh oh christ, ......incredibly smooth, medium bodied, this is the liquid form of petting kittens. You know what I mean? Pet a kitten .....go ahead....then taste that kitten...do it...if you are not satisfied toss the little critter on the skillet with some garlic...just a great beer! Finishes malty, slightly fruity and with a very acceptable ammount of bitterness that is nowhere near hard bitter. Great beer.

So this is my first Stone beer, and I would have to say that I am not overly impressed, however not disappointed.  It poured a hazy straw yellow with an eggshell white colored head.  Aromas were mostly hoppy.  I didnt really pick up on any citrus like I do with many other IPAs.  Taste sort of translated, it was pretty hoppy and had a sort of bitter taste to it, with absolutely no citrus taste. Overall it is a decent IPA, however I like them to have a bit more balance to them than this.  I will try some other stuff from Stone :)

"Hazy honey brown to the color of clean motor oil, off the pour the cap was minimal and all but disappeared after 30 seconds. Nice color to the body but the beer looks completely flat until I give it a good swirl. Aroma is intense citrus hops with leathery malts, sour peach candy is also coming to mind, very nice aroma not over the top and completely yummy. Flavor is very upfront and turns sweet in the finish, wood flavored malts, pine, and lots of citrus, and the taste of gin can all be noticed. Im getting a peach flavor on ever third sip. Beer is light bodied and very dry. Dam fine brew clean crisp complex what ells could you ask for."

A nice looking slightly hazy copper beer with a decent off-white head that leaves lacing. Aroma is all piney and citrusy hops, a little sweet. The flavor is mostly hop bitterness, and quite bitter it is too. A one-dimensional IPA, but hey: I love hops.
This is a good IPA, alot more palate friendly than the Ruination.  Nice and hopy, what you expect from a quality India Pale Ale , put this one one your list of must tries.

very little maltiness.  a clean dry finish.  Extremely close to being a double.  piny citrusy hoppy. nice froathy head that gives way to lacing.  Even if you dont like IPAs this beer is worth buying and just smelling it for hours.

Poured from 12oz. Bottle into Snifter glass.

Pours a crystal clear glowing orange with a fantastic slightly off-white creamy head. Aroma has caramel malt, granny smith apple and touches of citrus hops. Flavor has more of the citrus hops upfront with some light malts and a very light bitterness that doesnt dominated. its light to medium bodied with a very light carbonation. Very nicely done IPA, doesnt really stand out from most but the aroma is unique.

Pours a deep gold with little white head. Aroma of floral hops, pineapple, and red apples. Has an intensified IPA flavor: lots of hops, lots of pine, lots of crispness, lots of bitterness. The flavor will stay with you for quite a while, so you better like IPAs.
This beer is just ridiculous...it makes it almost impossible to drink cheap american domestics ever again.

pours golden/amber yellow. nice white head that lasts.  medium hoppy nose and pleasant complex floral aroma.  this is very well balanced beer. there are so many IPAs out there that arent hopped appropriately.

There is a subtle sweet smell of hops to the aroma, but I feel less potent out of the bottle than the tap. It has a clear golden color. There is a clean hops flavor because, as it advertises, its made with four simple ingredients. But it is not an overabundance of hops that hits you hard like a hop slam. I prefer their pale ale, but this is a delicious beer to drink.

Pours a golden amber color with about half an inch of head.  Floral hops and citrus heavy on the nose.  Medium bodied.  On the palate I get hops, citrus, grapefruit with a nice strong finish.  We are verging on perfection here.  Nice subtle floral hop flavor stays on your palate for a long time after...get it!
12oz bottle, liquid gold with a hint of orange color.  Definitely a standard bearer for American IPAs - flawless balance, great hop bitterness, pine, caramel.  Fantastic!

Sample at Rozis Wine House Stone Brewing Co. Event.  Poured a cloudy yellow/orange color with white head.  A little piney aroma and a bubbly mouth feel with smooth finish and alcohol aftertaste.  Not my favorite IPA but certainly decent.

Orange amber hue,  grapefruit, citrus & resin profile.  Perfume, herb, caramel malt nose. Crisp and acceptably bitter finish.  Again, agree with Pipper, not my favorite IPA but its a decent one.
Sampled at Rozis Wine & Liquor, Stone Tasting Event, Lakewood, OH.
Poured orangish golden, crisp, piney hops, citrus, little caramel, little malty.
12oz. Golden-ish pour with creamy head, standard. Hoppy bitter citrus, loads of caramel malts....it is what it is...

12oz bottle. So staggeringly drinkable. The hops are evident from the moment the cap is popped. I had this alongside some excellent IPAs and it stood just that extra step above. Thick, viscous mouthfeel and evident complexity of hops with just the right malt backing to convince the drinker that they are in the hands of a master brewer. Wonderfully long finish. Tantalizingly good from the best IPA brewers in the country.
Great beer.  The smell is hoppy, but inviting.  I think that is my favorite feature of the beer.  Good session beer.

Purchased by a friend while videotaping a Jazz/Fusion show. I had one hand on the camcorder and the other on a glass of some now forgotten Flying Fish offering when a shift of the wind brought a Stone IPA into my reality. I hadnt been the same since. Thank you Stone for  big hops, ruination, arrogance and a reason to pursue other Stone offerings.

Good for the style. Just a little too much for me. High marks for quality, low on drinkability. Not my favorite style, so keep my bias in mind when considering my rating. Another solid stone offering.
Bottle and Draft.  Pours a copper body with a white head.  Earthy chewy, caramel with a light bubblegum character to it.  A good ipa but more IBUs would really make this crazy.
how does stone make so many good beers? had this one many times while stationed in S.D. had it again after 5 years in MA, same great IPA, well done!

A hazy yellow ale with an airy white head. Citrus nose with some pine the malt aroma is hidden but there. The taste is hoppy with a good balance of malts. It is sweet and bitter, a good IPA. A strong medium body beer with a nice lingering hop taste. Overall a well balanced IPA.
Excellent IPA. Lots of floral hops in the nose and a similar taste. Finishes smooth with a hint of citrus.
A very smooth IPA that was good in every aspect, but not great. Not as strong as I was expecting, and it is very easy to drink. LC

Huge aroma of cascade and chinook(?)
Malty and dry at the same time. Best IPA around. The only downfall is that is is sometimes hard to find fresh stuff here in Philadelphia. Check your date codes for maximum hop aroma.
This is by far the best IPA I have had.  The aroma was amazing with the great hop smell, then the taste was very refreshing.  This is a very good beer.

(bottle from Weber St Liqour in Colorado Springs). Pours a cloudy, light copper color. Large off white head. Strong hop aroma. Strong hop flavor with bitterness. Long duration. Heavy bitterness on the finish. Slightly oily texture. Good lacing. Moderate carbonation.
Simply one of the best IPAs Ive ever had! Very crisp and refreshing. The hops balance the alcohol for a very enjoyable brew!

Pours a clear orange color with a nice thick and dense head.  Smells lightly of hops which citrus is definitely apart of.  The hops are definetly noticeable giving off the standard taste of citrus and pine.  This is a little malty as well which is a nice aspect of the beer.  The flavor is wonderfully mild, making this an excellent choice for a session beer.

It pours a golden color with an off white head. The aroma is of caramel and citrus- grapefruit, orange, and lemon. The taste is the same. Very well balanced, and stylish. Tasty and bitter without destroying the palate.

Pours golden with two fingers of frothy white head; nice lacing.  A brief wisp of malt aroma is quickly outgunned by the bouquet of the freshest floral hops; a tiny bit of skunk.  Flavor is well balanced between the aggressive hop bitterness and the flavors of malt and evergreen hops.  Medium body and a clean finish.  This is a great beer and the best thing by Stone Ive had.

12 oz. bottle. a light aroma of sweet, bitter hop. pours a thin white head, semi cloudy gold.  flavor of bitter hop, sweet banana. subtle malts and fine hop content for i p a. dry after taste, far from overpowering , as some over hopped i p a s can be. this is a fine i p a, but not a 99  for me.

Pours an orangy straw color with a thin head and nice lacing.

It tastes exactly how an IPA should taste. This isnt an overpowered IPA trying to be too much, bordering on a DIPA, this is a perfectly crafted hoppy but balanced IPA. Good amount of citrus, not too much pine, and a smooth sweet malt finish.

Starts dry, finishes sticky. Kind of like me with your mom.
Bottle. Pours a hazy amber-orange color with a large off white head. Aroma is huge floral hops, grapefruit, orange, pine

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 love this one, Stone IPA is as good as it gets, big hops aroma and flavor nice bitterness, deep golden orange color, fluffy head lacing everything...Perfect for hops lovers like me..drinkability!!!!

Bottle. A yellowy-orange color, a bit lighter than I expected, with a nice foamy, fluffy, and clean off-white head. Lots of rich, fresh, piney, earthy, citrusy hops in the aroma. Broadly hopped, no doubt, as the flavor is dominated by them, in all the same variety as the aroma. Just a little bit of malt sweetness hiding in the background. A nice sharp bitterness lingers in the back of the mouth. Smoothly and finely carbonated. How come Ive never tried this before now? Seriously, Ive been missing out on an exceptional IPA.
a fearsome stone figure that has power to ward ward off evil spirits.  Good hoppy taste Pours a clear yellow with a hoppy aroma. Hazy orange w/ a huge off-white head.
Solid IPA. Nothing too hard to handle with a moderately masked sweet finished so the bitterness is finely juxtaposed. I like

On tap at DLD 09. Pours an absolutely crystal clear, bright golden body with a gorgeous, two-finger width, foamy and dense, off-white head that never dissipates entirely and stays extremely lacy. Sexual. Aroma is loaded with citrus. Lots of sour grapefruits and oranges. Some soft malts hold it together nicely, but mostly juicy, fresh off the vine hops. Im taken back by how good this smells for being so simple. The flavor is brilliantly straightforward as well. Intensely hoppy. Tons of citrus and medium earthiness. A deep pine taste, like middle of the damn forest deep. Some melony goodness comes in as well as simple caramels and light bready notes. Lingers forever. Medium bodied, crisp yet smooth, and surprisingly easy drinking for such a hop explosion. Overall, phenomenal. Assertive, but never out of balance or over-the-top. Wow! Definitely tied for the #1 spot on my IPA board.

12 oz. bottle (2009) courtesy jbean. Beautiful, beautiful IPA. Hazy orange w/ a huge off-white head. Flowery cascade goodness and quite well-balanced to boot. Only marginally below the Two Hearted ale. Lovely.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2010 Draught from 1/2 barrel in my kegerator.                                                                 First 10 beers                                                                                                                              --       Very nice golden color, with an off-white head that sticks around. Hoppy taste and aroma that dominate the this brew, but aroma also consists or caramels and grapefruit along with other citrus. Flavor is sweet malty (caramel and light bread) and biting bitter grapefruit perfectly singeing your nostrils right of the back half of the taste. Beer is dry throughout and bold with citrus hops. Tight quick finish.   
NExt 150 continued to reaffirm this beers closeness to my heart! After class (and sometimes before) this beer has an X-factor intangible something extra about it that sets it a grade above.

Fantastic IPA. Great example of the style.

Appearance is a golden pale. Nice head and solid lacing

Smell is hops, hops, hops. Citrus dominate with some pine and floral hints.

Taste is hoppy, citrus, floral, bitter. Great balance between bittering hops and flavor hops. Finish isnt sweet but there is a dry malt flavor on the very back end.

Mouthfeel is very nice.

Drinkability is terrific if you are a fan of the style. If you dont like IPAs..this one isnt for you.

Great beer. Its simplistic: hops are hops and malts are malts. Not overly complex but everything is in perfect balance allowing one to enjoy this fine beer in all its glory. Well done.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2012 On tap at DLD 09.  Im not really sure why I was so skeptical about this one going into trying, but it absolutely blew me away.  I had already tried quite a few world class before trying it, so maybe I was alittle overly happy from the day of drinking quality beer, but the entire time drinking this, I wasnt sure if I was just imagining how good this beer really was.  Ill have to re-rate sometime, but at that moment, this is what I had:

The aroma definitely leans toward the hoppy side, but never theres never too much.  Enticing smells to perfection.  Just so many different hop notes with floral bouquets, citrus, grapefruit, melons, earth, and all of it coming together brilliantly.  A backing aroma of basic yet pleasant caramels and pale malts that are exactly what the beer needed.  Probably the only weakness I can see in this beer is in its appearance, only because of the lighter looking body, otherwise, still very appealing with good sized creamy froth head, mild carbonation, great lacing and retention the whole way, and golden tangerine in color.  I know my friends thought I was crazy when i first started drinking this, but golly! I really couldnt believe how it tasted.  The hoppy bitterness is just impossible to beat.  Just too complex and it works too well.  Citrus grapefruits, mixed citrus, melons, and earth galore.  Again, like the aroma, just the perfect backing of basic, but great quality malts with caramels and pales.  The bitter then just lasts, and lasts, and lasts in the finish.  Incredible! Too good to be true!

Its filtered and clear and beautiful and looks like a million bucks, but the bitterness lingers in a way thats remarkably out-of-balance.  Theres actually not much hop *flavor*.  Thought it would be better, more surprising.  A perfectly clean beer, though uninspired.

From Bottle. 22-APR-2009.
Drank this one in the hotel Room in New York.
Light colour with a little orange. but mostly just pale (!).
Very hoppy with lots of pine.
A very looong aftertaste, but ends a little watery. Bitter astringent finish almost without sweetnes.
Nice IPA with emphasis on hops. I think I prefer them a little sweeter, but I would drink this any time.
Pours dark amber with thick white head. aroma fresh hops .citrus, grapefruit  . taste is  very bitter , oily . has slight sweet malt backbone. Nice sticky lacing.

On tap at Dark Lord Day 09 as one of the many beers on "The Fancy Beer Tapping Schedule". Poured a fairly clear, light orange/amber with a thick white, foamy head and excellent rings of lacing. The aroma was strong but pleasant pine, and then citrus, toned down a bit by some smooth malt. Ditto on the flavor with some nice even hop bitterness. Up there with all the solid IPAs.

Bombers from Wegmans, VERY well priced. Uncaps a oh yeah! aroma and pours a beautiful goldy hazy yellow and fine moderate head releasing fruit citrus and hint of spruce and sweetness. Taste big open juicy hop profile, all citrus and piney, and no lack of bittering hops over the beguiling pale fruit (pear or peach?) that lurks underneath. The assertively dry bitterness runs away a bit over the initial mellowness, which maybe just calls for salty buttery snacks or cuts of fine charcuterie. I love the subtle aromatic tones along with that bitterness. No... you dont understand, Ive just never had any beer like this particular India Pale. THIS is the American IPA. Something has now arrived for me.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine.  Bright orange in color with a nice white head.  Piney and light citrus hop aroma.  Flavor of piney hops with bitter grapefruit.  No alcohol presence just everything that makes an IPA great.  Absolutely one of the top IPAs available.

12 oz. [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Oslo. Pale amber with an orangey shade and slight haze. Firm white head. Predominant hop aroma; sweet grapefruit, oranges, some resin and a touch of perfume. Malts in the background. Nice hoppy flavor as well; lots of citrus, pine and resin, quite sharpish, yet tasty and fresh. Delicate sweet malts in the backbone. Well-bodied. Fruity-bitter ending. 
Moreish, high drinkability.

Pours plain amber with white head.  Nose is hop focused, as expected, with emphasis on fresh pine and grapefruit.  Prickly hops on the palate with good carbonation and lick smacking hop presence.  Very "juicy".  Finish leaves a pine taste that you dont want to end.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2009 Aroma seems much weaker than I was expecting. Flavor is big hops, citrus and clean, bracing bitterness. Alcohol taste seems right up front, too, not at all hidden. The first 12 oz. was great, but everything here is so intense that it was not easy to finish the whole 22 oz. bomber.

Pours a very clear yellow amber.  Smells great!  The aromas are soft sweet malts and very present but not overwhelming American hops.  The flavor is somewhat plain, but exceedingly well done.  Soft malty sweetness balanced with very nice American hops.  Finishes lightly bitter.  The mouthfeel is great, I can really tell they adjust/filter their water with precision.  Soft, round and clean.  

Overall, none of the attributes of this beer are utterly beautiful or arresting, but everything is done just right, and together this for me the standard of a great IPA

12 oz bottle.  Orange amber.  Sticky head.  Sweet hoppy nose.  Taste hoppy bitter and sweet.  Sticks to the back of the throat.  Some citrus and honey.  Buy a sixer and drink it straight from the bottle.  Yummers.

Pours a hazy orange with thick head that sticks around for a while.  Head starts to dissipate leaving a lacing obvious from where it was.  Aroma of hops very evident with a bit of pine.  Flavor is quite pleasant, but no surprise.  Mouthfeel is slightly oily.  Very refreshing and inviting brew that I am sure I will be having a bit more of.

As soon as I opened this beer, the hops exploded!  This IPA reminds me Two Hearted in that this is a big piney, fresh beer.  Not nearly as overbalanced on the hop side as Ruination of course, but it still is one of my favorite beers.  Very easy to drink, very refreshing and very well hopped!

Pours clear amber, with a thin white head, good lacing.  Smells of pine, hay, citrus, oats, and dough.  Medium, crisp, and slightly dry body.  A lot of bread and barley up front, with deep grass and citrus bitterness.  A strong, but nice bitter aftertaste.  A lot of depth and subtlety in both the malt and hop profiles.  A very nice blend of flavors.

12 fl. oz. bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 6.9%. Deep golden to orange colour, moderate white head. Lovely hoppy aroma, notes of citrus and tropical fruits. The zesty and fruity flavour is distinctly hoppy from start to finish, on a sufficient malty background. Ends in a grapefruity bitterness, but it is not overdone. Long bitter aftertaste. More to my liking than the Arrogant Bastard. Good stuff!
Wonderful beer. About the best IPA that I have ever graced my mouth with. Thanks Stone, yet another Fantastic brew!

Bottle poured into a regular pint glass this beer produced a hazy orange/gold color with a 2 finger head.  There was some nice lacing present.  The smell consisted of pine, hops, and citrus.  I found the taste to be a bit of a let down as the malts far outweighed the hops.  It was, however, very easy to drink and was still enjoyable.

Fairly fresh bottle. Golden brown pour with a 1 finger white head. Aroma of floral hops, citrus, bitter smelling. Flavor is pretzels, goldfish, malts and absolutely delicious floral hops. Nice bitter astringent taste.

Bottle at Bar & Cigar, Oslo.
Grassy, malty, strong, but not kick in the teeth flavour, either. 
Malty sweetness in the body. 
Clear gold.

Rating #400 -- hard to believe I havent rated ths.  K and I have a nice little history with this brew.  went to the stone bistro and got growlers full on a san diego trip.  just had a keg of it at our wedding reception.  yet somehow hadnt managed to rate it.  so...  hazy gold pour with a thinnish bright white head.  nice blend of piney citrus hops and honey in the aroma.  crisp hop bitterness right away.  nearly perfect chewy light to medium texture.  caramel malts back things up a bit - but this is all about the hops.  great stuff.  good times.

Golden in color, slightly cloudy in clarity, this brew lent itself to an awesome two-finger, cream colored head. The aroma is excellently balanced between the flowery (not bitter) hop and the coy, slightly sweet malt. Interestingly, this beer tasted opposite of most--the hop was up front followed by malt. The beer was balanced throughout the tasting. 

This is a full body ale with wonderful carbonation. This may be the best IPA Ive ever enjoyed. I am drawn to getting another even though I prefer variety.

35,5cl bottle at Bar & Cigar. It poured an orange colour with a medium big white foamy head. The aroma is hoppy with notes of citrus and melon. The flavour is fresh and hoppy with notes of citrus and melon. It has a short aftertaste.

Pours a beautiful amber with a medium head that dissolves to a lasting lace film.  Aroma is hoppy citrus and pine(?).  Taste is full-on smoothe... bitter lemoniness (yep, its a word) with an excellent finish that just leaves me wanting another swig.  Good stuff.

Phenomenal stuff from Stone. Pours that golden amber youre looking for in an IPA but lacks some of the sediment and cloudiness. However, aroma and flavor more than make up for it. Huge hits of lemon citrus and bitter pine assault the nostrils while your tastebuds are just trying to hold on for the ride. Perfect smooth, clovery bitter-hop finish. Amongst the top of the class in IPA.

Aroma:  I can smell the pine trees in this beer.  There are hints of grassy and maybe some citrus notes.

Appearance: Its clear, medium gold with a tall white head.   The head crashed quickly leaving thick lacing in the glass (gorgeous).

Flavor: Its a hop forward taste.  The initial bitter bite carries through the tasting experience.  I can taste the malt, but the flavor is balanced towards the hops. 
 
Mouth feel: It has a medium body

Overall Impression:   This is definitely an IPA; the hops smack me in the taste buds.  I was surprised aroma was not stronger (the hops seem muted) until I looked at the Enjoy By date and it read 03/31/09.  This was a bit surprising as I purchased the beer in mid-March (09).  I guessing the hop aroma diminished over time.   Even being old, I am still enjoying the beer.
pours hazy brownish yellowish, huge hoppy creamy head, taste is very piney, hoppy overall a great ipa make you want more then one
Almost sessionable. Definate slugable. Poured hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of lemon and orange. Finished wet.

Light orange, slightly hazy, small white head. Aroma is big on pine, resin and citrus hops, canned fruits, and a tiny bit of malt sweetness. Flavour is huge, loads of hops, but nicely balanced with malt sweetness. There are hints of other flavors here too, but they dont quite come through. Lively carbonated, medium body. Very drinkable and refreshing.
Like a pine tree in a glass! A bit too harsh for my tastes but its definitely a great ipa. Lots of bitter grassy flavor with notes of citrus and grapefruit.

Pours light yellow with little/thin lace. Hops come right through. Quick on the bitter with short linger. True to IPA flavor. A thumbs up, three stars and a freckle go to this decent brew.  
$10/sixer bottles at The Beer & Liquor Store in Lake Worth, FL
resonious piney hop aroma with the taste following suite. nice bitter bite through out that finishes bitter. hops from start to finish. really nice ipa

Bottle. This is piney goodness in an IPA. Clear orange pour with a small white head.  Laces to the glass solidly.  Pineapple and caramel flavors are very strong on the front end.  Solid hop balance in the finish.

Cloudy amber with a huge three finger head and good amount of lacings. Aroma is big bready and citrus hops. Taste is big citrus hops, grapefruit rind, some pine and resins. Malts are there but definately bringing up the rear. Mouthfeel is good very crisp, but slightly excessive carbonation. I may have served this a bit too cold. Overall an impressive IPA and just what I look for in a modern West Coast version. Drink em fresh for best results.

Appearance:  Pours a clear gold with a dense, foamy white head.

Aroma:  Piny and grassy hops in the nose.

Taste:  Citrus flavors such as lemon and lime, tons of bitter and spicy hops. A very modest malt bill can be found if you look hard enough.

Mouthfeel: Crisp and refreshing. Full bodied and carbonated.

Overall:  This IPA will knock your socks off with bitterness. The Ruination has more floral and fruit notes mixed in with the wheelbarrow of hops. This IPA is crisp, dry and really hoppy.  You should like both, but you might like one over the other for the differences mentioned.
Fantastic, especially if fresh.  Piney and resiny in the aroma and taste.  The ultimate in available west coast IPAs.

12oz bottle. Pours translucent golden orange with a fluffy white head. Fantastic aroma of citrus and grassy hops. The taste is big hops with a light malt backing. Lost of pine and resin with notes of grapefruit and caramel. Pleasant lingering bitter aftertaste. Excellent.

Pours a nice copper color with a foamy head. Heavy hop aroma. Lemons, grapefruit, pine and some flowers seem to make up the majority of this beer. Quite sure this is over-rated. Taste is a mixed up mess IMO. The flavors seem to run around all crazy like and never quite come together. Good beer, but not a great beer.
bottle.  bitter.  pretty straightforward ipa.  not as good as founders centennial ipa or bells two hearted.

Bottle.  This is golden orange in the glass with a half inch white head, medium carbonation.  Theres loads of pine in the aroma, fresh pink grapefruit, sliced apricot, lime juice and zest.  The body is medium, coating, slightly oily.  There are waves of lacing on the glass.  Malt and hops are really well balanced in this.  I taste lots of pink grapefruit, pine, wood, fresh sliced avocado in the hops; the bitterness is strong and inviting.  Finishes fairly long.
The best IPA out there, at least in my experience. Yes, hoppy, a little citrus note, yet overall, balanced and finishes smooth. Just an outstanding overall beer.

12 oz bottle 
sappy smelling .... and hopped out... nothing but bitter... i guess if you like nothiing but hops it is for you

A dazzling sunset of golden orange hues is topped by scattered clouds of white fluff which refuse to secede to the setting sun which fills my glass. Rays of her bouquet tickle my nose, bursting into a bouquet of orange, melon, nectarines, lemon, grapefruit, wet hop oils and grass. Sprinkles of joy dance in the apple of my eye which has been wholly captivated by the Stone IPA. Romantic illusions aside, how she tastes could make or break our union and with faint trepidation, I take deeply of her nectar. Sparkling bright with a body that immediately sticks to and coats all open surfaces. Orange nectar and nectarine juice linger while lemon and cut grass revitalize my tastebuds. Succulent summer melon creeps into her palate while my mouth waters after each drying finish. She is a perfectly played one-two punch of delicate sweetness followed by a strong crisp bitter hop presence while a hint of toasty malts support her performance from the shadows. Each mouth-watering quaff shortens our time together, shared by bitter-sweet sticky memories of orange, melon, hop oils and pine, lemon and grapefruit. Highly sessionable, my glass has long been empty while only pleasant memories remain.


Stone is now three-for-three in the success department, but I expected no less. I wouldnt go so far as to say I have a 6th sense for beers, and maybe I do, but that many Stone fanatics cant be wrong. Stone Brewing has brought this year to a wonderful close for me and no matter your hop preference, their IPA is just right for you.
Wow, the bitterness is perfect. Very drinkable. An accessible IPA that contains all of the characteristics of a good IPA, full of hops, amber color, hints of citrus, and intense flavor.
Yeah, its bitter, but then what? This is a one trick pony with no complexity, depth or body. At least the Ruination has some ambition.

Oh joy and rapture finally an IPA thats an IPA! Massive cascade and dark pineapple lumps on the nose. This kicks ass, its sweet but then the hops pounce like a rabid terrier for the kill! Im trying not to get to over the top about this one because ive had some pretty average US IPAs lately. Not as good as TWISTED HOP IPA or Armageddon but damn tasty!

Nice, easy to drink IPA. Nothing really stands out, its just extremely drinkable with a typical flavour profile leaning slightly to the brighter, hoppier side. The body is rather light with a decent amount of carbonation making it very easy to pour down. Good as most of the time with Stone.

Bottle. [thank you, after4ever]
Hazy darkish golden with a staying, frothy, off-white head. Good lacing. Nice hoppy aroma. There is pine, grapefruit, caramel, malts, grass. Great frothy mouthfeel, wonderful dryness, medium to high carbonation. Elegant hoppy flavour. There is a great deal of pine, sweet maltiness behind it. Some grapefruit and grassy notes. Long, lingering, dry, ashy, hoppy aftertaste.

Stone is consistent.  I have been drinking their IPA for many years and cannot notice any change.  There might be one or two brews out there to offer a challenge, but for the price, this is my staple IPA.  Pour, head, aroma, fllavor, mouthfeel, finish are all top notch.  I sure am glad somebody can make a beer this good, regularly.  Thanks, guys!

12 oz bottle Aroma of pine and hops and IPA goodness.  Poured a clear deep golden color with a small white head that didnt linger.  The flavor and palate were sort of a junior version of big brother Ruination.  A superior IPA.
Bottle from Port Chester Beer Distributor. Golden color with a warm and sweet floral hop flavor. Great hop flavor without the sting of alcohol.
tasting at lake las vegas..massive hop flavour..golden color..huge hop flavour.. nice IPA
Extreme hoppy flavor as suggested on the label.  A nice murky golden color with a large bite of hops with each drink.  Very full flavored beer and the 6.9% alcohol by volume sneaks up on you.

I could nose this beer all day, with its insistent hops jumping at me from my tulip glass. Pine notes abound, not quite like a Christmas tree, but close enough to merit mention. People seem to think this beer has some semblance of balance to it; I dont. The hops kicked me right in the teeth and went screaming down my throat. If Im in the right mood I can enjoy it, but its not one of my favorite IPAs.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2009 Bottle.  Pours clear amber with a frothy white head.  Aroma is mostly piny hops, a little bit of caramel and spice.  Mouthfeel is nice and fairly thick.  Initial taste is floral hops with just enough malty citrus sweetness, but quickly becomes an overwhelming aspirin bitterness- finish is long, but purely bitter without much character.

Tried this for the first time in Kentucky this past weekend (cant get it in Bama, of course).  Overall, simply, I loved it.  Solid flavor, good carbonation.  Lots of subtle and not so subtle pine notes and a little citrus.  Should have brought back a crate!  Ruination is up next.

Enjoyed on the patio at the brewery. Looks great - smells better; pine, malt and big cascade hop presenece. Flavor is much the same as aroma. Extremely well balanced and 6.9% is well hidden - until about half way through your 3rd pint I found.
One of the best (actually probably the best) American style I.P.A.s..
Could we get this in Ontario please?

A sparkling amber with a thick white head. HEAVY citrus/pine aroma. The flavor the hops impart on this beer match perfectly with the sweetness of the malt giving it a really nice, fruity taste. Finishes a little too bitter for me but nowhere near as overpoweringly as Stones Ruination. Very, very drinkable which can let the 6.9% sneak up on you. Very, very good.

Bottle.  A bright orange/yellow color, slightly cloudy.  Medium head that disappeared fairly quickly.  A citrusy aroma.  Initially a fairly hoppy flavor, but a long smooth finish.  A very enjoyable IPA, easy to gulp.  I prefer dogfish head 60-minute, but this is excellent.

12 oz bottle.  Almost as good as the Ruinition IPA.  Pours dark gold with a frothy soapy head.  Smells floral, citrusy, and piney.  Tastes piney up front, sweet malt, then a nice crisp citrus kick.  Sticky aftertaste leaving you wanting another drink.  Nice IPA.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 transcribed from a super old rating.

12 oz. bottle tasted blind.

pours hazy gold with little white head.

Solid aroma of jasmine and lemon.

Unfortunately, something just tasted off and out of balance for this IPA and the bitterness just did not work for my palate.

Super dry crisp clean mouthfeel with solid carbonation and a quick finish.

Overall, a solid IPA, representative of what Stone does with hops.

Pours gold with a finger of really soapy white head. Really killer lacing throughout. Nose is ALL floral hops. Yum. Taste is big hops up front but with a deftly executed malt note. Fairly balanced actually. It sits somewhat thin on the tongue and has a nice bracing bitter finish. Pretty much the epitome of the style. Nice beer.

A truly superb IPA that makes me think of America. Crisp with a great hop taste and aroma but certainly not too overpowering like some hop monsters out of the States. I can now buy this in England which is really good news. Without a doubt, one of my favourite IPAs.

Bottle.  Poured a hazy orange.  Definitely a hop monster maybe even closer to a DIPA or an IIPA.  Big flowery hops aroma.  Quite sweet, pretty standard citrus, pine, caramel all are there.  Dry finish.

Bomber.  Pours hazy orange yellow with nice thick white head.  Aroma is mainly hops with and a little honey and lemon.  Bitter hops and the front of the flavor, a bit of citrusy orange and pine underneath, possibly even some caramel at the end.  Fairly thick palate for an IPA, medium carbonation, has bite.  Very good.

355ml Bottle shared with Pyrozoid.  semi clear golden appearancewith an off white head and light lacing.  Aroma: pine, hops, grassy mint and ginger.  Flavor: hops, spicy, pine, orange zest and ginger.  Palate: medium body, creamy with a hoppy peppery finish.

Bouteille. Dégusté avec french tickler et Agaguk. Biere de couleur caramel clair avec un mince collet très collant. Odeur dépinette, ail, carotte et épices. Gout floral, sucre, épices et un soupçon de sel.

1/21/09 From the bottle. Aroma is grassy, not harsh, with a light caramel background. Appearance is clear gold with a very well maintained white head. Flavor is sourvsemi-earthy citrus hops forward, with a light watery sweetness in the background. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a medium carb texture. Overall, not huge, but big enough to typify the style.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 From 22 oz. bottle into tulip at brew pub.  Clear amber color with medium off-white head.  Good lacing remaining throughout.  Very hoppy - pine/citrus and bitter through the finish.  Review is of last half of bottle as the first pour included a slight aroma of bleach.  This from a respected brew pub - I did not complain, just let it sit awhile.  I will say it dampened my excitement immediately for my first taste of Stone IPA.  Overall very enjoyable - Cheers!  Updated 2011.  Have enjoyed this fine brew many times since, and with proper glassware.  A classic brew, flavorful, dry, bitter.  Excellent!

Bu dans un verre de la fin du monde et a temperature piece. Apparence exactement que sur la photos, or / orangé avec un collet extremement mousseux qui colle tres bien au verre.  Arome de pin, gingembre, zest dorange, belle variété dhoublons aromatique.  Palais tres crémeux, avec un debut amere subtile, mais qui reviens tres fort et qui persiste longtemps.  Finition sec.  Une des meilleurs IPA de base que jai gouté, de toute evidence il ny as rien de complexe, juste une belle variété dhoublon et de maltes.

Bottle. This would pass for an imperial IPA in most cases. Stronger in taste than most of that classification. Strong, fruity-hoppy aroma. Tastes rather fruity but extreme bitterness on the back end. Light color. It reminded me of the West Coast IPA, which I think is nearby.
Tap.Nice citrus aroma, good first impression. Crisp and smooth beer, just what I am looking for in an IPA

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2009 Bottle:  Definitely slight pine and citrus smell.  Nice dark amber color with off white head.  Very citrusy with an intense bitter finish.  Ive never have been a big fan of extra hoppy flavor, but I ve gotta say I really like this one.

Fresh hop aroma of mild pine, grapefruit and other florals with caramel malt in the background.
Beautiful apple juice color with a copper hue and sediment particles are suspended. Lots of action with an off white head.
Resin flavor of well balanced mild pine and fresh grapefruit with some sweet tea  and caramel flavor in the background.
Medium bodied, resinous, crisp carbonation, and has an alcohol warming throughout.
A session IPA for hopheads very tasty and well balanced overall.
Very tasty and damn good IPA, one of my favorite in its class.  Stone may not do much, but what they do know is IPA and this is as good as its bigger ruination brother.

I got this on tap at Lucky Pub in Marion, VA. I was getting growlers of dogfish 60 minute. I tried this at the same time and boy was I surprised. The Stone blew away the Dogfish 60 minute  in every way. Scent, flavor, color and palate. I will never waste money on Dogfish Head 60 minute again!
Bottle in Greenfield, MA. A great IPA from Stone. Yummy amber body with bursting head. Citrus and hoppy nose. Sweet with great hop flavours. Smooth finish.

Bottle.  Pours a great golden color, huge white head.  Smella a huge piny hop smell.  Tastes subtle matly sweetness but mostly that great hoppy-ness.  Huge amounts of hop and bitter bit.  Clean finish great IPA.

Six pack from Total Wine in Jacksonville, FL.  Pours a dark amber/gold color with a nice light head.  Aroma is citrus and a bit of pine hops.  Taste is hoppy and smooth with a touch of bitter to wrap it up.  A wonderful IPA.

2008 Bottle - Pours a murky straw color with a quickly dissipating white head...aroma is clean citrus and pine, flavour follows, nice fleeting bitterness balanced with a touch of back end malt...this suprised me by finishing a bit thin, but I like the ABV and is a decent west coast IPA ...
Nice citrus aroma, good first impression.  Crisp and smooth beer, just what I am looking for in an IPA

Basically a less intense version of Stone Ruination (the IPA I compare everything to nowadays).  Clear golden color with a foamy white head.  Simcoe/Amarillo hops on the aroma.  Hoppy and bitter yet smooth with sweet caramel malt.  Medium bodied and crisp.  Satisfies without kicking your ass.

A- Pours a clear light orange hue; large creamy white head that is mostly sustaining; moderate lacing throughout

S- Nose is dominated by citrusy hops and slight pine tones, classic west coast IPA. . .

T- Crisp and smooth taste; subtle hops initially followed quickly by citrus tones; aftertaste is rather short-lasting and the hops are not quite as bitter as similar IPAs; slight maltiness that is nicely balanced

M- Smooth and watery mouthfeel; nice creaminess and lively carbonation

D- This is a great example of a west coast IPA that is easy-drinking and full of hoppy goodness that is far from overwhelming.

Great beer, not sure how much difference there is between this and the ruination IPA. I think I like the slightly stronger ruination better than this. Very strong and full flavored. The finish was bitter, but the taste was not as bitter. Crisp and well carbonated. Light bodied and highly drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 [Bottle] Pours bright hazy orange with a small white head. Stone usually does a good job with big, hoppy aromas, and although this isnt their best example of it, it is still enjoyable. It does fade after the initial blast, but there is still a lot of citrus (especially lemon zest), honey, some malt and a strange herbal scent. The taste was really not as bitter as I had expected. There was grapefruit in the finish, but that was after some solid malt, and a strange semi-sweetness that I couldnt identify. Meium mouthfeel with a long, dry finish. Not bad. A very solid, clean, well made IPA that did not blow me away, but was fairly impressive nonetheless. Old rating: 7/3/8/4/15=3.7Re-rate: Still a pretty solid beer. The taste is surprisingly hot, quite bitter, and then an unusual blend of melon and papaya, with lots of lemon drop hard candy towards the end, before finishing with barley. Surprisingly thick mouthfeel, smooth, fairly long finish. Overall, enjoyable, but doesnt hide its alcohol very well. Drinks more like a IIPA, and not something Id want to sit down and have multiple pints of.
On draft at Coopers, Manayunk.  Poured light, clear orange with white head.  Sweet, hoppy citrus flavor.  Slightly spicy.  Thin.  Fairly simple but strongly representative of the style.

Bottle.  Pours a clear light yellow amber color.  A little lighter in color than I generally like in my IPAs.  Medium large white foam head.  Piles of citrus hops on the nose backed up with a sweet malt.  Soft pine background.  Medium body but almost empty in the middle.  Finishes lighter than the aroma would suggest with a lingering grapefruit bitterness.

pours a slightly hazy golden color with a foamy white head that dissipates quickly.  aroma has lots of grapefruit, some pineapple, a touch of spice, and the faintest hin of some doughy maltiness.  flavor has some maltiness...pilsner malt?...up front with spicy grapefruit overlapping it.  mouthfeel is smooth with a lingering fruity and dry aftertaste.  very nice but not the best ipa ive had.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2009 smells very much like centennial hops a little piney pretty good aroma. pours a nice color and tastes pretty balanced with the centennial hops coming through, the only thing i would say is that im not the biggest fan of centennial they just dont have the kick.

Nice aroma that makes this IPA inviting at first.  I was expecting a stronger bite with claim of over 70 IBUs listed.  There was a lingering finish on palate, but not crisp & clean like other West Coast IPAs.

Wow!!! I always had an impression of stone being very hoppy so before i tried the IPA I had already mad a decision. ha I was wrong. This beer had a mild aroma for a microw and I would have to say that it had a very nice finish especially for having 77ibus. I find it hard to believe that it is this high.
This is a good tasting IPA. There is a great aroma to this beer with a fruity/hoppy finish. It is a heavier style compared to others.

12 oz bottle. Hazy orange body with a diminishing off-white head. Aroma is fruity peaches and grapefruit. Flavor is medium sweet malty with notes of caramel and a nice balanced bitterness. It actually does not feel as bitter as 70 IBU, but there is a clean pronounced bitterness. Lovely.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 Orange body with gold highlight and frothy polished white creamy top,  semi-transparent. Smells like  Belium Dubbel ale, white chocolate, caramel and toffee. Tastes like a lighter Double as well with light hops, caramel, and butter. Light midway bite. Expecting more of a hoppier IPA.
12oz. Golden-ish pour with creamy head, standard. Hoppy bitter citrus, loads of caramel malts. Sweet spot of IPAs, excellent west coast example. Crisp.

Golden to light amber pour with more than a finger of a head. Decently hoppy aroma. Flavor of strong pine and grapefruit. Extremely smooth, but not quite the hop BITE Im looking for. Nice alchohol content. 

Not sure why Im not raving about this as much as others - guess Ill have to try it again :)

Slightly hazy golden pour with a two finger fluffy white head that leaves a nice lacing.  Nice hop aromas with a solid malt backbone.  Taste at first is not as inviting as the aroma.  An odd bitterness here with a smooth pine taste towards the finish.  The hops really come out as it warms up.  Heavy lacing as well.

From the bottle, pours a clear orange with a thick foamy white head.  Citrusy floral hops are the aromas.  Beer is light enough to drink but thick enough to be considered beer.  Flavors are malty and citrusy, a bit of orange/lemon, with some floral hops to finish.  Light bite at the end and finishes with just the right aftertaste.  This is an excellent IPA, though perhaps not a hop lovers delight.

Pours a beautiful amber/orange with a medium white head.  A huge aroma of citrusy hops hit the nose as you pour.  What a beautiful IPA.  Tastes of grapefruit, orange, and a perfect malt presence.  A very balanced IPA, not too overwhelming, just right.  One of my favorite IPAs.  Everyone must try this beer.

Bottled 12 Fl. Oz. Trade with nearbeer. Apperance: Slightly hazy pale copper with a bubbly off-white head. Good retention. Beautiful lacework. Aroma: Very strong. Centennial hops showing up. Reminiscent lychee, wood, hop resin, grapefruit, tangerine, quinces, licorice and caramel. Flavor and palate: Deep Centennial hop characteristic. Notes of grapefruit, licorice, wood and hop resin. Nice bitterness. Perfectly balanced. Wonderful finish of hop resin. Overall impression: Flawless and deeply pleasant. Thanks a lot nearbeer!

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Appearance:  slight haze; good IPA color; huge fluffy off-white head that never goes away

Aroma: Very nice but somewhat closed aroma--but its very nice!  just the right amount of malt in the background

Flavor: Very good flavor profile echoing the very nice nose; however, I might like some more intensity; seems a little restrained;  that said, it is very well balanced

Mouthfeel:  Tremendous!  One of the best parts to the beer; smooth, suave, well-balanced
Bottle. A lot of hops, which I like. Also a nice taste of citrus. I recomend this IPA!

A very good IPA. Smooth finish, nice hops flavor, some pine. Good citrus aroma. Not much citrus in the flavor though. Its good, but I dont know if Im really wild about it. It just doesnt have a whole lot of pow to in terms of citrus and hops. Quite easy to drink
UPDATED: MAY 24, 2009 Surprisingly darker golden, large amount of hops, most balanced IPA Ive enjoyed, a model for other IPAs.

Pours a dark golden color with a medium sized bubbly white head that settles to a thin film. Rings of lacing are left behind on the glass. Citrus, grassy, and piney hops come through in  the aroma. The flavor follows with the grassy and piney hops pushing forward, but are balanced out by a sweet caramel malt backbone. Medium bodied and very crisp on the palate. This one is easy drinking and finishes with a dry and bitterfinish. Solid IPA here.

12oz bottle from Whole Foods (Tampa, FL). Pours a slightly cloudy golden color with a one finger white head that settles quickly but laces the glass. Aroma is sweet and slightly floral with notes of citrus, honey, bread and yeast. Flavor is also sweet and floral with notes of grapefruit, honey, citrus, bread, some lemon and pine. Generally light to medium body with a pleasing hoppy finish.
Bottle: pours a cloudy amber with a foamy white head, sweet aroma of citrus, hops, taste hoppy, citrus, nice hoppy finish.  One fine IPA.
Pale orange our with a white head.  Strong aroma of hops.  Flavor is very hoppy with some citrus and yeast at the finish.  Very balanced and extremely drinkable.  Excellent.
Poured a clear golden with a somewhat rocky head.  Citrus notes straight away with a hop kick and clean finish.  Wow, outstanding beer and IPA.
12 oz bottle. Great Beer!!!! The only IPAs that are better in my opinion are Alesmith IPA, Bells Two Hearted, and Troegs Nugget Nectar.
I thought this was a very good IPA but definitely not worth the extra$ IMO. I would rather have a Flying Dod Snake Dog and use the extra cash for a cigar

Pours a cloudy gold/amber, medium white head with a creamy texture.  Decent lacing.  Strong aroma of hops, with citrus (grapefruit, lemon) and pine.  Underlying aromas of yeast.  Taste is extremely hoppy, with an excellent bite, and flavors of grapefruit balanced with a finish that is long and slightly on the sweet side.  Excellent beer.
A kick ass beer for all occasions. It has its own permanent space in the beer fridge.
Pours a clear copper with a small white head. Nose is bursting with strong hops, citrus and grapefruit. Flavor is all hops and incredibly refreshing a crisp.
Pours light and clear, and has good floral aromas and strong hoppy flavors.

Lots of concentrated grapefruit and citrus aromas up front then it started to settle out with an herbcious scent. It had a nice white head and the first sip had promise, but the aroma seemed more abundant than the flavor. It left nice thick laces on the sides of the pint glass. As expected it went extremely well with the super spicy tai chicken salad. Both flavors combined was an enormous firecracker. Paired with a dish "not worthy" of its spiciness would have been a train wreck.

22oz bottle.  Pours a mostly clear copper with a big white head.  Citrusy and piney hop aroma with just a touch of malty sweetness.  No sign of the sweetness in the flavor though.  Citrus hops all the way.  Quite crisp and delicious, but could stand to be a little more balanced.

i have slowly become a lover of beers that are over the top hoppy.  this one may be the best of the bunch so far.  Just picked up a sixer and the first two went down deliciously.  The sizzle on the tongue from the hops is unmistakeable.  Nothing about the look is going to warn you about the big character taste you get from this beer.  I cant wait to quit typing so I can pour another.

bottle.  Pours the color of raw amber with a nice white head.  Aroma of hops and lemon peel.  The mouthfeel is very light which really allows you to appreciate the hops in this one.  The best way to describe it is it just tastes fresh.  Fresh pine, fresh citrus.  It leaves a very clean feeling in your mouth along with a beautifully hoppy aftertaste

Clear copper with a small white head that leaves an immense amount of lacing... Slightly sweet aroma behind a wall of hops... Dry up front followed very quickly by a rush a very flavorful hops dominated by citrus flavors... I’ve had this countless times and sometimes i feel this to be horribly out of balance in a very hop forward manner, and other times i find it to be quite balanced with the sweet malts cutting through a bit...

1/4/09
shaker glass
gold apperance, small pinkie finger white head.  head dissapated quickly, but left a great lacing.   a blast of smooth hops to the nose, hints of apples and citrus.  delightfully smelling aroma.  very smooth on the palate.  smooth coming in, smooth going down, and only a slight bitter finish.  i’m very glad to see this beer make it to florida!  can get on tap at redlight redlight in orlando, and at total wine!!!

12 oz. Bottle. Pours a crystal clear golden-orange with a frothy, white head and decent lacing.  Great citrus hop aroma. Really smooth and well balanced. The flavor begins with a malty sweetness followed by an assertive grapefruity hop bitterness with a touch of pine. A light to medium body with a medium dry finish.

Bottle. A golden straw color with a fluffy white head,some soft lazy carbonation.Big hoppy aroma of floral citrus and spice .Big hops on the flavor,strait to the point some grapefruit,pine nuts,and orange zest,enough malt to make a showing here,nice fat crisp mouthfeel,with a hop coating. A thing of beauty

Bottle.  Pours an orangish, clear color with a white, frothy head.  Lacing is very strong.  Aromas of grapefruit, pine, and citrus from the hops.  Powerful aroma of hops!  Thin initial texture with a slick, oily finish.  Flavor is bitter all the way, although there is a bit of grapefruit toward the end that is nice.  Very good IPA.
Draft at Flying Saucer.  Golden color.  Awesome fruitiness from the hops.  Nice hoppy nose and a pleasant finish.  The alcohol came through this one just a bit.

Bottle from GBBF, drunk 30th Sept 08. Great dry hop aroma - lots of pine. Light amber with a lasting small white head. Very drinkable for a beer of over 6% but with sufficient body to let the flavours shine. Good dry finish. Straightforward but highly effective. Now pass me another one!
finally found this in south florida. hops are powerful and very well balanced with the malt. the after taste is awesome, full of hops.

Bottle--OK, I just missed the 1800 rating, so what else can I add.  Yummy, solid IPA, a wonderful benchmark.  Light gold color with a small/medium white head.  Solid hop taste without overwhelming.  Not much aroma.  Produce place.
Pours a light golden color with a white head.  Great tasting hops but does leave a little after taste to the mouth.  Very smooth palate and not your typical IPA.  Great brew!
Bottle. Nice orange colour. No head. Aroma and flavor is dominated by citrus/grapefruit hops. Bitter, but not exaggerated, aftertaste. Solid IPA.

Bottle at Oliver Twist, Stockholm.
It looks almost clear but I can´t see my finger throug the glass. Smells of grapefruit. Stone are great brewers, however this beer is a bit to easy and un-complex to impress. I think a lot of brewers could make this...
A good ale.  Well balanced and full of flavor.  A good/above averaged IPA.  Cheers.

Bottle to chilled glass.
Nice head.  Good lacing.  1 dimensional flavor.  Clean crisp hoppy finish
Yummy

Pours a beautiful dark golden color with a slightly orange hue. Really fluffy white head. Has a nice floral hoppy aroma, followed by an amazing fully hopped flavor. Goes down very smoothly, without any bitterness. I absolutely loved it! Best IPA in my samplings, hands down.

Bottle from Utobeer. Orange with a natural white head. Strong fresh hoppy and alcoholic aroma. Massive palate causing  pleasurable spasms on the tonge. Multilayered  flavours of citric fruits, particularly grapefruit with resinous piney notes. Fantastic, even at £6 a bottle.

Bottle (35 cl) at the Rover, Göteborg, Sweden. Cloudy amber/orange, low white head. Piney and apricot hop aroma, no malt character. Medium bodied and smooth. Well balanced, long bitter finish. Overrated.

It seems that ol Stone here is a well neglected treat this side The Isle of Mann.  Glad they finally got it here at Total Wine. I havnt checked Broudys yet.  Well, looking over Stones track record, I would say that had Wall Street invested their time in not being a bunch of dirty thugs, like Stone invest in producing a damn decent beverage on every occasion, I could quit my job and get another one tomorrow..on a Sunday!  Well, this pours a nice golden colour. Clarity is well deserved.  Nose is pine and Pilsner in style and a bit candied.  Taste is really like a candied Pilsner, hopped up and served...definitely not shaken. Very well balanced and highly enjoyable.  I like the fact that it really goes back and forth between an IPA and a Pilsner.  It keeps me gessing.  Lots of grapefruit in the aftertaste as well.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle this beer pours orange in color with a solid white creamy head.  You can smell the hops and citrus in this one from across the room.  Tasted of hops, citrus, pine and some spice.  Great combination and the carbonation on this was just right.  I little bit pricier than your average micro six pack but well worth it.  Great beer,
Poured cloudy yellow with an off-white head. Grapefruit aroma. Light and crisp with notes of citrus and grapefruit. Not overly bitter. Decent, but I do not quite get the hype.
Bottle. Pours a hazy gold color with a white head. Strong hop aroma. Hop and grapefruit flavors very smooth. Nice bitter finish.
Draft, pours a hazy yellow with a off white head.  Good hops and smooth crisp aroma.  Very nice taste with an okay kick.

Bottle. Hazy yellow color, brisk carbonation and a lingering foamy head. Flavor is sweet full bodied malt followed by a big kick of floral, grassy hops. Medium bodied. Finish is lingering, a bit sweet. Good IPA? For sure. Top 3 IPA in the world? Not sure. Would like to try one of these fresh on tap sometime. Will re-rate when I find the fresh version. For now the rating stands.
Golden Copper color, with a large head, the aroma has hops, and citrus.  The flavor is very hoppy, with a sweet malt.
Bottle: Great hops, flavorful, herbal, grassy, oil, great! Well rounded and crafted, excellent.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2009  Amber with an excellent off white head that lasts.  Hops and lychees along with a little vanilla in the aroma.  Something dusty about the taste. Perfectly balanced, fruity, hoppy and inoffensively dry.  A great smooth finish.

Amber  pour with white head.  Lots of hops and a typical bitterness of an IPA.  I do not understand why this is so highly rated, it does not really distinguish itself from the many other IPAs I have tried, just middle of the pack in my opinion.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2009 12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.99  Excellent.
Good in the bottle.  Better on tap at the brewery.  Tastes of grapefruit and hops.  Head with plenty of white foam.  Orange color.
Appearance: Orange with a small white head. Aroma: Hops, hops and more hops. Flavour: Amazing, hops, grapefruit juice, hops again, floral. Just wonderful. I wish I could have it more often.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2008 8.99 for a six pack at Total Wine.    Its been a long time coming to Florida..   Golden amber pour with a medium white head.  Strong aroma of sweet juicy hops.   Flavor is pretty much what you expect from a west coast hop bomb IPA.   Sweet pale malt on the front and then a huge hop blast and firm bitter end and aftertaste.   Lots of pine and grapefruit.   I let my wife taste it and she just got a pained expression on her face and handed it back to me.  A little too hoppy for her.   Extremely well done.
Amber pour with a thick and foamy head.  Oddly sweet scent.  Very distinct and unique taste.  A mike of corn like sweetness and bitter hops.  Tates unbalanced to me.  Interesting but I’m not a fan.

Orange pour with small frothy head. Lots of lacing. Citrus and pine aroma.
Flavor is same but lingering bitterness. Mouthfeel is ok. Prefer Ruination (I realize that’s a DIPA).

Bottle from College Liquors in Grand Junction, CO. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. The aroma is awesome; loads of sweet hops, juicy and ripe. The taste is just insanely quaffable; sweet grapefruit hops, some light bitterness in the finish, very clean and super easygoing. One of the best IPAs.

Very clear golden color with a nice white head.

Smell is of spicy hops with a hint o citrus.

The taste is very crisp and hoppy. The herbal, piny hops it first with the fruity hops adding immediately after. A nice malt presence envelops and cleanses the pallet to lead to a nice, smooth finish.

The drinkability of this brew is astounding. Quite possibly one of the smoothest IPAs I’ve ever had. Another top notch brew from stone.

Reviewed on: 08-17-2007

Typical west coast hop bomb. Not quite as great as Ruination, but not a whole hell of a lot behind it either. Nice little malty beginning before the hops hammer you down too, which is occasionally refreshing in a west coaster.

lots of american hop smell.  fruity floral, pours golden with minimal head.  fairly balanced slightly more on the hoppy side.  starts smooth and malty but quickly goes bitter.  slight lemon notes that are quite unique.  A nice beer that I can now get all the time!

Pours orange, white head.
Aroma is hoppy, grapefruit
Taste, hoppy and fruity, nice sugar, light caramel malts, with bitter hoppy finish. 
Just not a big fan of the West coast style IPA.
Bottle. The Rover, Gothenburg. Golden orange color with a white head. Aroma: Hops, mango, tropical fruit, sweet. Flavor: Soap, hoppy grape, pine, metall, unmatured banana, a bit too strong.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2009 Bottle. The Rover, Gothenburg. Golden orange color with a white head. Aroma: Hops, mango, tropical fruit, sweet malt.
Flavor: Hoppy, less sweet, grape, pine, metall. Very hoppy (off-course) but balanced and dry. The alcohol is a bit too strong.

Bottle 66cl. @ home.[ Courtesy of Secret Santa ]. Light light unclear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, pine, grapefruit, orange - apricot. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (030908)
UPDATED: NOV 18, 2008 One of the most sound IPAs I have tried.  It was my first Stone experience, and I was expecting a punch in the mouth, but got a wonderfully balanced IPA.

Nice fluffy white head. The beer is fairly orange in color. Nice ABV for a simple IPA. Fairly pungent hop aroma. Pine smelling hops. The beer is fairly transparent as well. Slightly creamy. The palate could be a bit better. The beer is full oh hop flavor. The dry hopping did pay off if you ask me. The bittering hop just gets all over the back of your mouth. I love this beer because the focus is all in the hops. Not really much to say about the   malts. Overall, a damn good bitter/hoppy IPA that I would love to drink a lot. Stone makes some pretty good brews. I feel the Arrogant Bastard and this are good, but the others are not as good as people say they are.
Beautiful hop aroma, like lemons squeezed on freshly mown grass. Lovely bitterness and good malt backbone. Excellent.

Pours a clear brilliant orange with zero sediment.  Medium head.  Citrus hops with possibly the best finish on any IPA out there, at least any I have ever have ever tried.  Beautifully, actually perfectly, blended IPA with just enough malt backbone to distinguish it from unnecessarily overhopped brews.  I love this stuff.  Glad it’s so easy to find.  Bravo.

Aroma is sweet like honey and fresh like mountain air, although a little weak.  Appearance is slightly opaque, with a hefe like quality and color.  Flavor is nice and sweet at first, then artisticly shifts over to bitter hops with a drawn out transition that reaches quite aptly in either direction.  Although I was disappointed  a little bit with the quality of the bitter sensation, but that’s just me.  Palate is fairly wet, but not thin or watery with plenty of carbonation and a tingling on the back of the throat.  Overall a great IPA but not quite my favorite.
Pours a clear orange with a frothy white head. Aromas of citrus, hops, and malt. Has a bitterness complemented by a slightly sweet, malty taste and a touch of grapefruit

Bottle. Pours a clear orange color with a small off white head. Aroma of cascade hops, caramel malt and grapefruit. Taste is hoppy and semi sweet. Another west coast hop monster but I do have to say that this one is relatively balanced though.

In short: A well-balanced highly drinkable IPA focusing on citrusy and resinous elements.
How: Bottle + tap many times.  This rating for a fresh 12oz bottle consumed a few days after purchase.  Drank side-by-side with the Stone Ruination IPA just for the fun of it
The look: Clear dark golden body topped by an initially large off-white head with medium retention and leaving excellent lacings
In long: Nose of citrus fruits with light pine-needles juicy notes.  More citrusy than the Ruination.  Taste proposes sweet maltiness with a 1/3 honey and 2/3 caramel flavour.  Finish is citrusy with resinous elements and the bitterness is not overwhelming like in the Stone Ruination IPA.  Some inherent spiciness in the hops reminding me of the Stone Pale Ale.  Im actually pretty sure the hopping of the Stone IPA has a lot in common with that of the Stone Pale Ale  This one is not as intense, as bitter or as dry as the Stone Ruination IPA but it really is better balanced.  Funny thing is despite all this I slightly prefer the totally unbalanced Ruination IPA.  IPAs are not girlfriends, being well balanced is not mandatory.

Bottle from Lithy, thanks! Orange blonde color. Malty perfumed grapefruit aroma with pineapple. Sweet but oily hopbitter, perfumed flavor. Mint, grapefruit and pineapple. The perfume spoils the fun a bit, this would have been a great beer otherwise.
Bottle:  A lot of real hoppy and light malt aroma.  Very fresh.  Nice crisp hope boquet ending with some light peach and more hops.  Damn good.
Draught. Medium high creamy and lasting head. Clear golden body. Dry hops and barley malt aroma and flavor with grassy notes. A bit boring.

Bottle. Light brown, clear pour, moderate head. Big floral hop aroma, with some citrus undertones.
Grassy hop taste, with just a little fruit. Very hops, very bitter. very delicious.
fantastic IPA. This beer defines what an IPA should be.
Has obvious hop scents with hints of cherries and pine.  Color is a golden color.  Tastes of hops with some fruit in it.  Nice aftertaste.  A descent IPA.
Big hoppy aroma.  Hoppy flavor with some maltiness to balance it.  Resinous aftertaste.  Good American IPA.
Bottled. Hazy golden color, thick whitish head. Hoppy aroma, slight grapefruit, lemon. Soft fruity taste, lemon, bitter. Bitter palate. Good stuff.

Reminds me of twohearted.  Great single IPA.  Got a case from FE pletchers in state college PA.  Very nice golden color some orange.  Nose is cut grass some malt.  Flavors of light citrus, medium hops.  Very well rounded and I would say somewhat perfected IPA.  Cheers!
Pours a nice coppery gold, with a thin white head. Awesome hopped up aroma. The taste is very smooth and dripping with hops, with a bit of citrus and pine mixed in. A beautiful IPA.

Pours a nice hazy golden amber with a thick, buttery, fine-bubbled head. Aroma is hoppy to the point of being piny. Flavor is rich and seriously hoppy, pleasantly bitter and evergreenish with just a touch of caramel sweetness. Finish is edgy and lively. A hop lover’s delight.

12 fl oz bottle from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. SE04/08.
App.:  Deep golden, clear, fair white foam.
  
Aroma:  Really sweet orange, blood orange, grapefruit, pine hops that has some grass and pepper notes, a bit fruity.
  
Palate:  Medium body and carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose  lots of pine and citrus notes, light caramel; somewhat fruity; kinda sweet and fairly bitter with light hops in the aftertaste.

Decent but not mind-blowing.

Pours a cloudy orange color with a thick white head that disapates in a few minutes.  Smells and taste of a decent amount of hops.   A solid IPA.

12 oz. bottle

Bright hazy orange, wispy tendrils of yeast(?) extending down the glass; frothy eggshell white head. Citric hop oil aroma. Floral citric hop flavor on light pale malt base. Cascade for the most part. A little one-dimensional but still tasty and very drinkable.

Bottle.  Wow, this is good.  Hoptastic aroma.  I want to bathe in this.  Taste is amazing.  Heavy hops, but not totally unbalanced.  Very quenching.  I could drink a few, and that’s what makes a great beer.
Draft. Very good hop aroma. A golden hue in color. Flavors of grapefruit and orange are prominent. A nice bitter finish. Very fine IPA!

Amber in color with a tiny, off white head with little to no lacing.  The aroma is of citrus, hops, and caramel.  The flavor is very hoppy and bitter throughout with notes of citrus and an orange peel finish.  The palate is syrupy.  Overall I’d say its a good IPA, not as good as Stone’s Ruination IPA, but nothing to be scoffed at.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Found at Tyler’s Bottle Shop. Pours a clear gold with moderate carbonation and a medium, white head. Pretty much all around the Ruination times 0.5. Even though I enjoy it a little less, in terms of everyday drinking this is more palatable. The hops insanity is very much toned down here allowing you to enjoy the citrus aroma a little more. The body is smoother and the aftertaste more neutral in contrast to the Ruination’s twenty minute lingering bitterness. For 70 IBU’s this is pretty sweet and creamy- no hops onslaught like you would expect.
Clear amber with a moderate off white head. Hoppy aroma with a hint of citrus. Flavor is very smooth, hoppy, and dry. Another great beer from Stone.

Pours a light copper with faint white head. Fantastic appearance. Aroma is of caramel, some fruit (esters at play), and plenty of American citrusy, resiny goodness. Medium body. Taste is of several varieties of sweet malt, followed by the flavor of American hops. Notice I didn’t say bitterness. Although over 70 IBUs, the flavor takes center stage. A great example of how flavoring hops should be used. One of my favorites.
This is a good IPA. Not only were the hops not biting, but there was a solid malt base that lingers in the aftertaste.

09/04/08 22oz

I had to re-review this to be fair. The only hop presence seems to be a very strong bitterness. Maybe I got a bad bottle but this sure was a disappointing IPA and I used to really like it.

12 oz bottle which I poured into a ruination mug. The color is dark yellow and almost clear. The smell is wonderful but not overwhelming. I think I can smell grapefruit, but better than grapefruit (cause I don’t like grapefruit). The taste is slightly bitter and the mouthfeel is pleasant. This beer goes down way too easy and that is why it is one of my favorites. This is yet another winner from the good folks down in San Diego.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-16-2007 01:20:05

Like the double IPA I had last night, this beer is much more golden in color than most.  It displays only a hint of amber hue.  A nice light yellow 2 finger head has good retention and leaves an oily lacing.  Aroma is hops galore with some dry hopping evident.  Nothing subtle about the flavor.  The hops come right at you with pine and grapefruit in the forefront.  Grass, biscuit, and floral notes as well.  Just the right amount of sweetness takes the edge off but still lets the hops star.  Incredibly well crafted.
